Sec. 2-63. - Other committees. 
All committees other than standing committees shall be appointed by the mayor, unless a ballot is called for by the members of council. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 1, 1-27-04; Ord. No. 2008-08, § 1, 1-22-08; Ord. No. 2012-58, § 1, 2-14-12; Ord. No. 2016-015, § 1, 1-26-16 )  
Sec. 2-64. - Reports to be signed by majority of committee. 
All reports shall be signed by a majority of the committee to whom the subject was referred. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 1, 1-27-04; Ord. No. 2008-08, § 1, 1-22-08; Ord. No. 2012-58, § 1, 2-14-12; Ord. No. 2016-015, § 1, 1-26-16 )  
Sec. 2-65. - Prayers, petitions and memorials not to be granted without referral to and report by committee; exception. 
No prayer, petition or memorial shall be granted, except by unanimous consent, without first being referred to its appropriate committee and until there has been a report from such committee. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 1, 1-27-04; Ord. No. 2008-08, § 1, 1-22-08; Ord. No. 2012-58, § 1, 2-14-12; Ord. No. 2016-015, § 1, 1-26-16 )  
Sec. 2-66. - Election of officers and commissioners. 
The election of all officers and commissioners shall be by roll call, the clerk of council to call the roll and every member to state for whom he desires to vote, except when otherwise provided for by ordinances, and the election shall be determined by a majority of votes actually given. When, however, there is only one nomination for any vacant office, the mayor shall cast the unanimous vote of council for that office; unless a councilmember specifically shall request a roll call. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 1, 1-27-04; Ord. No. 2008-08, § 1, 1-22-08; Ord. No. 2012-58, § 1, 2-14-12; Ord. No. 2016-015, § 1, 1-26-16 )  
Sec. 2-67. - Robert's Rules to be followed. 
The rules of parliamentary practice comprised in the current edition of Robert's Rules of Order shall govern the council in all cases to which they are applicable, and in which they are not inconsistent with the foregoing rules. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 1, 1-27-04; Ord. No. 2008-08, § 1, 1-22-08; Ord. No. 2012-58, § 1, 2-14-12; Ord. No. 2016-015, § 1, 1-26-16 )  
Sec. 2-68. - Election of mayor pro tempore. 
At the first meeting of each year, there shall be elected by ballot from the councilmembers, a mayor pro tempore who for the ensuing year, shall act as mayor, during the sickness or temporary absence of the mayor, and who shall not be re-elected to such office during the term, and in the event of the sickness or temporary absence of the mayor pro tempore, while acting as mayor, then and in that event, the chairman of the first standing committee in the order named in section 2-49, who shall be in the city and available, shall be acting mayor in said interim. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 1, 1-27-04; Ord. No. 2008-08, § 1, 1-22-08; Ord. No. 2012-58, § 1, 2-14-12; Ord. No. 2016-015, § 1, 1-26-16 )  
Sec. 2-69. - Petitions and memorials. 
All communications to the city council shall be by petition or memorial. None other than members of council shall be heard on any petition or memorial without the unanimous consent of council, except that during a period of thirty (30) minutes of each regular meeting the mayor may recognize citizens of Charleston who wish to address council on matters of city business. City council shall be provided, by the office of the clerk of council, with a published agenda the Thursday before each regular meeting. The deadline for submitting items to be considered at the city council and ways and means committee shall be noon on the Monday of the week prior to the scheduled meetings. A two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote of the council members present shall be required for a matter to be added to the agenda after it has been closed. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 1, 1-27-04; Ord. No. 2008-08, § 1, 1-22-08; Ord. No. 2010-84, § 2, 4-27-10; Ord. No. 2012-58, § 1, 2-14-12; Ord. No. 2016-015, § 1, 1-26-16 )  
Sec. 2-70. - Ways and means committee to hold meetings every month and public works and utilities to hold meetings when necessary, to carry out the provisions of section 2-52(a). 
The ways and means committee of city council shall hold at least one meeting every month for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of section 2-52(a). The public works and utilities committee of city council shall hold meetings as necessary for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of section 2-52(a). Meetings of the public works and utilities committee shall be called at the discretion of the committee chairman or when at least one-third ( 1/3 ) of the committee requests a meeting in writing. When any matter is referred to any committee at any regular or extra meeting of council, said committee shall meet and take action on such matters before the next regular meeting, reporting thereon at said meeting, and to every subsequent meeting until said matter reaches final disposition. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 1, 1-27-04; Ord. No. 2008-08, § 1, 1-22-08; Ord. No. 2012-58, § 1, 2-14-12; Ord. No. 2016-015, § 1, 1-26-16 )  
Sec. 2-71. - Rescission, suspension or alteration of rules. 
Any of the foregoing rules, except those requiring unanimous consent, can be rescinded, suspended, or altered by a majority of three-fourths (¾) of the members present. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 1, 1-27-04; Ord. No. 2008-08, § 1, 1-22-08; Ord. No. 2012-58, § 1, 2-14-12; Ord. No. 2016-015, § 1, 1-26-16 )  
Sec. 2-72. - Procedure upon absence of quorum. 
(a)  No member of council shall absent himself/herself from the service of city council without leave. If at any time during the sessions of city council, a question shall be raised by any councilmember, as to the presence of a quorum, or if needed, a money quorum, the mayor or presiding officer shall forthwith direct the clerk of council to call the roll, and shall announce the result, and these proceedings shall be without debate. 
(b)  Whenever upon such roll call it shall be ascertained that a quorum, or if needed, a money quorum, is not present a majority of the members of council present may direct the sergeant-at-arms to request and when necessary, to compel, the attendance of the absent members of council, which order shall be determined without debate; and, pending its execution, and until a quorum or, if needed, a money quorum, shall be present, no motion, except to adjourn, shall be in order. 
(c)  The clerk of council, or any proper person deputized by the clerk shall be the sergeant-at-arms. 
(Ord. No. 2004-06, § 1, 1-27-04; Ord. No. 2008-08, § 1, 1-22-08; Ord. No. 2012-58, § 1, 2-14-12; Ord. No. 2016-015, § 1, 1-26-16 )  
Secs. 2-73—2-85. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-86. - Conflict of interest. 
Any municipal officer or employee who has a substantial financial interest in any business which contracts with the municipality for sale or lease of land, materials, supplies, equipment or services, or who personally engages in such matters shall make known that interest and refrain from voting upon or otherwise participating in his capacity as a city officer or employee in matters related thereto. Any city officer or employee who willfully conceals such a substantial financial interest or willfully violates the requirements of this section shall be guilty of malfeasance in office and upon conviction shall forfeit his office or position. Violations of this section with the knowledge express or implied of the person or corporation contracting with or making a sale to the city shall render the contract or sale voidable by the municipal governing body. 
(Code 1975, § 1-9; Ord. No. 1977-71, § 1(1-9), 11-8-77) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-130.  
Sec. 2-87. - Employment procedures. 
City employees shall be employed in accordance with the current classification and compensation plan of the city and with the approval of the mayor; provided, however, that the mayor is empowered in any emergency or for increased efficiency in government to refrain from filling any vacancy in any department or division, or to transfer any individual on the payroll from one department or division to another; provided, however, the mayor may delegate this authority as he may deem appropriate. 
(Code 1975, § 2-25)  
Sec. 2-88. - Medical examination prerequisite to employment. 
Each employee shall submit to medical examination by the city physician prior to his or her employment. Employment shall be contingent upon the medical report as approved by the city physician and personnel director. These reports shall remain in the custody of the personnel director and shall not be released to others without written authorization from the employee. All files are subject to review as requested by the employer; this is to include committee functioning as a part of the city.  
Sec. 2-89. - Political campaigns. 
No city employee shall participate in a city election campaign during paid working hours, and no city employee shall identify himself or herself as a city employee if otherwise participating in a city election campaign. Nothing herein shall be construed to apply to elected officials of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1999-75, § 1, 5-18-99)  
Sec. 2-90. - Selective Service System registration. 
(a)  Findings. Federal law requires all male citizens and all male immigrant non-citizens living in the United States to register with the Selective Service System upon the attainment of eighteen (18) years of age. While the all-volunteer military force policy has proven successful, registration with the Selective Service System remains a vital component of national security strategy. Should a draft be required in the future, such draft must be as fair as possible, and fairness dictates that all eligible persons be appropriately registered with the Selective Service System. Further, registration with the Selective Service System has value as it is a prerequisite for federal student aid, job training, government employment and U.S. citizenship. City council has determined it to be fair, reasonable and in furtherance of federal policy to require, as a condition of employment, that any male job applicant between the ages of eighteen (18) and twenty-six (26) provide proof of registration with the Selective Service System or appropriate deferment credentials. 
(b)  From and after the effective date hereof [Oct. 24, 2000], every male between the ages of eighteen (18) and twenty-six (26) who seeks employment with the City of Charleston shall submit documentation evidencing registration with the Selective Service System or documentation evidencing exemption from such registration. 
(Ord. No. 2000-247, § 1, 10-24-00)  
Secs. 2-91—2-95. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - MAYOR[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Appointment by mayor of member of county boxing commission, S.C. Code 1976, § 52-3-30; appointment by mayor of commissioners of housing authority, S.C. Code 1976, § 31-3-340. 
 
Sec. 2-96. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The mayor shall be the chief administrator of and executive officer of the city. He shall be responsible to the city council for the administration of all city affairs and the execution of all laws and ordinances. 
(b)  The mayor shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To appoint and, when he deems it necessary for the good of the municipality, suspend or remove all municipal employees and appointive administrative officers, except as otherwise provided by law or personnel rules adopted pursuant to state law. He may authorize any administrative officer who is subject to his direction and supervision to exercise these powers with respect to subordinates in that officer's department, office or agency; 
(2)  To direct and supervise the administration of all departments, offices and agencies of the municipality except as otherwise provided by state law; 
(3)  To preside at meetings of the city council and vote as other council members; 
(4)  To act to ensure that all laws, provisions of state law and ordinances of the council, subject to enforcement by him or by officers subject to his direction and supervision, are faithfully executed; 
(5)  To prepare and submit the annual budget and capital program to the city council; 
(6)  To submit to the council and make available to the public a complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the municipalities at the end of each fiscal year; 
(7)  To make such other reports as the city council may require concerning the operations of municipal departments, offices and agencies subject to his direction and supervision. 
(8)  To call special meetings of the city council; and 
(9)  To fill vacancies on committees, boards and commissions appointed by him. 
(Code 1975, § 2-1; Ord. No. 1977-71, § 1(2-1), 11-8-77)  
Sec. 2-97. - Compensation; holding other office. 
The mayor shall devote his full time and efforts to serving as mayor, and shall receive such compensation as the city council shall from time to time provide, but no ordinance changing such compensation shall become effective until the date of commencement of the term of the mayor elected in the next general election following the change. The mayor may also receive payment for actual expenses incurred in the performance of his official duties within limitations prescribed by ordinance. Except where authorized by law, no mayor shall hold any other municipal office or municipal employment while serving the term for which he was elected. 
(Code 1975, § 2-3; Ord. No. 1977-71, § 1(2-3), 11-8-77) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, §§ 5-7-170, 5-7-180.  
Sec. 2-98. - Mayor pro tempore. 
At the first regular meeting of council in January of each year there shall be elected by ballot from the board of council members, a mayor pro tempore who for the ensuing year, shall act as mayor, during the sickness or temporary absence of the mayor, and who shall not be reelected to such office during the term, and in the event of the sickness or temporary absence of the mayor pro tempore, while acting as mayor, then and in that event, the chairman of the first standing committee in the order named in section 2-50, who shall be in the city and available, shall be acting mayor in such interim. 
(Code 1975, § 2-4; Ord. No. 1977-71, § 1(2-4), 11-8-77; Ord. No. 1980-32, § 1(XXIX), 1-22-80) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-190.  
Sec. 2-99. - Vacancy. 
Vacancy in office of the mayor shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term at the next regular election or at a special election if the vacancy occurs one hundred eighty (180) days or more prior to the next general election. 
(Code 1975, § 2-5; Ord. No. 1977-71, § 1(2-5), 11-8-77) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-200(b).  
Sec. 2-100. - Forfeiture of office. 
The mayor shall forfeit his office if he 
(1)  Lacks at any time during his term of office any qualification for the office prescribed by the general law and Constitution; 
(2)  Violates any expressed prohibition of Chapters 1 through 17 of Title 5 of the South Carolina Code of Laws of 1976; or 
(3)  Is convicted of any crime involving moral turpitude. 
(Code 1975, § 2-6; Ord. No. 1977-71, § 1(2-6), 11-8-77) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-200(a).  
Secs. 2-101—2-105. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

Sec. 2-106. - Department established. 
There is hereby established a department to be known as the office of the corporation counsel. 
(Code 1975, § 2-28; Ord. No. 1978-7, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Sec. 2-107. - Appointment. 
The corporation counsel shall be appointed by the mayor, with the approval of city council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-29; Ord. No. 1978-7, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Sec. 2-108. - Duties and responsibilities of department. 
(a)  The office of the corporation counsel shall advise the city council, the mayor, and city departments in all matters of a legal nature, shall act as prosecutor in municipal court, shall make appearances in all courts when required to do so, and shall draft such instruments of a legal nature as may be required by his office. 
(b)  Corporation counsel shall consult with the mayor as to the best method of handling all matters referred to him by the mayor and shall conduct and dispose of all cases placed in his hands by the mayor in such manner as the mayor shall direct. The corporation counsel shall attend all meetings of council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-30; Ord. No. 1978-8, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Sec. 2-109. - Administration of department. 
The management, direction, and control of the department shall be under the supervision of the corporation counsel. 
(Code 1975, § 2-31; Ord. No. 1978-8, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Sec. 2-110. - Same—Appointment of personnel. 
The corporation counsel shall have the power to hire, with the approval of the mayor, such personnel in such positions as are provided for in the budget of the department as approved by the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-32; Ord. No. 1978-8, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Sec. 2-111. - Private legal practice. 
The corporation counsel and such members of his staff as are hired on a part-time basis shall be allowed to continue in the private practice of law, but they shall be prohibited from representing clients in and before the city council, the municipal court or before any boards or commissions of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 2-33; Ord. No. 1978-8, § 1, 1-24-78; Ord. No. 2003-09, § 1, 1-28-03)  
Sec. 2-112. - Same—Employment of additional counsel. 
The mayor, in his discretion, shall be authorized, on particular occasions, to engage the services of additional counsel, the compensation for such services to be provided by the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-34; Ord. No. 1978-8, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Secs. 2-113—2-120. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - CLERK OF COUNCIL[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Clerk of municipality as secretary of commissioners of the public works, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-31-240; municipal clerk, 5-7-220. 
 
Sec. 2-121. - Office established. 
There is hereby established the office of the clerk of council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-22; Ord. No. 1978-9, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Sec. 2-122. - Appointment. 
The clerk of council shall be appointed by the mayor, with the approval of the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-23; Ord. No. 1978-9, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Sec. 2-123. - Duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  The clerk of council shall be the custodian of the seal of the city and official records of the city council, and shall provide administrative research and clerical support services to the city council. The clerk of council shall attend all meetings of the city council and its committees. 
(b)  The clerk of the city council shall have the journals of the city council printed in pamphlet form, make an index thereto, and have them bound periodically. 
(c)  The clerk of council shall have all ordinances to be presented to the council prepared in proper form for ratification, and shall see that the ordinances are codified. 
(d)  The clerk of council shall be the custodian of all documents, books, records and papers of the city government and shall be responsible for the establishment and maintenance of a citywide records management program to maintain, protect, retain or dispose of city records in accordance with government regulations, legal requirements and city historical and reference needs. Duties and responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the creation of city records, filing and housing of active records, preparation and issuance of approved records retention schedules, establishment and operation of a centralized records storage facility, management of centralized microfilming and the establishment of appropriate procedures and practices to carry out these functions. 
(e)  The clerk of council shall have oversight responsibilities for the arts and history commission and the tourism commission, including the power to hire, with the approval of the mayor, the manager of the arts and history/tourism commissions, as is provided for in the budget of the clerk of council as approved by city council. The clerk of council shall also have supervisory and oversight responsibilities for the manager of the arts and history/tourism commissions. 
(Ord. No. 1978-9, § 1, 1-24-78; Ord. No. 1990-7, § 1, 1-23-90; Ord. No. 2015-164, § 8, 11-10-15 )  
Sec. 2-124. - Administration of office. 
The management, direction, and control of the office shall be under the supervision of the clerk of council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-25; Ord. No. 1978-9, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Sec. 2-125. - Appointment of personnel. 
The clerk of council shall have the power to hire, with the approval of the mayor, such deputy clerks or other personnel in such positions as are provided for in the budget of the office of the clerk of council as approved by city council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-26; Ord. No. 1978-9, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Sec. 2-126. - Clerk pro tempore; appointment. 
In case of the unavoidable absence or sickness of the clerk, the mayor shall appoint a clerk pro tempore, who, during such appointment, shall perform all duties of the clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 2-27; Ord. No. 1978-9, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Secs. 2-127—2-135. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - BONDS 
 
Sec. 2-136. - Required; conditions. 
Except as otherwise provided, such city officers and employees as shall be designated by the committee on ways and means shall be bonded in such amounts as required by the committee on ways and means. All bonds shall be payable to the city council and conditioned for the faithful performance of all the duties of the respective officers or employees, as defined and set forth by the provisions of the Code. 
(Code 1975, § 2-32)  
DIVISION 6. - MUNICIPAL COURT OPERATIONS 
 
Sec. 2-137. - Division responsibilities. 
With the exception of those powers and duties set forth in chapter 20 of this Code, the division shall be responsible for the management and proper administration of all facets of the city's municipal court operations in support of the city's chief municipal judge and other municipal judges who serve the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § 3, 3-9-10)  
Sec. 2-138. - Duties of administrator. 
The administration and control of the division shall be under the supervision of the municipal court administrator. The municipal court administrator shall be responsible to the chief municipal judge for matters concerning legal processes and issues within the court, but shall be under the direct supervision of the department of budget, finance and revenue collections. 
(Ord. No. 2010-38, § 4, 3-9-10; Ord. No. 2012-240, § 2, 5-8-12)  
Secs. 2-139—2-150. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS[6]

Cross reference— Yacht basin commission, § 2-235; board of commissioners of Colonial Common and Ashley River Embankment, § 9-16 et seq.; board of commissioners of Cypress Gardens, § 10-16 et seq.; municipal election commission, § 11-21 et seq.; board of firemasters, § 13-41 et seq.; board of trustees of firemen's insurance and inspection fund, § 13-51; bureau of inspection of oil burning equipment, § 13-146 et seq.; tourism commission, § 29-31 et seq.; administrative relationship of chief building official to department of public service, § 7-5; obstructing or interfering with public service facility personnel, § 21-195. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-151. - Organizational meetings upon election by council; notice. 
(a)  Upon their election by the city council, the members of the respective commissions, boards and committees shall meet for purposes of organization, within forty-five (45) days from the date of their election, and for this purpose they shall be called together by the clerk of council, who shall give to each member of such boards, written notice of the time and place thereof five (5) days previous to such meeting. 
(b)  At such organizational meeting, commissions and boards shall elect a chairman and may elect a member or employee as secretary or treasurer or secretary and treasurer, to serve without compensation. Thereafter boards and commissions shall meet at such time and place as each shall elect. 
(Code 1975, § 2-11)  
Sec. 2-152. - Term of office; staggered terms. 
(a)  Findings. City council finds that there are a number of city boards and commissions that have vacancies that may need to be filled or that have members serving in a holdover capacity who may need to be reappointed or replaced. City council finds that it is in the public interest for the terms of members of boards and commissions in the city that are in excess of one (1) year to be staggered so there remains a sense of continuity and experience as members of boards and commissions roll off and new members are appointed. The purpose of this section is to establish a commencement date of terms of boards and commissions and to stagger the terms of the members of those boards and commissions whose members have terms in excess of one (1) year, where such does not now occur. 
(b)  Terms of boards and commissions shall commence on March 1 of a given year. 
(c)  On the following boards and commissions, appointments made between December 20, 2016 and February 28, 2017, one-half (½) of the members (or one-half (&half), plus one (1) when the number of members is odd) so appointed shall serve for two (2) years, and the other one-half (½) shall serve out the term of the member being replaced or in which a vacancy exists, as determined by city council, to wit: 
Berkeley -Charleston- Dorchester (BCD) Council of Government 
Bicycle and Pedestrian Advisory Committee 
Charleston Regional Development Alliance 
Half-Cents Sales Tax Citizens Committee 
Jury Commission 
Minority Business Enterprise Advisory Board 
Sustainability Advisory Board 
Thereafter, all members appointed shall serve two-year terms, or until their successors are appointed. 
(d)  On the following boards and commissions, appointments made between December 20, 2016 and February 28, 2017, one-third ( 1/3 ) of the members (or one-third of the members, plus one (1), or when the number of members is not divisible by three (3)) so appointed shall serve for three (3) years, and one-third ( 1/3 ) of the members so appointed shall serve out the term of the member being replaced or in which a vacancy exists for two years, and one-third (frax;1;3>) of the members so appointed or in which a vacancy exists shall serve for one (1) year, as determined by city council, to wit: 
Charleston Regional Transportation Authority Board 
Commission for Women 
Commission on Disability Issues 
Planning Commission 
Town and Gown Committee 
Tourism Commission 
Thereafter, all members shall serve three-year terms, or until their successors are appointed. 
(e)  On the following boards and commissions, appointments made between December 20. 2016 and February 28, 2017, one-half (&half) of the members (or one-half (&half), plus one (1) when the number of members is odd) so appointed shall serve for four (4) years, and the other one-half (½) shall serve out the term of the member being replaced or in which a vacancy exists for a period of two (2) years, as determined by city council, to wit: 
Charleston Aviation Authority 
Charleston Museum Board of Trustees 
Design Review Board 
Fire Department One Percent Committee 
Thereafter, all members shall serve four-year terms, or until their successors are appointed. 
(f)  On the following boards and commissions, appointments made between December 20, 2016 and February 28, 2017, one-half (½) of the members (or one-half (½), plus one (1) when the number of members is odd) so appointed shall serve for five (5) years, and the other one-half (½) shall serve out the term of the member being replaced or in which a vacancy exists for a period of two (2) years, as determined by city council, to wit: 
Housing Authority of the City of Charleston 
Thereafter, all members appointed shall serve five-year terms, or until their successors are appointed. 
(g)  On the following boards and commissions, appointments made between December 20, 2016 and February 28, 2017, one-third ( 1/3 of the members so appointed shall serve for six (6) years, and one-third ( 1/3 of the members so appointed shall serve out the term of the member being replaced or in which a vacancy exists for four (4) years, and one-third ( 1/3 of the members so appointed shall serve out the term of the member being replaced or in which a vacancy exists shall serve for two (2) years, as determined by city council, to wit: 
Municipal Election Commission 
Thereafter, all members appointed shall serve terms of six (6) years, or until their successors are appointed. 
(h)  The terms and appointment of members of the Board of Architectural Review—Large and Board of Architectural Review—Small shall be in accordance with the provisions of section 54-233 of the Zoning Ordinance and the terms and appointments of municipal judges shall be in accordance section 20-4 of the Code of the City of Charleston. 
(i)  On the following boards and commissions, for appointments made between December 20, 2016 and February 28, 2017, two (2) members so appointed shall serve for a term of three (3) years, two (2) members so appointed shall serve for a term of two (2) years, and three (3) members shall serve for a term on one (1) year, as determined by city council, to wit: 
Board of Zoning Appeals—Site Design 
Board of Zoning Appeals—Zoning 
Thereafter, all members appointed shall serve terms of three (3) years, or until their successors are appointed. 
(j)  On the following boards and commissions, for appointments made between December 20, 2016 and February 28, 2017, one member shall so appointed shall serve for five (5) years, one (1) member so appointed shall serve out the term of the member being replaced or for which there is a vacancy for four (4) years, one (1) member so appointed shall serve out the term of the member being replaced or for which there is a vacancy for three (3) years, one (1) member so appointed shall serve out the term of the member being replaced or for which there is a vacancy for a period of two (2) years, and one (1) member so appointed shall serve out the term of the member being replaced or for which there is a vacancy for a period of one (1) year, as determined by city council, to wit: 
Building Code Board of Appeals 
Thereafter, all members appointed shall serve terms of five (5) years, or until their successors are appointed. 
(k)  On the following boards and commissions, members appointed between December 20, 2016 and February 28, 2017 shall serve for terms of one (1) year, and continue until their successors are appointed: 
Accommodations Tax Advisory Committee Carolina Art Association Board
