ARTICLE XI. - DEPARTMENT OF BUDGET, FINANCE AND REVENUE COLLECTIONS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-324. - Establishment. 
There is hereby established a department to be known as the Department of Budget, Finance and Revenue Collections. 
(Ord. No. 1998-162, § 1, 9-8-98)  
Sec. 2-325. - Duties and responsibilities of the department. 
The department shall have the general responsibility for the administration, supervision and management of the city's financial affairs including: budget preparation and administration; management improvement initiatives; enterprise contract administration and oversight; capital improvement plan development and oversight; accounting; cash flow and investment strategy; payroll preparation and reporting, revenue forecasting, collections and reporting; risk management; debt management; fixed asset management; the city municipal court administration with the exception of those powers and duties set forth in Chapter 20 herein, all city procurement; management of all city-owned and city-leased property; on and off-street parking program and facilities; special facilities management to include the Gaillard Auditorium, the Dock Street Theatre, the Visitors' Reception and Transportation Center and the Charleston Maritime Center; and safety management for city employees, including the administration of the city's workers' compensation program, the establishment and compliance of written safety procedures, conducting and coordinating safety training; regulatory compliance for safety management; and minority business enterprise. 
(Ord. No. 1998-162, § 1, 9-8-98; Ord. No. 2000-19, § 1, 2-8-00; Ord. No. 2003-22, § 3, 2-11-03; Ord. No. 2006-596, § 1(a), 12-19-06; Ord. No. 2014-10, § 3, 1-30-14)  
Sec. 2-326. - Administration; duties of director; bonds; vouchers. 
(a)  The administration, direction and control of the department shall be under the supervision of the chief financial officer who shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of council. In the absence of the chief financial officer ("CFO"), assistant CFOs assume the direction and control of the department. Two (2) assistant CFOs shall be appointed by the CFO with the approval of the mayor. 
(b)  The chief financial officer (CFO) serves as chief financial advisor of the city, and shall be responsible for the management and administration of all city finances, attend to the proper compilation and disbursement of the city payroll, be the custodian of all contracts, insurance policies, cancelled bonds or cancelled coupons, or other appropriate evidence thereof, formulate and oversee implementation of all policies and practices related to budget, finance and revenue decisions affecting the city, shall prepare and submit to the city council an annual budget of all city operations, and attend to such other duties and responsibilities as may be delegated from time to time by the mayor and city council. 
(c)  The chief financial officer shall be required to give the city council a bond of not less than five hundred thousand ($500,000.00) dollars and shall also require a bond in a like amount of the two (2) assistant CFOs, the finance director and the assistant finance director. The CFO shall further see that all other employees of the department of BFRC who handle cash receipts are bonded in an amount not less than twenty-five thousand ($25,000.00) dollars. 
(d)  The chief financial officer shall sign all orders, vouchers, accounts and authorizations for payments thereof and is vested with the authority to delegate to the two (2) assistant CFOs or director of finance the authority to sign such orders, vouchers, accounts or authorization for the payment thereof as he or she deems appropriate. In the absence of the CFO or his or her designee, the mayor, or in his/her absence, the chairman of the ways and means committee or in his/her absence any member of the ways and means committee in the order of his/her rank of appointment, according as his/her immediate superior may be absent, is hereby authorized to sign in the place and stead of the CFO or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 1998-162, § 1, 9-8-98; Ord. No. 2003-22, §§ 4, 5, 2-11-03; Ord. No. 2014-10, § 4, 1-30-14)  
Sec. 2-327. - Divisions. 
The department of budget, finance and revenue collections shall be comprised of the budget and management division, the finance division, the revenue collections division, the procurement division, the special facilities division, the municipal court administration division, the safety management division and the minority business enterprise division. 
(Ord. No. 1998-162, § 1, 9-8-98; Ord. No. 2000-19, § 2, 2-8-00; Ord. No. 2003-22, § 6, 2-11-03; Ord. No. 2006-596, § 1(b), 12-19-06; Ord. No. 2014-10, § 5, 1-30-14)  
DIVISION 2. - BUDGET AND MANAGEMENT DIVISION 
 
Sec. 2-328. - Division responsibilities. 
This division is responsible for the preparation of the annual budget and for providing assistance to city departments in departmental budget preparation, process analyses, and cost-benefit analyses. This division shall also be responsible for enterprise contract management within the city. The budget and management division shall be managed by the budget director, who shall be appointed by the CFO, with approval of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 1998-162, § 1, 9-8-98; Ord. No. 2003-22, § 7, 2-11-03)  
Sec. 2-329. - Duties of the director. 
The budget director shall be responsible for directing the compilation of the city's annual general fund budget, shall assist departments in budget formulation, track revenues and expenditures, assist in development of trend analyses for recurring expenses and for all revenue sources, administer enterprise activity contracts, and evaluate organization structures and operations for sound management practices that improve efficiency and effectiveness, and shall perform any other duties and responsibilities delegated by the CFO. 
(Ord. No. 1998-162, § 1, 9-8-98; Ord. No. 2003-22, § 8, 2-11-03)  
DIVISION 3. - FINANCE DIVISION 
 
Sec. 2-330. - Division responsibilities. 
This division is responsible for the accounting and reporting of all city revenue collections and expenditure disbursements. The division is also responsible for cash management, fixed asset accounting, and preparation of the annual external audit report. The finance division shall be managed by a finance director, who shall be appointed by the CFO, with the approval of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 1998-162, § 1, 9-8-98; Ord. No. 2003-22, § 9, 2-11-03)  
Sec. 2-331. - Duties and responsibilities of director. 
The finance director shall be responsible for the prompt and accurate collection of all monies owed the city and the proper disbursement of the same pursuant to the direction of the CFO, depositing the monies of the city in appropriate accounts, establishing and maintaining records of all monies collected and disbursed including any uncollected taxes or special assessments made by or to the city, in accordance with generally accepted accounting, attending to and assuring that all properties within the city are properly listed and assessed and that all taxes owing to the city thereon are collected, acting as the custodian of investment securities of the city and submitting to the CFO, the mayor and city council from time to time and as requested but at least annually, an accounting of city monies received, collected and disbursed. The finance director shall be entitled to make all refunds of monies received but not due to the city up to five thousand ($5,000.00) without the approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1998-162, § 10, 9-8-98; Ord. No. 2014-10, § 6, 1-30-14)  
Sec. 2-332. - Annual audit. 
The books and accounts of the finance division shall be audited at the close of each fiscal year by an independent certified public accountant selected by the audit committee of the city council for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 1998-162, § 1, 9-8-98)  
DIVISION 4. - REVENUE COLLECTIONS DIVISION 
 
Sec. 2-333. - Division responsibilities. 
The revenue collections division shall be responsible for the revenue collection pursuant to the direction of the chief financial officer, including depositing the monies of the city in the appropriate accounts. This division shall include such activities as the collection of business license fees, hospitality tax fees, parking and parking ticket fees and other fees, permitting fees or special fees as directed by the ordinance. The division shall also have responsibility for the enforcement of the city's business license ordinance or other ordinances related to the collection of city revenues. The revenue collection division shall be managed by the revenue collections director, who shall be appointed by the CFO with approval of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 1998-162, § 1, 9-8-98; Ord. No. 2003-22, § 11, 2-11-03; Ord. No. 2014-10, § 7, 1-30-14)  
Sec. 2-334. - Duties of the director. 
The revenue collections director shall be responsible for directing the collection of all city revenues as assigned by the chief financial officer, the business license committee, or the ways and means committee in an efficient, effective and customer focused manner, shall recommend potential revenue sources, shall implement procedures to comply with the city's business license ordinance and other revenue collection ordinances, shall develop operating procedures to ensure adequate cash management controls and shall perform any other responsibilities delegated by the CFO. 
(Ord. No. 1998-162, § 1, 9-8-98; Ord. No. 2003-22, § 12, 2-11-03)  
DIVISION 5. - PROCUREMENT DIVISION 
 
Sec. 2-335. - Director. 
The Procurement Division of the Department of Budget, Finance and Revenue Collection shall be managed by the director of procurement who shall be appointed by the CFO, with the approval of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 2000-19, § 3, 2-8-00; Ord. No. 2003-22, § 13, 2-11-03)  
Sec. 2-336. - Duties, responsibilities of director. 
The director of procurement shall be responsible for making all city purchases of commodities, supplies and technical services to be utilized by the departments under the jurisdiction of the city council, implementing a standard procedure to be utilized by city departments and agencies in ordering supplies of commodities, properly storing, maintaining and otherwise protecting such supplies or commodities and maintaining an accurate accounting of orders from departments and agencies which shall be turned over to the director of budget, finance and revenue collection to be credited to the proper accounts. 
(Ord. No. 2000-19, § 3, 2-8-00)  
Sec. 2-337. - Guidelines for acquisition and storage of goods and supplies. 
The director of procurement shall prescribe guidelines for use by the departments of the city in the ordering, storage, maintenance and inventory control of city goods and supplies. 
(Ord. No. 2000-19, § 3, 2-8-00)  
Sec. 2-338. - Purchases to be let in fair and impartial manner, protection of city interests. 
The director of procurement shall see that all city purchases are let in a fair and impartial manner and in accordance with such procurement policies as may, from time to time, be adopted by the city council, and shall work with the appropriate city departments to assure that the interests of the city are duly protected. 
(Ord. No. 2000-19, § 3, 2-8-00)  
Sec. 2-339. - Approval of purchases over $40,000 required. 
Any purchase, as provided for in section 2-336, except purchases budgeted by the council and not exceeding forty thousand dollars ($40,000.00) shall be submitted to the committee on ways and means for approval of such committee before such purchase shall be made. 
(Ord. No. 2000-19, § 3, 2-8-00; Ord. No. 2003-22, § 14, 2-11-03; Ord. No. 2010-269, § 2, 12-21-10; Ord. No. 2014-10, § 8, 1-30-14)  
DIVISION 6. - SPECIAL FACILITIES 
 
Sec. 2-340. - Director. 
The special facilities division of the department of budget, finance and revenue collections shall be managed by the director of special facilities who shall be appointed by the CFO with the approval of the mayor. The director shall have responsibility for all special facilities of the City of Charleston. 
(Ord. No. 2000-19, § 4, 2-8-00; Ord. No. 2003-22, § 16, 2-11-03; Ord. No. 2014-10, § 9, 1-30-14)  
Sec. 2-341. - Bond required. 
The manager of the Municipal Auditorium box office shall give bond in a sum determined by the director of budget, finance and revenue collection and subject to the approval of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 2000-19, § 4, 2-8-00)  
DIVISION 7. - SAFETY MANAGEMENT DIVISION[19] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 2-342. - Safety management division responsibilities. 
The division shall be responsible for establishing and ensuring regulatory compliance with written safety procedures, conducting and coordinating safety training, and administering the city's workers' program as may be established or amended by city council from time to time, and such other duties as may be assigned to it by the CFO, mayor or city council.

DIVISION 8. - MINORITY BUSINESS ENTERPRISE[20] 

Footnotes: 
--- (20) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2014-10, §§ 1, 2, adopted Jan. 30, 2014, retitled Div. 8, formerly reserved, as herein set out. The editor has renumbered the provisions of former 2-267, pertaining to the office of minority business development as § 2-344. 
 
Sec. 2-344. - Establishment of the office of minority business development. 
(a)  Establishment. There is hereby established the office of minority business development (also referred to as "MBD") that shall be a division of the department of budget, finance and revenue collections and said office shall be administered by a director who, in turn, shall report to the mayor. 
(b)  Duties and responsibilities of director. The MBD director shall be responsible for administering the minority business development plan as adopted by city council, from time to time, to increase participation of disadvantaged and women business enterprises. The director shall also establish programs, subject to the approval of the mayor, to assist potential entrepreneurs and existing small business owners through the following: 
(1)  Assisting potential entrepreneurs to identify and evaluate resources related to the start-up of his or her business; 
(2)  Aiding existing business owners in the capacity of business growth and expansion; 
(3)  Providing access to potential economic and financial opportunities through the use of business databases; 
(4)  Providing guidance and counsel to assist businesses become more efficient by improving management skills and operational effectiveness; 
(5)  Conducting and co-sponsoring workshops on topics related to starting and operating a small business in South Carolina. 
(c)  Duties of the office. 
(1)  Financial assistance. The office shall provide financial planning and technical assistance to businesses by evaluating and analyzing financial records. The office shall also assist in the preparation of business loan proposals. 
(2)  Loan programs. The director is hereby authorized, subject to review and approval of the mayor, to create, administer, and manage loan programs. All loan programs shall have strict guidelines, lending limits, and require a governing board review for approval. The governing board shall be appointed by the mayor and shall consist of seven (7) members as follows: one (1) member from the enterprise community board, the enterprise community coordinator of the department of housing and community development, one (1) accountant, one (1) member from the business community and three (3) members who possess lending experience. 
(Ord. No. 1999-07, § 1, 1-26-99; Ord. No. 2014-10, §§ 1, 2, 1-30-14)  
Sec. 2-345. - Reserved.

Secs. 2-346—2-360. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 10. - MUNICIPAL AD VALOREM TAX ABATEMENT[22] 

Footnotes: 
--- (22) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1999-88, § 1, adopted July 20, 1999, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as Div. 5, §§ 2-335—2-337. Because the section numbers and the division number had been used prior to the actual inclusion of said ordinance in this Code, the editor has redesignated the provisions added by Ord. No. 1999-88 as Div. 10, §§ 2-361—2-363. 
 
Sec. 2-361. - General provisions 
(a)  An exemption granted under this division shall not result in any refund of taxes. 
(b)  An exemption granted under this division shall begin with the tax year in which the facility is placed on the assessment rolls and run for that tax year plus four (4) additional tax years. 
(c)  Any company availing itself of the exemption granted under this division shall submit a letter confirming its compliance with this division to the department of budget, finance and revenue collections by July 31 in each of the five (5) years in which the exemption applies. Failure to comply with this provision shall invalidate any tax abatement for the given year in which the abatement is sought. 
(Ord. No. 1999-88, § 1, 7-20-99)  
Sec. 2-362. - Manufacturing and research and development incentives. 
(a)  There is hereby established an exemption from municipal ad valorem taxation for a period of five (5) years for all new manufacturing establishments and the facilities of all new enterprises engaged in research and development activities located in the City of Charleston and for all additions, including additional machinery and equipment, to existing manufacturing establishments located in the city costing fifty thousand ($50,000.00) dollars or more. 
(b)  An exemption shall only be available pursuant to this section for location of or additions to manufacturing establishments and enterprises engaged in research and development activities where ten (10) or more new jobs that are full-time are created in the city offering its employees a comprehensive health benefit package and pays an average wage rate of ten dollars and fifty-four cents ($10.54) per hour. 
(c)  For purposes of this section: 
(1)  New job means any job created by an employer in the City of Charleston at the time a new facility or an expansion is initially staffed, but does not include a job created when an employee is shifted from an existing location in Charleston, Berkeley or Dorchester counties to work in a new or expanded facility; 
(2)  Full-time means a job requiring a minimum of thirty-five (35) hours of an employee's time a week for the entire normal year of company operations or a job requiring a minimum of thirty-five (35) hours of an employee's time for a week for a year in which the employee was initially hired for or transferred to the Charleston facility and worked at a rented facility pending construction of a new or expanded Charleston facility; 
(Ord. No. 1999-88, § 1, 7-20-99)  
Sec. 2-363. - Corporate headquarters and distribution facilities incentives 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, the term: 
(1)  New job means any job created by an employer in the City of Charleston at the time a new facility or an expansion is initially staffed, but does not include a job created when an employee is shifted from an existing location in Charleston, Berkeley, or Dorchester counties to work in a new or expanded facility; 
(2)  Full-time means a job requiring a minimum of thirty-five (35) hours of an employee's time a week for the entire normal year of company operations or a job requiring a minimum of thirty-five (35) hours of an employee's time for a week for a year in which the employee was initially hired for or transferred to the Charleston facility and worked at a rented facility pending construction of a new or expanded Charleston facility; 
(3)  Corporate headquarters means the location where corporate staff members or employees are domiciled and employed, and where the majority of the company's financial, personnel, legal, planning, or other business functions are handled either on a regional or national basis and must be the sole such corporate headquarters within the region or nation. 
(4)  Staff employee or Staff member means executive, administrative or professional worker. At least eighty (80) percent of an executive employee's business function must involve the management of the enterprise and directing the work of at least two (2) employees. An executive employee has the authority to hire and fire or has the authority to make recommendations related to hiring, firing, advancement and promotion decisions, and an executive employee must customarily exercise discretionary powers. An administrative employee is an employee who is not involved in manual work and whose work is directly related to management policies or general business operations. An administrative employee must customarily exercise discretion and independent judgment. A professional employee is an employee whose primary duty is work requiring knowledge of an advanced type in a field of science or learning. This knowledge is characterized by a prolonged course of specialized study. The work must be original and creative in nature, and the work cannot be standardized over a specific period of time. The work must require consistent exercise of discretion: 
(5)  Region or regional means a geographic area comprised of either: 
a.  At least five (5) states, including South Carolina; or 
b.  Two (2) or more states, including South Carolina, if the entire business operations of the corporation are performed within fewer than five (5) states; 
(6)  Corporate office facility means the location where corporate managerial, professional, technical, and administrative personnel are domiciled and employed, and where corporate financial, personnel, legal, technical, support services, and other business functions are handled. Support services include, but are not limited to, claims processing, data entry, word processing, sales order processing, and telemarketing; 
(7)  Distribution facility means an establishment where shipments of tangible personal property are processed for delivery to customers, but the term ("distribution facility") does not include an establishment which operates as a location where retail sales of tangible personal property are made to customers. A distribution facility includes establishments which process customer sales orders by mail, telephone, or electronic means, if the establishment also processes shipments of tangible personal property to customers. The terms "retail sale" and "tangible personal property", for purposes of this definition, have those meaning as contained in Chapter 35 of Title 23 of the South Carolina Code 1976, as amended. Certification of the required investment and the number of new jobs which are full-time and which are created must be provided by the South Carolina Department of Revenue and Taxation to the appropriate local tax officials. 
(b)  There is hereby established an exemption from municipal ad valorem taxation for a period of five (5) years for all new corporate headquarters, corporate office facilities, distribution facilities and all additions to existing corporate headquarters, corporate office facilities, or distribution facilities located in the City of Charleston for a period of five (5) years from the time of establishment, construction or being placed in service if the cost of the new construction or additions is fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) or more and seventy-five (75) or more new jobs that are full-time are created in the city, has a comprehensive health benefit package and pays an average wage rate of seven dollars ($7.00) per hour. 
(Ord. No. 1999-88, § 1, 7-20-99)  
Secs. 2-364—2-390. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XII. - DEPARTMENT OF LIVABILITY AND TOURISM  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-391. - Establishment. 
There is hereby established a department to be known as the department of livability and tourism. 
( Ord. No. 2015-164, § 2, 11-10-15 )  
Sec. 2-392. - Duties and responsibilities of department. 
The department shall be charged with providing direction, leadership and general oversight and enforcement of property maintenance within the city, including substandard structures, code enforcement programs and the enforcement of the City's tourism and special events activities, and shall interpret and ensure compliance with a variety of municipal codes and state statutes by performing the following duties: 
(a)  Facilitate the development of strategy and policy in collaboration with the mayor's office and other city departments to protect the safety, health, welfare and quality of life for its citizens. 
(b)  Provide leadership on a broad range of quality of life and tourism ordinances, community organizing and revitalization efforts that impact the city. 
(c)  Exercise the authority to enforce the City of Charleston's Code of the City of Charleston and state statutes enforceable by the city, including overseeing the enforcement of the provisions of Chapter 29. 
(d)  Implement the activities subscribed by the tourism commission with related commercial activities, neighborhood organizations and appropriate civic groups. 
(e)  Make an annual report to city council, the mayor and the tourism commission on the activities of this office regarding tourism, the tourism commission and the state of tourism in the city. 
(f)  Mitigate code violations, including but not limited to, substandard or unsafe structures, trash and garbage violations, overgrown lots, abandoned vehicles, graffiti, tourism and special events. 
(g)  Coordinate with the city's special events committee to ensure that the requirements outlined on approved special events permits are carried out in accordance with the city ordinance and enforced as necessary. 
(h)  Advise the mayor on tourism, tourism management and special events-related issues and with the mayor's input, advise city council and the tourism commission on matters that affect tourism management in the city. 
(i)  Oversee the enforcement of tourism-related ordinances as set forth in Chapter 29 of the Code of the City of Charleston. 
(j)  Proactively identify neighborhoods and communities where the physical environment can be improved through a unified approach to code enforcement. 
(k)  Ensure that department staff is adequately trained and is consistently enforcing the Code of the City of Charleston. 
(1)  Increase citizen participation in neighborhood revitalization through community outreach and education of the public. 
(m)  Develop and ensure proper execution of the department's budget. 
(n)  Provide direction in the day-to day administration of the Department, including the budget, personnel management, employee development and growth. 
(o)  Prepare reports and communicate the results of code enforcement violations and neighborhood revitalization efforts to the Mayor and the public. 
(p)  Supervise all assigned full and part-time department personnel. 
(q)  Operate computer and use applicable software to perform research, identify trends and report on code enforcement activities. 
(r)  Ensure quality service to customers through a user-friendly notification and remediation process. 
(s)  Oversee the identification, research and application of potential grant opportunities. 
(t)  Collect and analyze pertinent data, identify trends and formulate strategies to improve compliance with community standards. 
( Ord. No. 2015-164, § 3, 11-10-15 )  
Sec. 2-393. - Administration; duties of director. 
The management, administration, direction and control of the department of livability and tourism shall be under the supervision of the director of livability and tourism, who shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of city council. 
( Ord. No. 2015-164, § 4, 11-10-15 )  
Sec. 2-394. - Appointment of personnel. 
The director of livability and tourism shall have the power to hire, with the approval of the mayor, such personnel in such positions as are provided for in the budget of the department of livability and tourism as approved by city council. 
( Ord. No. 2015-164, § 5, 11-10-15 )  
DIVISION 2. - LIVABILITY DIVISION 
 
Sec. 2-395. - Livability division responsibilities. 
The livability division is responsible for: 
(a)  Effectively and efficiently enforcing applicable city ordinances to improve the livability and quality of life of all citizens, residents and visitors of the City of Charleston. 
(b)  Investigating nuisance complaints regarding overgrowth, litter and other types of unsightly debris on commercial and residential properties. 
(c)  Investigating complaints of unregistered and inoperable vehicles on private property. 
(d)  Enforcing nuisance violations as set forth in the Code of the City of Charleston regarding the standards for vacant structures. 
(e)  Responding to graffiti complaints and removing graffiti from public property. 
( Ord. No. 2015-164, § 6, 11-10-15 )  
DIVISION 3. - TOURISM DIVISION 
 
Sec. 2-396. - Tourism division responsibilities. 
The tourism division is responsible for: 
(a)  Serving as a liaison between the tourism industry and the city's residents. 
(b)  Issuing transportation and tour permits for motor coaches and tour buses. 
(c)  Issuing tour medallions, T-tags and tour zone assignments for carriage operators and carriages. 
(d)  Enforcing tourism code violations as set forth in the Code of the City of Charleston. 
( Ord. No. 2015-164, § 7, 11-10-15 )  
ARTICLE XIII. - POET LAUREATE 
 
Sec. 2-397. - Establishment of position of poet laureate. 
The position of poet laureate is hereby established in the City of Charleston. The title of the position shall be "The Poet Laureate of the City of Charleston." The administration of the position of poet laureate shall be under the direction of the mayor's office of cultural affairs. 
( Ord. No. 2016-065, § 1, 5-24-16 )  
Sec. 2-398. - Purpose. 
The poet laureate shall have the following roles and responsibilities: 
(a)  Implement in conjunction with the mayor's office of cultural affairs a community outreach and education program to encourage the writing, reading and performance of poetry within the city. 
(b)  Participate in civic events each year to encourage the writing, reading and performance of poetry by providing public poetry readings, workshops, lectures and/or presentations. 
(c)  Promote literacy through poetry in schools and foster the development of a youth poetry initiative, with the goal of providing a system and platform for emerging young poets to present their works in conjunction with city sponsored events. 
(d)  Commemorate the City of Charleston by composing poetry that speaks to, for and of our region which works will be presented at an annual City of Charleston sponsored event. 
( Ord. No. 2016-065, § 2, 5-24-16 )  
Sec. 2-399. - Qualifications; term; honorarium. 
(a)  The poet laureate shall meet the following eligibility requirements: 
(1)  Be at least eighteen (18) years old and a legal resident of the City of Charleston for at least one year. 
(2)  Demonstrate the following: 
a.  Excellence as evidenced by submitted poetry samples. 
b.  Excellence in his/her profession as evidenced by a history of publications in journals and books, awards, honors, fellowships, and/or recognition. 
c.  Advancement of poetry in the Charleston area as demonstrated by a history of activity in the area's literary community through teaching, readings, publications and/or public presentations. 
(b)  The poet laureate shall serve a term of two (2) years. 
(c)  The position of poet laureate will be funded from private sources. 
(d)  The City of Charleston shall retain the license to use, reproduce, and compile the work created for the city by the poet laureate in his/her official capacity. 
( Ord. No. 2016-065, § 2, 5-24-16 )  
Sec. 2-400. - Selection. 
The selection of the poet laureate shall be made based on the qualifications set forth in section 2-399(a). 
The first poet laureate shall be appointed by the mayor, with the recommendation of the South Carolina Poet Laureate and the director of the office of cultural affairs. Subsequent appointments shall be made by the mayor, with the recommendation of the South Carolina Poet Laureate, the then City of Charleston Poet Laureate and the director of cultural affairs. 
( Ord. No. 2016-065, § 4, 5-24-16 )  
Sec. 2-401. - Implementation. 
The mayor is authorized to implement such administrative procedures as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this article. 
( Ord. No. 2016-065, § 5, 5-24-16 )  
Secs. 2-402—2-420. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIV. - DEPARTMENT OF STORMWATER MANAGEMENT 
 
Sec. 2-421. - Establishment and organization. 
There is hereby established a department to be known as the department of stormwater management and shall consist of the following divisions: 
(1)  Administration; 
(2)  Stormwater project and floodplain management; 
(3)  Stormwater management system maintenance. 
( Ord. No. 2018-149 , § 6, 11-27-18)  
Sec. 2-422. - Duties and responsibilities of the department. 
The department shall: 
(1)  Provide direction, leadership, administration, general oversight, and enforcement of stormwater infrastructure and water quality projects including planning, design, and construction of new and existing development; 
(2)  Manage the city's floodplain management program; 
(3)  Maintain the city's stormwater drainage system; 
(4)  Provide education on corrective and preventative measures for reducing flood damage; 
(5)  Manage the city's stormwater user fees. 
In carrying out these duties and responsibilities, the Department shall coordinate with the Departments of Planning and Public Service and the Division of Resiliency & Emergency Management and shall collaborate with such departments to develop strategies and policies to protect the public health, safety, welfare, and quality of life for the city's citizens. 
( Ord. No. 2018-149 , § 7, 11-27-18)  
Sec. 2-423. - Administration; duties of director. 
The administration, management, direction, and control of the department of stormwater management shall be under the supervision of the director of the department of stormwater management who shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of city council. 
( Ord. No. 2018-149 , § 8, 11-27-18)  
Sec. 2-424. - Appointment of personnel. 
The director of the department of stormwater management shall have the power to hire, with the approval of the mayor, such personnel in such positions as are provided for in the budget of the department of stormwater management as approved by city council. 
( Ord. No. 2018-149 , § 9, 11-27-18)  
Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17; drunkenness in public, § 21-163. 
State Law reference— Preemption of field as to alcoholic beverages, suspension of certain local ordinances, S.C. Code 1976, § 61-13-760; municipal police officers' powers as to enforcement of alcoholic beverage laws, S.C. Code 1976, § 61-13-780. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2000-165, §§ 1—3, adopted July 18, 2000, amended former Art. I, §§ 3-1—3-5, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. I pertained to general provisions relating to alcoholic beverages and derived from the Code of 1975; this codification; Ord. No. 1982-38, § 1, 4-27-82; Ord. No. 1983-10, § 2, 9-28-82. 
 
Sec. 3-1. - Beer, ale, porter and wine defined. 
Beer, ale, porter and wine shall be defined for purposes of this section as stated in Section 61-4-10 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina 1976, as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 2000-165, § 2, 7-18-00)  
Sec. 3-2. - Prohibited operation. 
Commercial establishments which allow for the on-premises consumption of beer, ale, porter and/or wine shall be prohibited from operating between the hours 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Mondays through Saturdays. 
(Ord. No. 2000-165, § 3, 7-18-00)  
Secs. 3-3—3-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WINE AND BEER 
 
Sec. 3-16. - Hours of sale restricted. 
It shall be unlawful within the city for the owner or person in charge of any store, beer parlor or other place of business or commercial establishment to sell, give away or, in any manner, dispense or permit the consumption of any wines or malt liquors in such store, beer parlor or other place of business or commercial establishment between the hours of 1:30 a.m. and 7:00 a.m.; provided, however, that, any establishment licensed pursuant to S.C. Code 1976, section 61-5-10 et seq., shall be authorized to sell such products during those hours in which the sale of alcoholic beverages in containers of two (2) ounces or less is lawful. 
(Code 1975, § 3-9)  
Sec. 3-17. - Sunday sales prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, or offer for sale, any wine or beer in the city between the hours of 12:00 midnight Saturday night and sunrise on Monday morning; provided, however, that any establishment licensed pursuant to S.C. Code 1976, section 61-5-10 et seq. shall be authorized to sell such products during those hours in which the sale of alcoholic beverages in containers of two (2) ounces or less is lawful. 
(Code 1975, § 3-10)  
Secs. 3-18—3-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - TRANSPORTATION OF BEVERAGES IN OPEN CONTAINERS AND PUBLIC CONSUMPTION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to adopt, S.C. Code 1976, § 61-13-760. 
 
Sec. 3-31. - Restricted. 
No person shall transport or possess on his person or in a motor vehicle any beer, wine, or alcoholic beverage in an open container, nor consume any beer, wine, or alcoholic beverage in or upon the streets, sidewalks, alleys, or public ways of the city, except as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1977-86, § 1, 12-20-77; Ord. No. 1983-15, § 1, 3-22-83)  
Sec. 3-32. - Permit for transporting, etc., beverages in open containers and consumption at group functions—Required. 
(a)  No person shall possess, carry, or transport any beer, wine, or alcoholic beverage in an open container, nor consume any beer, wine, or alcoholic beverage in or upon streets, sidewalks, parks, playgrounds, alleys, public ways, or upon any private parking lot that is open for the public's use, except with the permission or consent of the owner, or at a group function, a permit for which has been obtained from the chief of police as provided in this article. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess alcoholic beverages, beer or wine, upon the premises of the Gaillord Municipal Auditorium, unless the same has been obtained on or brought to the premises under a permit from the city. The director of special facilities may refuse a permit for the use of alcoholic beverages, beer or wine upon the premises of the auditorium where it can be reasonably expected that a large portion of the audience will be below the legal drinking age or when public safety requirements justify careful control of alcohol consumption upon the premises. 
(Ord. No. 1977-86, § 2, 12-20-77; Ord. No. 1983-42, §§ 1, 2, 8-16-83; Ord. No. 2014-15, § 1, 1-30-14) 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17.  
Sec. 3-33. - Same—Application generally. 
(a)  A person seeking issuance of a permit to consume or possess alcoholic beverages required by section 3-32 of this article shall file an application with the chief of police on forms provided by him. An application for a permit shall be filed with the chief of police not less than three (3) days nor more than thirty (30) days before the date on which the proposed activity is to take place. 
(b)  The chief of police, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider any application hereunder which is filed less than three (3) days before the date such activity is proposed to be conducted. 
(Ord. No. 1977-86, §§ 3, 5, 12-20-77)  
Sec. 3-34. - Same—Application contents. 
The application for a permit required by section 3-32 of this article shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, and telephone number of the person seeking the permit. 
(2)  The name, address, and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization or association requesting the permit and of the authorizing and responsible head of such organization or association. 
(3)  The name, address, and telephone number of the person who will be the chairman and who will be responsible for the conduct of the activity. 
(4)  The date when the activity is to be conducted. 
(5)  The specific location of the activity proposed. 
(6)  The approximate number of persons who will participate in the activity. 
(7)  The hours when such activity will start and terminate. 
(8)  Any additional information which the chief of police shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued. 
(Ord. No. 1977-86, § 4, 12-20-77)  
Sec. 3-35. - Same—Action upon application. 
The chief of police shall act upon the application for a permit required by section 3-32 of this article within two (2) days after the filing thereof. If the chief of police disapproves the application, he shall mail to the applicant within two (2) days after the date upon which the application was filed a notice of his action, stating the reasons for his denial of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 1977-86, § 6, 12-20-77)  
Sec. 3-36. - Same—Issuance upon certain findings. 
The chief of police shall issue a permit as provided for under section 3-32 of this article when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the activity proposed will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly activity of the park and playground in question or the safe and orderly movement of traffic, pedestrian and vehicular. 
(2)  The conduct of the activity will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the activity so as to prevent normal police protection to the city. 
(3)  The concentration of persons at the activity will not unduly interfere with proper utilization of the parks and playgrounds or with proper fire and police protection of the parks and playgrounds and areas contiguous to such areas. 
(4)  The conduct of the activity is not reasonably likely to cause injury of persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance. 
(5)  The conduct of the activity is not reasonably likely to cause littering or a health hazard to the citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1977-86, § 7, 12-20-77)  
Sec. 3-37. - Same—Issuance for activity during certain times prohibited. 
No permit shall be granted under this article for an activity to convene before 9:00 a.m. or terminate after 8:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 1977-86, § 8, 12-20-77)  
Sec. 3-38. - Same—Appeal from denial. 
Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of a permit required by section 3-32 of this article to city council. The appeal shall be taken within forty-eight (48) hours after notice. The city council shall act upon the appeal at its next regularly scheduled meeting, but no later than twenty (20) days from the time of receipt of the appeal. 
(Ord. No. 1977-86, § 9, 12-20-77)  
Sec. 3-39. - Same—Chief of police's authority to offer alternative permit. 
The chief of police, in denying an application for a permit required by section 3-32 of this article, shall be empowered to authorize the activity on a day, at a time, or at a different location from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within two (2) days after notice of the action of the chief of police, file a written notice of acceptance with the chief of police. An alternate permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have the effect of a permit required by such section 3-32. 
(Ord. No. 1977-86, § 10, 12-20-77)  
Sec. 3-40. - Same—Notice to other city officials upon issuance. 
Immediately upon the issuance of a permit the chief of police shall send a copy thereof to the mayor, the fire chief, the director of the department of leisure services, and any other city officials affected thereby. 
(Ord. No. 1977-86, § 11, 12-20-77)  
Sec. 3-41. - Same—Revocation. 
The chief of police shall have the authority to revoke a permit required by section 3-32 of this article upon violation of the standards for issuance as set forth in section 3-36 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1977-86, § 12, 12-20-77)  
Sec. 3-42. - Same—Activity chairman or leader to have permit upon person during conduct of activity. 
The activity chairman or other person heading or leading an activity for which a permit is required by section 3-32 of this article shall carry the permit upon his person during the conduct of the activity. 
(Ord. No. 1977-86, § 13, 12-20-77)  
Sec. 3-43. - Same—Permittees required to comply with terms of permit and applicable laws and ordinances. 
A permittee under section 3-32 of this article shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1977-86, § 14, 12-20-77)  
Secs. 3-44—3-60. - Reserved.
