Sec. 7-47. - Exception as to existing piping. 
Notwithstanding any provision of this article to the contrary, consumer piping installed prior to April 13, 1971 or piping installed to supply other than natural gas, may be converted to natural gas if the inspector finds upon inspection and proper tests that such piping will render reasonably satisfactory gas service to the consumer and will not in any way endanger life or property; otherwise, such piping shall be altered or replaced in whole or in part to conform to the requirements of this article.

Such bonds shall cover and be conditioned for the faithful performance of all such work entered upon or contracted for in strict accordance and compliance with the provisions of this article as well as the requirements of chapter 24. 
(Code 1975, § 27-12; Ord. No. 2001-54, § 15, 5-29-01)  
Sec. 7-49. - Gas piping, gas appliances and gas construction—Contracting license review procedures. 
Any licensed gas piping, gas appliances and gas construction, alteration or repair contractor who violates any of the rules, regulations or ordinances relating to gas piping, gas appliances and gas construction contracting may be referred to the applicable Charleston County review board for action. 
(Ord. No. 1991-93, § 6, 9-10-91; Ord. No. 2001-54, § 15, 5-29-01)  
Sec. 7-50. - Same—Licensing. 
No person shall engage in the business of gas piping, gas appliances and gas construction, alteration or repair in the city unless he shall have first secured a gas piping, gas appliances, and gas construction license and shall have otherwise complied with the requirements for securing such license as the same may, from time to time, be promulgated by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1991-93, § 19, 9-10-91; Ord. No. 2001-54, § 15, 5-29-01)

Cross reference— Building codes, § 7-26 et seq.; gas code, § 7-47 et seq.; housing code, § 7-71 et seq.; mechanical code, § 7-141; electrical code, § 12-16 et seq.; fire prevention code, § 13-76; plumbing code, § 24-16 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 7-71. - Legislative findings; declaration of intent to repair, close or demolish unfit dwellings. 
The city council hereby finds that dwellings exist within the city which are unfit for human habitation due to dilapidation, defects increasing the hazards of fire, accidents or other calamities, lack of ventilation, light or sanitary facilities, or due to other conditions rendering such dwellings unsafe or unsanitary, or dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety or morals, or otherwise inimical to the welfare of the residents of the city. The city council hereby declares its intent to exercise its police powers to repair, close or demolish such dwellings. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-72. - Definitions. 
The following words and terms wherever used and referred to in this article shall have the following respective meanings for the purpose of the article, unless a different meaning clearly appears in the context: 
Authorized officer. The term "authorized officer" shall be taken to mean the public safety and housing officer or their designee. 
Dwelling. The word "dwelling" shall be taken to mean any building, structure or part thereof, used and occupied for human habitation or intended to be so used, and includes any outhouses and appurtenances belonging thereto or usually enjoyed therewith. 
Governing body. The term "governing body" shall mean the city council. 
Living room. The term "living room" shall be taken to mean a room or enclosed floor space used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, or cooking purposes, excluding bathroom, toilet-room, laundries, pantries, foyers or community corridors, closets and storage spaces. 
Municipality. The word "municipality" shall be taken to mean the city. 
Occupant. The word "occupant" shall be taken to mean any person(s) living and sleeping, either or both, in a dwelling or rooming unit. 
Operator. The word "operator" shall be taken to mean any person who has charge, care or control of a building or part thereof in which dwelling units and/or rooming units are let. 
Owner. The "owner" shall be taken to mean the holder of the title in fee simple and every mortgagee of record. 
Parties in interest. The term "parties in interest" shall be taken to mean all individuals, associations, corporations and others who have interest of record in a dwelling and any who are in possession thereof. 
Public authority. The term "public authority" shall be taken to mean any housing authority or any officer who is in charge of any department or branch of the government of the city or the state relating to health, fire, building regulations, or to other activities concerning dwellings in the city. 
Public officer. The term "public officer" shall be taken to mean the public safety and housing officer who is authorized by this article to exercise the power prescribed by this article and by S.C. Code 1976, §§ 31-15-10 through 31-15-120, and any amendments thereto. 
Unsafe equipment. The term "unsafe equipment" shall be taken to mean any boiler, heating equipment, elevator, moving stairway, electrical wiring or device, flammable liquid containers or other equipment on the premises or within the dwelling which is in such disrepair or condition that such equipment is a hazard to life, health, property or safety of the public or occupants of the premises or dwelling. 
Unsafe dwelling. The term "unsafe dwelling" shall be taken to mean a dwelling that is found to be dangerous to the life, health, property or safety of the public or the occupants of the dwelling by not providing the minimum safeguards to protect or warn occupants in the event of fire, or because such dwelling contains unsafe equipment or is so damaged, decayed, dilapidated, structurally unsafe or of such faulty construction or unstable foundation, that partial or complete collapse is possible. 
Where terms are not defined in this article and are defined in the building code as adopted pursuant to state law, they shall have the meanings ascribed to them as in the building code. 
Where terms are not defined under the provisions of this article or under the provisions of the building code, they shall have ascribed to them their ordinarily accepted meanings or such as the context herein may imply. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-73. - Construction of article. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed to abrogate or impair the powers of the court or of any department of the city to enforce any provisions of its chapter or its ordinances or regulations, nor to prevent or to punish violations thereof; and the powers conferred by this article shall be in addition and supplemental to the powers conferred by any other ordinance or law. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-74. - Public safety and housing officer—Designated. 
The chief building official shall be the public safety and housing officer. The fact that the designated person might also serve the city in some other capacity shall not, in itself, disqualify that person from otherwise serving as the public safety and housing officer. It shall be the duty and responsibility of the public safety and housing officer to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-75. - Same—Powers and duties generally. 
The public safety and housing officer is hereby authorized to exercise such powers as may be necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purposes and provisions of this article, including the following powers in addition to others hereinbefore and hereinafter granted: 
(1)  To investigate the dwelling conditions in the city in order to determine which dwellings therein are unfit for human habitation; 
(2)  To administer oaths, affirmations, examine witnesses, and receive evidence; 
(3)  To enter upon premises for the purpose of making examinations, provided that such entries shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession; 
(4)  To appoint and fix the duties of such officers, agents, and employees as he deems necessary to carry out the purposes of this article; and 
(5)  To delegate any of his functions and powers under this article to such officer and agents as he may designate. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-76. - Funds for examination and investigation; examination, investigations and enforcement; appropriations, grants and donations. 
The city council shall prepare an estimate of the annual expenses or costs to provide the equipment, personnel and supplies necessary for periodic examinations and accept and apply grants or donations to assist it in carrying out the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-77. - Failure to comply with lawful notice or order. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dwelling unit unfit for human habitation under the provisions of this article to fail to comply with any notice or order to repair, vacate or demolish such dwelling issued by any person authorized by this article to issue such notice or order. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-78. - Injuring, removing, or defacing posted notices. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or deface any notice posted on any dwelling by any authorized officer under the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-79. - Receipt of rental payments after expiration of time limit in notice or order. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, individually or as the representative of any person, to demand or receive rent payments after the expiration of any time limit set forth in any notice or order issued by the public safety and housing officer for any period during which a dwelling has been declared unfit for human habitation. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-80. - Interference with enforcement of article. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, individually or as the representative of any person, to interfere in any way with the enforcement of any of terms or provisions of this article. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, individually or as the representative of any person, to cause a reduction in services or utilities, to increase rents or cause rents to be increased, in retaliation for any tenant's reporting of a violation of this article. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person, individually or as the representative or agent of any person, to allow a vacant dwelling which has been declared unfit for human habitation to be used or occupied during any period in which the public safety and housing officer has found such vacant dwelling to be unfit for human habitation and of which notice is given to the owner or his agent. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person, individually or as the representative of any person, to evict or cause to be evicted any inhabitant or tenant in retaliation for reporting a violation of this article to the public safety and housing officer or any other public authorities. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter a dwelling unit which has been declared unfit for human habitation except for the purpose of making the required repairs or demolishing such structure. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-81. - Damaging facilities in unfit dwellings. 
It shall be unlawful for any person individual, or as the representative of any person, to damage, mutilate or remove, or cause to be damaged, mutilated or removed, any of the facilities in a dwelling, as referred to in this article or the code adopted by this article. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-82. - Violations. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, individually or as the representative of any person, to violate any of the terms or provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Secs. 7-83—7-90. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PROCEDURE FOR DETERMINING HABITABILITY 
 
Sec. 7-91. - Minimum standards, generally. 
(a)  A dwelling shall be determined to be unfit for human occupancy whenever it is found that such dwelling is to be an unsafe dwelling, or unlawful, or because of the degree to which the dwelling is in disrepair or lacks maintenance, is unsanitary, vermin or rat infested, contains filth and contamination, or lacks ventilation, illumination, sanitary or heating facilities or other essential equipment required by the International Residential Building Code, or because the location of the dwelling constitutes a hazard to the occupants of the dwelling or to the public. 
(b)  At a minimum all dwelling structures shall have: 
(1)  Access to a code compliant exit from the building and every room used for sleeping; 
(2)  Fresh water from a South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control approved well or from a public water system supplied to the individual building through an on site water meter; 
(3)  On-site sanitary waste disposal provided by a South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control approved septic system or from an approved private or public waste water system; 
(4)  Electricity from the public utility company provided through an on site electric meter or a city-approved alternative power source; 
(5)  An approved source of heat from October 1st through May 1st; and 
(6)  A lock for all exterior doors. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-92. - Complaint of building unfit for human habitation; notice of hearing thereon. 
Whenever a petition is filed with the public safety and housing officer by a public authority or by at least five (5) residents of the city charging that any dwelling is unfit for human habitation or whenever it appears to the public safety and housing officer (on his own motion) that any dwelling is unfit for human habitation, the public safety and housing officer shall, if his preliminary investigation discloses a basis for such charges, issue and cause to be served upon the owner of and parties in interest in such dwelling, a complaint stating the charges in that respect and containing a notice that a hearing will be held before the public safety and housing officer (or his designated agent) at a place therein fixed not less than ten (10) days nor more than thirty (30) days after the serving of such complaint. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-93. - Right to answer. 
The owner and parties in interest shall be given the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person, or otherwise, and give testimony at the time and place fixed in the complaint; and that the rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law or equity shall not be controlling in hearings before the public safety and housing officer. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-94. - Determination of unfitness for human habitation; order to repair, alter, improve or demolish. 
If, after notice and hearing, as provided for in section 7-92, the public safety and housing officer determines that the dwelling under consideration is unfit for human habitation he shall state in writing his findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the owner thereof an order: 
(1)  If the repair, alteration or improvement of the dwelling can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the dwelling, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to repair, alter, or improve such dwelling to render it fit for human habitation or to vacate and close the dwelling as a human habitation; or 
(2)  If the repair, alteration or improvement of such dwelling cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the dwelling, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to remove or demolish such dwelling. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-95. - Repair or vacation and closing of building when owner fails to comply with order; posting of placard indicating that building is closed. 
If the owner fails to comply with an order to repair, alter or improve or to vacate and close the dwelling, as provided in section 7-94, the public safety and housing officer may cause such dwelling to be repaired, altered, or improved or to be vacated and closed; and the public safety and housing officer may cause to be posted on the main entrance of any dwelling so closed, a placard with the following words: "This building is unfit for human habitation; the use or occupation of this building for human habitation is prohibited and unlawful." 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-96. - Removal or demolition of building when owner fails to comply with order. 
If the owner fails to comply with an order to remove or demolish the dwelling, as provided in section 7-94, the public safety and housing officer may cause such dwelling to be removed or demolished. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-97. - Cost of demolition or repair as lien; sale of material upon demolition of building; council's powers to declare nuisance. 
The amount of the cost of repairs, alterations, or improvements, or vacating and closing, or removal and demolition by the public safety and housing officer, under sections 7-94 and 7-95 shall be a lien against the real property upon which such cost was incurred. If the dwelling is removed or demolished by the public safety and housing officer, he shall sell the materials of such dwelling and shall credit the proceeds of such sale against the cost of the removal and demolition and any balance remaining shall be deposited in the circuit court by the public safety and housing officer, shall be secured in such manner as may be directed by such court, and shall be disbursed by such court to the person found to be entitled thereto by final order or decree of such court; provided, however, that nothing in this article shall be construed to impair or limit in any way the power of the city council to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement, by summary proceedings or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-98. - Service of complaints and orders; posting of copy of complaint or order; copy of complaint or order to be filed with clerk of county; effect of such filing as lis pendens. 
Complaints or orders issued by the public safety and housing officer pursuant to this article shall be served upon persons either personally or by registered mail, but if the whereabouts of such persons is unknown and the same cannot be ascertained by the public safety and housing officer in the exercise of reasonable diligence, and the public safety and housing officer shall make an affidavit to that effect, then the serving of such complaint or order upon such persons may be made by publishing the same once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in a newspaper printed and published in the city. In addition to publication, a copy of such complaint or order shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises affected by the complaint or order. A copy of such complaint or order shall also be filed with the clerk of the county and the Register Mesne Conveyance Office and such filing of the complaint or order shall have the same force and effect as other lis pendens notices provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-99. - Injunctive relief against public officer; damages not to flow from order of public safety and housing committee. 
(a)  Any person affected by an order issued by the public safety and housing officer may petition the circuit court for an injunction restraining the public safety and housing officer from carrying out the provisions of the order, and the court may, upon such petition, issue a temporary injunction restraining the public safety and housing officer pending the final disposition of the cause; provided, however, that within sixty (60) days after the posting and service of the order of the public safety and housing officer such persons shall petition such court. Hearings shall be had by the court on such petitions within twenty (20) days or as soon thereafter as possible. 
(b)  The court shall hear and determine the issues raised and shall enter such final order or decree as law and justice may require. In all such proceedings the findings of the public safety and housing officer as to facts, if supported by evidence, shall be conclusive. Costs shall be in the discretion of the court. The remedies herein provided shall be exclusive remedies and no person affected by an order of the public safety and housing officer shall be entitled to recover any damages for action taken pursuant to any order of the public safety and housing officer, or because of compliance by the chief building official, the director of code enforcement, or the fire chief with any order of the public safety and housing officer. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-100. - Immunity of enforcement personnel from liability. 
Except as may otherwise be provided by statute or local law or ordinance, no officer, agent or employee of the municipality charged with the enforcement of this article shall render himself personally liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this article. No person who institutes, or assists in the prosecution of, a criminal proceeding under this article shall be liable to damages hereunder unless he acted with actual malice and without reasonable grounds for believing that the person accused or prosecuted was guilty of an unlawful act or omission. Any suit brought against any officer, agent, or employee of the municipality, as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this article, shall be defended by the legal representative of the municipality until the final determination of proceedings therein. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-101. - Article provisions are cumulative. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed to abrogate or impair the powers of the courts or of any department of any municipality to enforce any provisions of its charter or its ordinances or regulations, or to prevent or punish violations thereof and the powers conferred by this article shall be in addition and supplemental to the powers conferred by any other law. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 7-102. - Severability. 
It is declared the intent of city council that the sections, subsections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this article are severable; and if any such provision shall be declared unconstitutional or otherwise invalid or unenforceable by a court of competent jurisdiction, it shall not affect the validity or enforceability of any remaining provisions of this article, and it is the intent of city council that such provisions shall continue in full force and affect. 
(Ord. No. 2010-110, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Secs. 7-103—7-115. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - MINIMUM STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 7-116. - Sanitation and environmental standards. 
(a)  Scope of section. The provisions of this section shall govern the minimum conditions of property and buildings to be used for human occupancy. Every building or structure occupied by humans, except as otherwise exempted, and the premises on which it stands, shall comply with the conditions herein prescribed as they may apply thereto. 
(b)  Compliance with exterior property area standards required for occupancy. No person shall occupy as owner-occupant or let to another for occupancy any dwelling unit for the purpose of living therein, or premises, which does not comply with the requirements of sections 307.1, 307.4 and 307.5 of the Standard Housing Code adopted by this article and paragraph (c) of this article. The public safety and housing officer shall cause periodic inspections to be made of dwelling premises to secure compliance with these requirements. 
(c)  Grading and drainage. All premises shall be graded and maintained so as to prevent the accumulation of stagnant water thereon, or within any building or structure located thereon. 
(d)  Compliance with exterior structure standards required for occupancy. No person shall occupy as owner-occupant, or let to another for occupancy, any dwelling or multi-family dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming house, rooming unit, or portion thereof for the purpose of living therein, which does not comply with the requirements of the exterior structure standards of section 305 of the Standard Housing Code and paragraphs (e) and (f) of this section. 
(e)  Basement hatchways. Every basement hatchway shall be so constructed and maintained as to prevent the entrance of rodents, rain, and surface drainage water into the dwelling or multi-family dwelling. 
(f)  Exit doors. Every door available as an exit shall be capable of being opened from the inside, easily and without the use of a key. 
(g)  Compliance with interior structure standards required. No person shall occupy as owner-occupant, or let to another for occupancy, any dwelling, multi-family dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming house, rooming unit, or portion thereof, for the purpose of living therein which does not comply with the requirements of paragraphs (h) through (j) of this section and the interior structure standards of sections 305 and 307 of the Standard Housing Code. 
(h)  Freedom from dampness. In every dwelling, multi-family dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming house, and rooming unit, cellars, basements and crawl spaces shall be maintained reasonably free from dampness to prevent conditions conducive to decay or deterioration of the structure, as required by the building code. 
(i)  Interior stairs and railings required. Stairs shall be provided in every dwelling, multi-family dwelling, rooming and boarding house as required by the building code. 
(j)  Maintenance of stairs. All interior stairs of every structure used for human habitation shall be maintained in sound condition and good repair by replacing treads and risers that evidence excessive wear or are broken, warped or loose. Every inside stair shall be so constructed and maintained as to be safe to use and capable of supporting a load as required by the provisions of the building code. 
(k)  Responsibility of owner to exterminate rodents. Notwithstanding the provisions of section 307.5 of the Code adopted by section 7-71 of this article, whenever infestation of rodents is caused by failure of the owner to maintain any dwelling or multi-family dwelling in a rodent-proof condition, extermination of such rodents shall be the responsibility of the owner. 
(Code 1975, §§ 10-80, 10-81, 10-83, 10-87, 10-102, 10-103, 10-107, 10-108, 10-110, 10-111, 10-118)  
Sec. 7-117. - Responsibility of owner to remove lead-based paints from exposed surfaces. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
Exposed surface. An "exposed surface" is any interior surface of a dwelling, dwelling unit or child care facility and any exterior surface of such a structure, such as stairs, porches, railings, windows, doors and siding from ground level to a vertical distance of at least five (5) feet, which are readily accessible to children six (6) years of age or younger, especially those surfaces where peeling or chipping of paint or other surface-coating material occurs. 
Lead base substance. A "lead-base substance" is any paint, lacquer, putty, plaster glaze or other similar surface-coating material containing lead in the dried paint film of paint already applied as measured positive by an in-site analyzer device. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner to provide for the removal or permanent covering of exposed surfaces of public or private premises on which a lead-base substance has been applied whenever the board of health determines that the presence of such substances constitutes a danger to health. The public safety and housing officer shall report any apparent violations to the board of health. 
(Code 1975, § 10-118A; Ord. No. 1980-83, § 1, 6-24-80)  
Sec. 7-118. - Facilities—Requirements. 
(a)  Compliance with section required. No person shall occupy as owner-occupant, or let to another for occupancy, any dwelling unit for the purpose of living, sleeping, cooking, or eating therein which does not comply with the requirements of facilities requirements of section 302 of the Standard Housing Code and this section. 
(b)  Kitchen sink. Every dwelling unit shall contain a kitchen sink apart from the lavatory required under section 302.1 of the Standard Housing Code adopted by this article. 
(c)  Rubbish storage facilities. Every dwelling, multi-family dwelling and dwelling unit shall be supplied with approved containers and covers for storage of rubbish, and the occupant or occupants of such dwelling or multi-family dwelling shall be responsible for the removal of such rubbish. 
(Code 1975, §§ 10-119, 10-124, 10-129)  
Sec. 7-119. - Same—Installation and maintenance. 
(a)  Compliance with section required. No person shall occupy as owner-occupant, or let to another for occupancy, any dwelling, multi-family dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming house, or rooming unit for the purpose of living, sleeping, cooking, or eating therein which does not comply with the requirements of this section and the provisions of the National Electrical Code and section 302 of the Standard Housing Code relating to installation and maintenance of facilities. 
(b)  Facilities and equipment. All required equipment and all building space and parts in every dwelling and multi-family dwelling shall be constructed and maintained so as to properly and safely perform their intended function in accordance with the provisions of the building code. 
(c)  Sanitation of facilities. All housing facilities shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition by the occupant so as not to breed insects and rodents or produce dangerous or offensive gases or odors. 
(d)  Plumbing fixtures. In buildings and structures used for human habitation, water lines, plumbing fixtures, vents and drains shall be properly installed, connected and maintained in working order and shall be kept free from obstructions, leaks and defects and capable of performing the function for which they are designed. All repairs and installations shall be made in accordance with the provisions of the plumbing code. 
(e)  Plumbing systems. In buildings and structures used for human habitation, every plumbing stack, waste and sewer line shall be so installed and maintained as to function properly and shall be kept free from obstructions, leaks and defects to prevent structural deterioration or health hazards. All repairs and installations shall be made in accordance with the provisions of the plumbing code. 
(Code 1975, § 10-131—10-135)  
Sec. 7-120. - Space and occupancy requirements. 
(a)  Compliance with section required. No person shall occupy or let to another for occupancy, any dwelling unit for the purpose of living therein which does not comply with the requirements of this section and sections 306.1 through 306.4 of the Standard Housing Code. 
(b)  Access to dwelling units from commercial uses prohibited. No habitable room, bathroom or water closet compartment which is accessory to a dwelling unit shall open directly into or shall be used in conjunction with a food store, barber or beauty shop, doctor's or dentist's examination or treatment room, or similar room used for public purposes. 
(c)  Location of bath and second sleeping room. No residence building or dwelling unit hereafter constructed containing two (2) or more sleeping rooms shall have such room arrangements that access to a bathroom or water closet compartment intended for use by occupants of more than one sleeping room can be had only by going through another sleeping room; nor shall the room arrangement be such that access to a sleeping room can be had only by going through another sleeping room or a bathroom or water closet compartment. No bathroom shall be so located that access thereto is solely through a kitchen. 
(Code 1975, §§ 10-139, 10-143, 10-144)  
Sec. 7-121. - Light and ventilation. 
(a)  Compliance with section required. No person shall occupy as owner-occupant, or let to another for occupancy, any dwelling, multi-family dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming house or rooming unit for the purpose of living therein which does not comply with the requirements of this section and section 303 of the Standard Housing Code. 
(b)  Lighting in non-habitable work spaces. Every laundry, furnace room, and all similar non-habitable work spaces located in a dwelling or multi-family dwelling shall have one supplied electric light fixture available at all times. 
(Code 1975, §§ 10-146, 10-148)  
Sec. 7-122. - Fire safety requirements. 
No person shall occupy as owner-occupant, or shall let to another for occupancy, any dwelling, multi-family dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming house, rooming unit, lodging house or lodging unit which does not comply with the applicable provisions of the fire prevention ordinances of the municipality. 
(Code 1975, § 10-153)  
Sec. 7-123. - Maintenance responsibility. 
(a)  Scope of subdivision. Occupants of dwellings, multi-family dwelling and dwelling units, and owners or operators of rooming houses shall be responsible for maintenance thereof as provided in this section and sections 307.2, 307.3 and 307.6 of the Standard Housing Code. 
(b)  Rubbish disposal. Every occupant of a dwelling unit shall dispose of all his rubbish in a clean and sanitary manner by placing it in the rubbish containers required by section 7-118(c) of this article. 
(c)  Installation and maintenance of plumbing fixtures furnished by occupant. Every plumbing fixture furnished by the occupant of a dwelling unit shall be properly installed and shall be maintained in good working condition, kept clean and sanitary, and free of defects, leaks or obstructions. 
(Code 1975, §§ 10-156, 10-158, 10-161)  
Sec. 7-124. - Rooming houses. 
(a)  Applicability of article; exception. Every person who operates a rooming house, or who occupies or lets to another for occupancy any rooming unit in any rooming house, shall comply with the provisions of every section of this article, except as provided in this section and sections 308.3, 308.4 and 308.6 of the Standard Housing Code. 
(b)  Bed linen and towels. The operator of every rooming house shall supply bed linen and towels therein at least once each week, and prior to the letting of any room to another occupant. The operator shall be responsible for the maintenance of all supplied bedding in a clean and sanitary manner. 
(c)  Shades or drapes required. Every window of every rooming unit shall be supplied with shades, drawn drapes, or other devices or material which, when properly used, will afford privacy to the occupant of the rooming unit. 
(d)  Sanitary facilities. Every water closet, flush urinal, lavatory basin and bathtub or shower required by section 308.2 of the Standard Housing Code shall be located within the rooming house and within a room or rooms which: 
(1)  Afford privacy and are separate from the habitable rooms; 
(2)  Are accessible from a common hall and without going outside the rooming house or through any other room therein. 
(Code 1975, §§ 10-162, 10-165, 10-166, 10-168; Ord. No. 1991-93, § 9, 9-10-91)  
Secs. 7-125—7-140. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - MECHANICAL CODE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Building codes, § 7-26 et seq.; swimming pool code, § 7-156; electrical code, § 12-16 et seq.; fire prevention code, § 13-76 et seq.; plumbing code, § 24-16 et seq. 
 
Sec. 7-141. - Adopted. 
(a)  The International Mechanical Code, 2000 Edition and App. A published by the international Code Council, Inc. is hereby adopted, so that hereafter all mechanical construction and all material and appliances used in connection with mechanical work and the operation of all mechanical apparatus within the City shall conform thereto. 
(b)  The code adopted by section 7-141 of this article is hereby amended as follows: 
109.2 Fee Schedule is amended by adding the following: 
Fees shall be charged in accordance with the fee schedule established and reviewed from time to time by the Council. The fee schedule shall be made available to the public online at the City's website, at the Clerk of Council's office or at the Building Inspections Division of the Department of Public Service. 
Section 106.5.3 Fee Refunds is amended by deleting the same with no substitutions. 
Section 108.4 Violation. Persons who shall violate a provision of this code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall erect, install, alter or repair mechanical work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the code official, or of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this code, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to penalties as prescribed by law. 
Section 108.5 Stop Work Orders. Upon notice from the code official that mechanical work is being done contrary to the provisions of this code or in a dangerous or unsafe manner, such work shall immediately cease. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, or to the owner's agent, or to the person doing the work. The notice shall state the conditions under which work is authorized to resume. Where an emergency exists, the code official shall not be required to give a written notice prior to stopping the work. Any person who shall continue any work on the system after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be subject to penalties as prescribed by law. 
(Ord. No. 1980-76, § 1, 6-24-80; Ord. No. 1984-58, § 2, 6-12-84; Ord. No. 1986-97, § 7, 9-9-86; Ord. No. 1989-61, § 6, 7-18-89; Ord. No. 1991-93, § 10, 9-10-91; Ord. No. 1994-420, § 5, 12-6-94; Ord. No. 1999-186, § 5, 12-21-99; Ord. No. 2001-54, § 16, 5-29-01; Ord. No. 2017-131, § 3, 10-10-17 )  
Sec. 7-142. - Licensing of mechanical contractor. 
No person shall engage in the business of installation or repair of or to any mechanical equipment in any building or structure in the city on or after January 1, 1991, unless he shall have first secured a license as a mechanical contractor qualified to do business in the city and shall have otherwise complied with the requirements for securing such license as the same may, from time to time, be promulgated by the city council. Nothing herein shall preclude an owner who occupies his residence from doing work on his own residence pursuant to applicable state law. 
(Ord. No. 1990-70, § 2, 12-18-90)  
Sec. 7-143. - Mechanical contractor license review procedures. 
Any licensed mechanical contractor who violates any of the rules, regulations or ordinances relating to the mechanical contracting may be referred to the applicable Charleston County Review Board for Action. 
(Ord. No. 1991-93, § 11, 9-10-91)  
Sec. 7-144. - Master plumber, plumbing contractor, HVAC contractor and gas installer license identification decal display requirements. 
Master plumber, plumbing contractor, HVAC contractor and gas installer license holders shall display a current license identification decal issued by the Charleston County Building Inspection Department or the City of Charleston Building Inspection Department. This decal shall be displayed on the left front door of all work vehicles of the said license holders. 
(Ord. No. 1991-157, § 3, 12-10-91)  
Secs. 7-145—7-155. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VII. - BUILDING PERMITS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 20001-54, §§ 19, 20, adopted May 29, 2001, amended former Art. VIII, §§ 7-171, 7-181—183, to read as herein set out by repealing former section 7-171, by amending former section 7-183 and by renumbering former sections 7-181—7-183 as 7-171—7-173. Sec. 7-171. - Statement of total cost of construction required. 
Before granting a permit, as required in the city building code, the chief building official shall require the applicant for such permit to state in writing, under oath, the total cost of construction, erection, alteration, repair, removal or wrecking, including cost of materials and supplies, as well as labor and services. For the purposes of verifying this statement, the chief building official may require the applicant to submit for his inspection the contracts, bills, estimates, plans, specifications, or other documents pertaining to the work. 
(Code 1975, § 10-13; Ord. No. 2001-54, § 20, 5-29-01)  
Sec. 7-172. - Signature of fire official required on permit application. 
No permit for any building or other construction intended for the storage of gasoline or other flammable liquids or for any building of other construction which for any reason is especially hazardous from the standpoint of fire shall be issued until the fire official shall have signed or otherwise affixed his name upon the face of the permit in question. 
(Code 1975, § 10-15; Ord. No. 1989-61, § 7, 7-18-89; Ord. No. 2001-54, § 20, 5-29-01)  
Sec. 7-173. - Cash bond required from owner for demolition permit of building with uncapped sewer or stormwater facility. 
Before any permit, as provided for in the city building code, is issued for the wrecking or removal of any building which has an uncapped sewer or stormwater facility connection, the owner shall be required by the chief building official to deposit a cash bond of five hundred dollars ($500.00), which bond shall be refunded to the owner only after the sewer or stormwater facility connections shall have been capped in a manner satisfactory to the chief building official. Should the owner fail to so cap a sewer or stormwater facility connection within sixty (60) calendar days after issuance of the permit, the chief building official shall be authorized to arrange to cap the sewer or stormwater facility connection and the bond shall be forfeited to the city. In addition to forfeited bond, any additional expenses shall also be the responsibility of the owner. 
(Code 1975, § 10-16; ; Ord. No. 2001-54, §§ 19, 20, 5-29-01; Ord. No. 2007-158, § 1, 8-21-07)  
Secs. 7-174—7-195. - Reserved.

Chapter 7.5 - CEMETERIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to acquire and operate, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-29-10. 
 
Sec. 7.5-1. - Establishment and use of burial places. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to establish or use within the limits of the city any place for the burial of any dead human body, except such as were established prior to January 1, 1975 for these purposes. Provided, that the expansion of a burial place existing before January 1, 1975 may be allowed if the expansion occurs on a contiguous site to the existing burial place and such expansion is approved by the board of adjustment. 
(Code 1975, § 8-2; Ord. No. 1994-435, § 1, 12-6-94)  
Sec. 7.5-2. - Burials restricted to established burial grounds. 
No person shall bury any dead human body in any burial ground or place within the limits of the city except in such burial ground or place as were set apart and devoted to such purposes prior to January 1, 1975. 
(Code 1975, § 8-3)  
Sec. 7.5-3. - Burial permit required. 
No person shall bury any dead human body in any cemetery, vault or burial ground within the city until thee shall have been obtained a permit therefor from the board of health. 
(Code 1975, § 8-4)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 8-1—8-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CHARLESTON HOME FOR CHILDREN 
 
Sec. 8-16. - Establishment. 
There is hereby established an orphan asylum to be known as "The Charleston Home for Children." 
(Code 1975, § 12-2)  
Sec. 8-17. - Election and appointment of commissioners. 
The Commission of the Charleston Home for Children shall consist of the Bishop of the Catholic Diocese of Charleston, the Director of Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Charleston, the attorney of the Catholic Diocese of Charleston, two (2) sisters appointed by the Mother General of the Sisters of Charity of Our Lady of Mercy, eight (8) citizens to be elected by city council, and seven (7) citizens to be appointed by the Bishop of the Catholic Diocese of Charleston. The term of office of the commissioners appointed subsequent to the initial commissioners shall be three (3) years. A vacancy occurring during the respective terms shall be filled in the same manner as the original election or appointment, but only for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1975, § 12-3)  
Sec. 8-18. - Eligibility for admission. 
All such poor orphan children and children of poor, distressed or disabled parents as shall be deemed proper objects of admission by the commissioners of the Charleston Home for Children shall be admitted into the Charleston Home for Children and shall be supported, educated and maintained during such terms and under such regulations as the city council shall, from time to time, prescribe or sanction. 
(Code 1975, § 12-4)  
Secs. 8-19—8-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CHARLESTON ORPHAN HOUSE FUNDS AND ESTATE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— By order of the Court of Common Pleas, dated June 13, 1979, in an action entitled Charleston Orphan House, Inc. v. Daniel R. McLeod, etc., et al, Case No. 79-CP-10-205, the Charleston Orphan House was transferred to Charleston Orphan House, Inc. 
Cross reference— General provisions applying to boards and commissions, § 2-151 et seq. 
 
Sec. 8-31. - Trustees of orphan house created. 
The mayor, the president of Charleston Orphan House, Inc., and the director of the department of administrative services for the time being, and their successors in office forever, shall be, and they are hereby, constituted and declared trustees for the Charleston Orphan House funds and estate; to be by them invested, from time to time, in such stock, bank shares, or other estate, as they may deem most beneficial to the institution; and to be by them held in trust for the use and benefit of the Charleston Orphan House. 
(Code 1975, § 12-10)  
Sec. 8-32. - Property transferred to trustees; powers and duties of trustees; investments. 
(a)  All the specialties, stock, money on hand, and other property or estate, of right belonging to the Charleston Orphan House, shall be, and are hereby directed to be assigned, transferred or paid over to the trustees for the purposes aforesaid; and the same, together with all future donations, devises and bequests, to or for the benefit of the institution; and, also, all moneys or other estate, which may arise to the same from escheated property, are hereby placed under the special charge of the trustees, who are directed and required to pursue all lawful ways and means for the recovery of all such property, real or personal, as may be so given, devised, bequeathed, or which shall result from escheated property, and when recovered, to invest the same in such stock, bank shares or other estate, as may be most beneficial to the Charleston Orphan House. 
(b)  All investments made as aforesaid shall be in the official name and character of such trustees and the same are hereby declared to be sacred, and shall be forever kept apart and distinct from all other city funds. The principal sums of such investments shall not on any consideration be expended, but shall be preserved whole and entire for the benefit of the Charleston Orphan House. 
(Code 1975, § 12-10)  
Sec. 8-33. - Annual statement of trustees. 
The trustees of the Charleston Orphan House shall render to the city council an annual statement of the funds entrusted to them, distinguishing the amount of each donation, devise or bequest, and the name of each donor or devisor; and also all moneys or other estate arising to the institution from escheated property, and showing the amount of the annual income, and the manner of the expenditure thereof, so that the citizens may see that a faithful application is made of the funds aforesaid. 
(Code 1975, § 12-12)  
Secs. 8-34—8-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - WILLIAM ENSTON HOME 
 
Sec. 8-46. - Establishment. 
There shall be established as hereinafter provided, with the funds devised and bequeathed to the city by the late William Enston, a home for old and infirm persons. 
(Code 1975, § 12-13(1))  
Sec. 8-47. - Site. 
The premises known as late as Storen's Farm, situate in the city and lying on the east side of King Street (and more particularly described in the deed thereof of Michael Storen to City Council of Charleston), containing eight (8) acres, are hereby set apart and dedicated by the city council as a site for the home established by this article, and the premises shall be known and designated as the William Enston Home, and the same are hereby vested in the board of trustees for the use and benefit of the home. 
(Code 1975, § 12-13(6))  
Sec. 8-48. - Qualifications of trustees; filling of vacancies. 
The mayor of the city shall always be ex officio a member of the board of trustees of the home established by this article and the twelve (12) other trustees shall be residents of the city, and shall be chosen to serve perpetually and without compensation. Upon the death, resignation or removal from the city of any one of the trustees, the vacancy shall be filled by the remaining trustees. 
(Code 1975, § 12-13(3))  
Sec. 8-49. - Persons eligible for admission. 
(a)  All such old and infirm persons in poverty of good, honest character and decent life and conduct as shall be deemed proper objects of admission by the trustees may be admitted into the home, and the board of trustees shall at all times have power to remove any person so admitted. 
(b)  No person under the age of forty-five (45) years shall be admitted, unless in the case of some great physical infirmity, such as lameness. 
(c)  No lunatic person shall be admitted or allowed to remain therein. 
(d)  There shall always remain in the gift of any of the family of William Enston six (6) gifts or appointments in the home to be enjoyed by six (6) individuals. 
(Code 1975, § 12-13(4))  
Sec. 8-50. - Employees. 
The board of trustees of the home established by this article shall have power to appoint such officers, physician or physicians, nurses and servants as they may deem necessary, and to allow them such compensation for their services as shall be reasonable, and shall also have power to remove them or any of them at their will and pleasure, and shall and may exercise such other powers and authorities for the well governing and ordering of the affairs of the home as shall not be repugnant to or inconsistent with the true intent and meaning of the provisions of the last will and testament of William Enston, deceased. 
(Code 1975, § 12-13)  
Sec. 8-51. - Memorial. 
In improving and laying out the grounds of the William Enston Home, the board of trustees is hereby required to reserve and set apart a space of one hundred (100) feet square at or near the center of the grounds, or at some other suitable point therein as they may determine, which spot is hereby dedicated for the erection thereon of a perpetual memorial by the city to William Enston, her large-hearted, noble benefactor. 
(Code 1975, § 12-13(7))  
Sec. 8-52. - Property received under William Enston will vested in board of trustees. 
All the money, stock, securities, investments and estate of every kind and description, with the increment thereon, which has heretofore come and which hereafter shall come into the possession of the city, or which is now held by any agent or officer of the city, or trustees on behalf of the city, which has been or may hereafter be received by the city under the bequests and devises contained in the will of the late William Enston, and the articles of agreement and deeds and instruments executed by and between the parties in interest under such will in settlement of such estate of William Enston, shall pass to and be vested in such board of trustees for the use and benefit of the home established by this article. 
(Code 1975, § 12-13(8))  
Sec. 8-53. - Trustees' power to dispose of property. 
The board of trustees of the home established by this article shall have power to sell, at public or private sale, and transfer and convey any and all of the property, real or personal, applying the proceeds of such sale to the use of such home. All funds held by them shall be invested in such public securities or other estate, real and personal, as they may deem most beneficial. All such investments shall be made in the name of the trustees of the William Enston Home. No investment or change of investment of such property shall be made unless by the vote of three-fourths (¾) of the members of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1975, § 12-13(9))  
Sec. 8-54. - Annual report of trustees. 
It shall be the duty of the board of trustees of the home established by this article to make in writing annually to the mayor and city council a full report of their proceedings during the year, and of the state of the home, showing the number and condition of the cottages, inmates, and all matters necessary to a full understanding of the affairs of the home, which shall be certified by the president and secretary of such board. There shall be rendered with such report annually an account or statement, certified in like manner, showing the receipts and expenditures for the year and the assets and pecuniary condition of the home, and such reports shall be addressed to the mayor before the tenth day of January in each year for the preceding fiscal year. 
(Code 1975, § 12-13(12))  
Chapter 9 - COLONIAL COMMON AND ASHLEY RIVER EMBANKMENT[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Boards and commissions generally, § 2-151 et seq. 
 
Sec. 9-16. - Created; composition, appointment; vacancies. 
In pursuance of the decree of the Court of Common Pleas for Charleston County, dated July 5, 1881, decreeing that all remaining marsh lands on each side of Broad Street should forever after be held and kept as a common for the use of the people of Charleston and that the city council was to provide for a board of commissioners, to be known as "Commissioners of The Colonial Common and Ashley River Embankment" is hereby constituted, to consist of the mayor, ex officio, and ten (10) citizens to be appointed by nomination of the mayor and confirmed by the city council. All vacancies therein shall be filled in like manner. 
(Code 1975, § 15-2)  
Sec. 9-17. - Duties of board. 
It shall be the duty of the board of commissioners provided for in section 9-16, to carry into effect the decree referred to in such section, and to have the care and administration of The Colonial Common and Ashley River Embankment, and of all funds to be expended upon its improvement. 
(Code 1975, § 15-3)  
Sec. 9-18. - Chairman and secretary; appointment; duties; reports; bylaws. 
The board of commissioners provided for in section 9-16 shall keep in writing regular minutes of their proceedings, and shall report annually, or oftener, if required by the city council, their acts and doings, and shall have power to make all proper bylaws necessary or convenient for conducting their business and advancing the purposes of their creation. 
(Code 1975, § 15-4)  
Chapter 11 - ELECTIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration generally, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference— Nominations and elections for municipal offices, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-15-10 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2000-212, § 1, adopted Aug. 15, 2000, amended former §§ 11-2—11-7 of Art. I in their entirety to read as herein set out, pending approval by the voters by referendum held on Nov. 7, 2000. Former §§ 11-2—11-7 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 1998-159, § 1, 8-18-98; Ord. No. 1999-25, § 1, 2-9-99. 
 
Sec. 11-1. - General elections. 
General elections in the city shall be held every two (2) years, in November of odd-numbered years, on the first Tuesday following the first Monday of November. The clerk of the city council shall give public notice of the general election at least sixty (60) days prior to such election. 
(Ord. No. 1979-10, § 1, 2-13-79; Ord. No. 2011-14, § 1, 2-22-11)  
Sec. 11-2. - Method of election. 
The city shall be divided into districts, and each district shall be represented on the council by one (1) member, who is elected by the qualified electors of the district and who must be a resident of the district during the entire term of office. The mayor shall be elected at large. 
(Ord. No. 2000-212, § 1, 8-15-00)  
Sec. 11-3. - Terms of office. 
The mayor and councilmembers shall be elected for a term of four (4) years. Terms of councilmembers shall be staggered, with districts bearing even numbers being scheduled for the general election of November, 2001, and districts bearing odd numbers being scheduled for the next general election thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 2000-212, § 1, 8-15-00)  
Sec. 11-4. - Method of election and determination of results. 
The method of electing candidates for mayor and council shall be pursuant to the nonpartisan election and runoff method as specified by S.C. Code Ann., Section 5-15-60(2) (Supp. 1999). Determination of the results of the nonpartisan general election and runoff method shall be made in accordance with S.C. Code Ann., Section 5-15-62 (Supp. 1999). 
(Ord. No. 2000-212, § 1, 8-15-00)  
Sec. 11-5. - Filing for election. 
(a)  The filing period for general elections in the City of Charleston shall commence at 12:00 noon on the first Monday of August and close at 12:00 noon on the third Monday of August. 
(b)  A candidate seeking a municipal office or seat on the commissioners of public works of the City of Charleston ("CPW") must file with the municipal election commission within the filing period as herein defined, a statement of candidacy, along with a filing fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for a council seat or CPW seat, or one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for the office of mayor. A candidate filing for a seat on city council must be a registered voter residing in the district for which he or she files, at the time of filing. A candidate for the office of mayor or a seat on the commissioners of public works must be a registered voter residing in the City of Charleston at the time of filing. The candidate shall offer proof of such residency as may be required by the municipal election commission, at the time of filing. if the residency requirements are met, the municipal election commission shall place the name of the candidate on the ballot. 
(c)  In lieu of a candidate filing fee as set forth is subsection (b), the Municipal Election Commission shall accept the application of any indigent person if said application is accompanied by a notarized affidavit establishing the applicant's indigent status. For purposes of this subsection, an indigent person is defined as a person who has gross income less than the most recently published federal poverty guidelines published by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services and who has net assets, including any campaign contributions on hand, of less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 2000-212, § 1, 8-15-00; Ord. No. 2003-58, § 1, 6-17-03; Ord. No. 2005-313, § 1, 7-19-05; Ord. No. 2005-607, §§ 1, 2, 10-18-05; Ord. No. 2007-87, § 1, 4-10-07; Ord. No. 2009-121, § 1, 7-21-09; Ord. No. 2011-53, § 1, 7-19-11; Ord. No. 2013-72, § 1, 7-16-13; Ord. No. 2015-050, § 1, 5-12-15 )  
Sec. 11-6. - Notice of election. 
The clerk of council shall give public notice of the election at least sixty (60) days prior to such election. 
(Ord. No. 2000-212, § 1, 8-15-00)  
Sec. 11-7. - Hours polls open. 
On the day of the election or any runoff, the polls shall be open for voting from 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 2000-212, § 1, 8-15-00)  
Secs. 11-8—11-20. - Reserved.

There is hereby established a City of Charleston Municipal Election Commission. 
(Ord. No. 1979-9, § 1, 2-13-79)  
Sec. 11-22. - Organization. 
The municipal election commission shall be composed of three (3) electors who shall be residents of the city and who shall be appointed by the city council. The terms of the members shall be six (6) years, except for those first appointed. 
(Ord. No. 1979-9, § 2, 2-13-79)

(Ord. No. 1979-9, § 3, 2-13-79)  
Chapter 12 - ELECTRICITY[1] 
Footnotes:
