ARTICLE II. - CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Building codes, § 7-26 et seq.; gas code, § 7-47 et seq.; housing code, § 7-71 et seq.; mechanical code, § 7-141 et seq.; swimming pool code, § 7-156 et seq.; fire prevention code, § 13-76 et seq.; plumbing code, § 24-16 et seq. 
 
Sec. 12-16. - Adoption of Electrical Code; resolution of conflicts. 
(a)  All electrical construction and all materials and appliances used in connection with electrical work and the operation of all electrical apparatus within the city shall conform to the standards, rules and regulations of the 1996 Edition of the National Electrical Code, for the installation of wiring and electrical apparatus for electrical purposes as they are now established, one copy of which such standards, rules and regulations has been filed in the office of the clerk of council, and are hereby adopted and approved and made a part of this code as fully as if every word, clause, phrase, sentence, section and part thereof were printed herein; provided that such rules, regulations, and standards are not in conflict with the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city. 
(b)  Where conflict occurs, the laws of the state shall prevail over the ordinances of the city or the National Electrical Code; and the ordinances of the city shall prevail over the National Electrical Code. 
(Code 1975, § 18-53; Ord. No. 1977-82, § 1, 12-20-77; Ord. No. 1985-116, § 1, 9-24-85; Ord. No. 1991-93, § 13, 9-10-91; Ord. No. 1992-295, § 2, 12-15-92; Ord. No. 1995-568, § 1, 12-19-95)  
Sec. 12-17. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1995-568, § 1, adopted Dec. 19, 1995, repealed former section 12-17 in its entirety which pertained to the requirement of the use of threaded rigid conduit in certain structures and derived from the Code of 1975, § 18-40(a)(1).  
Sec. 12-18. - Aluminum wire; use prohibited. 
The use of aluminum wire is prohibited in any structure. 
(Code 1975, § 18-40(a)(4))  
Sec. 12-19. - Duplex receptacles in dwellings controlled by wall switch; when permitted. 
Duplex receptacles in dwellings controlled by a wall switch shall be permitted when the wall switch controls the complete duplex receptacle at the outlet. 
(Code 1975, § 18-40(d); Ord. No. 1978-55, § 3, 9-12-78)  
Sec. 12-20. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1995-568, § 4, adopted Dec. 19, 1995, repealed former section 12-20 in its entirety which pertained to the use of alternate materials and derived from Ord. No. 1986-97, § 11, adopted Sept. 9, 1986.  
Sec. 12-21. - Upgrading electrical service. 
When upgrading residential service, the requirements of the National Electrical Code, Articles 210 (Branch circuits), 220 (Branch circuit and Feeder calculation) and 230 (Services), as adopted by city council shall be complied with. 
(Ord. No. 1987-67, § 1, 5-26-87)  
Sec. 12-22. - Service neutral. 
For residential service up to two hundred (200) amps, the service neutral shall be the same size as the ungrounded conductors. 
(Ord. No. 1987-67, § 1, 5-26-87)  
Sec. 12-23. - Kitchen counter electrical receptacles. 
In addition to the requirements of Article 220 (Branch Circuit and Feeder calculations) of the National Electrical Code as adopted, two (2) twenty-amp small appliance circuits shall be installed for receptacle outlets above kitchen counter space. These circuits are to be dedicated for these receptacle outlets. There shall be a maximum of three (3) outlets per circuit. 
(Ord. No. 1987-67, § 1, 5-26-87)  
Sec. 12-24. - Wafer ("piggy back") circuit breakers, Use Prohibited. 
The use of wafer ("piggy back") circuit breakers shall be prohibited in the city. 
(Ord. No. 1987-67, § 1, 5-26-87)  
Sec. 12-25. - Washing machine receptacle. 
There shall be no additional electrical outlets permitted on the twenty-amp circuit required for a washing machine receptacle for a residential dwelling. 
(Ord. No. 1987-67, § 1, 5-26-87)  
Sec. 12-26. - Smoke detectors required. 
All residential dwellings hereby constructed within the City of Charleston shall have at least one (1) electrical outlet installed in the dwelling unit for a smoke detector. 
(Ord. No. 1987-67, § 1, 5-26-87) 
Cross reference— Sprinkler systems required for buildings of certain institutional and residential occupancies, § 13-8.  
Sec. 12-27. - Sub-panel amperage restrictions. 
Every sub-panel installed within the city shall be served by a four-wire feeder not exceeding fifty (50) amps. 
(Ord. No. 1987-67, § 1, 5-26-87)  
Sec. 12-28. - Grounding electrode systems. 
Grounding electrode systems shall not be bonded or connected to water pipe systems in any building. Every grounding electrode system shall be installed in accordance with the requirements of the National Electrical Code as adopted. 
(Ord. No. 1987-67, § 1, 5-26-87)  
Sec. 12-29. - Helpers or apprentices. 
Nothing contained in this article shall prevent helpers or apprentices from working under or assisting qualified electricians for the purpose of learning the trade, but all installations, alterations or repairs shall be made in fact by a qualified electrician and not by the helper or apprentice. 
(Ord. No. 1987-67, § 1, 5-26-87)  
Sec. 12-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS.[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17. 
 
Sec. 12-31. - Permit required; qualifications. 
No building shall be wired for electric light, heat or power and no addition to or alteration or repair of existing wiring for light, heat or power in or upon any building shall be made without a written permit from the chief building official, which permit shall be granted by him only to persons licensed as electricians by the county. No person who holds a master electrician's certificate shall allow his name or his certificate to be used by another person either for the purpose of obtaining a permit or for doing business or work under the certificate. 
Homeowners who satisfactorily complete a homeowner's electrical examination administered by the chief building official or his electrical inspector may perform electrical wiring at their own residences without the assistance of a licensed electrician. 
(Code 1975, § 18-28; Ord. No. 1987-67, § 2, 5-26-87; Ord. No. 1991-93, § 18, 9-10-91)  
Sec. 12-32. - Construction plans and data to be required for permit. 
Before granting a permit, as provided in section 12-31, the chief building official shall require the applicant therefor to describe the scope of the proposed work, and to supply sufficient construction details and other data to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the chief building official that the work will be carried out in a safe and workmanlike manner, in compliance with provisions of the Code and other ordinances of the city and with the National Electrical Code, as adopted by section 12-16. Among other data, the chief building official shall require the applicant to submit legible scaled drawings showing the work contemplated, the size of service subfeeder wires, location of service box switches and center of distribution, arrangement of circuits and number of outlets involved.  
Sec. 12-33. - Fees; amount; payment before commencement of work. 
If a permit, as required in section 12-31, shall be granted, the applicant, prior to beginning the work, shall pay a fee charged in accordance with the fee schedule established and reviewed from time to time by the council. The fee schedule shall be made available to the public online at the city's website, at the clerk of council's office or at the building inspections division of the department of public service. 
(Code 1975, § 18-30; Ord. No. 2017-131, § 4, 10-10-17 )  
Sec. 12-34. - Inspection upon completion of work. 
Upon completion of the work covered by any particular permit, as required in section 12-31, it shall be the duty of the applicant to notify the inspections division, and the inspections division shall inspect such wiring and apparatus. 
(Code 1975, § 18-31)  
Sec. 12-35. - Certificate of satisfactory inspection. 
If work covered by any particular permit, as required in section 12-31, complies with applicable ordinances, rules and regulations, a certificate of satisfactory inspection shall be issued, and the use of such wiring and appliances shall be permitted. 
(Code 1975, § 18-32)  
Sec. 12-36. - Inspection and written permission required before turning on current. 
If shall be unlawful for any person to connect electrical current on or through any wiring or apparatus or to furnish or supply electric current for any installation or wiring until the same shall have been inspected and approved by the inspections division and the inspections division shall have given written permission for current to be turned on. 
(Code 1975, § 18-33)  
Sec. 12-37. - Unsafe or dangerous wiring or apparatus. 
Whenever any wiring or apparatus shall appear to be unsafe or dangerous to life or property, the inspections division shall disconnect service from the defective installations, unless in its opinion the danger is not imminent that immediate disconnection is required, in which event it shall notify the person owning, using or operating the wiring or apparatus to place it in a safe and secure condition within a specified time. 
(Code 1975, § 18-34)  
Sec. 12-38. - Electrical contractor license procedures. 
Any licensed electrical contractor who violates any of the rules, regulations or ordinances relating to electrical contracting may be referred to the applicable Charleston County Contractor Review Board for action. 
(Ord. No. 1991-93, § 14, 9-10-91)  
Sec. 12-39. - Electrical contractor license identification decal display requirements. 
Electrical contractor license holders shall display a current license identification decal issued by the Charleston County Building Inspection Department or the City of Charleston Building Inspection Department. This decal shall be displayed on the left front door of all work vehicles of said license holders. 
(Ord. No. 1991-157, § 2, 12-10-91)  
Chapter 13 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Committee on public safety, § 2-56; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; electrical regulations, Ch. 12; plumbing, Ch. 24. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2001-54, §§ 24—28, adopted May 29, 2001, amended former Art. I, §§ 13-1—13—14, to read as herein set out. Section 24 of Ord. No. 2001-54 repealed former section 13-8 which pertained to sprinkler systems in certain buildings and derived from the Code of 1975 and Ord. No. 1981-4, § 1, 2-17-81.  Sections 25—27 of said ordinance repealed former sections 13-11—13-13 which pertained to inspections by the fire official and derived from the Code of 1975 and Ord. No. 1987-66, §§ 1—3; 5-26-87.  Section 28 of Ord. No. 2001-54 renumbered former sections 13-9, 13-10 and 13-14 as 13-8—13-10. 
 
Sec. 13-1. - Compliance with chapter required. 
No person shall oppose, interfere with or refuse to obey any of the regulations prescribed in this chapter. 
(Code 1975, § 24-1)  
Sec. 13-2. - False alarms; interfering with or damaging alarm boxes or equipment. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to give, or cause to be given, a false alarm of fire, with intent to deceive, or to pull the slide of any station or signal box, except in case of fire, or to tamper, meddle or interfere in any way with such boxes, or any part thereof, or to cut, break, injure, deface or remove any of the boxes, or any of the wires or supports thereof, connected with any part of such fire alarm, or to make any connection or communication therewith, so as to interrupt or interfere with the proper working of the same, or with evil intent to injure, break or destroy any machinery or fixtures connected with it. 
(Code 1975, § 24-3)  
Sec. 13-3. - Unauthorized persons to remain outside fire line. 
As far as may be practicable, no person whatever, not connected with the fire department, police department, public service department or underwriters' agents, shall be allowed to remain within the line of operations unless actually employed. For this purpose, a cordon shall be drawn around the fire, within which no person shall enter unless his services are required. 
(Code 1975, § 24-7)  
Sec. 13-4. - Command at scene of fire. 
All the operations at a fire shall be considered as under the direction and control of the chief of the department and the officers of the fire department. 
(Code 1975, § 24-8)  
Sec. 13-5. - Interfering with directions of fire officer. 
No person shall oppose, interfere with or refuse to obey the directions of the chief of the fire department and the officers of the fire department. Any person in any way interfering with the fire department shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and may be arrested and removed beyond the line of operations, provided for in section 13-3, or committed, as the case may be. 
(Code 1975, § 24-9)  
Sec. 13-6. - Turning off gas in event of fire. 
Whenever a fire occurs within the city, it shall be the duty of the chief officers of the fire department, or any of their assistants, who may be on duty at such fire, to give directions for shutting off gas from any house on fire, or about to take fire. No person other than the occupant of the house, shall shut off the gas, except by the express order of such officers or assistants. Before any such order shall be given, full and sufficient notices shall be given to the occupants of the house, to enable them to make such arrangements as the urgency of circumstances will permit. Any person who shall shut off the gas from a house on fire, or in the neighborhood of a fire, without the order of the chief of the fire department, or one of his assistants, or of the occupants of the premises, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Should the chief of the fire department, or his assistants, order the gas to be shut off from any house not actually on fire without first giving full notice of such order to the inmates of the house, and in time for them to make such preparation and arrangements as circumstances will admit, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1975, § 24-10)  
Sec. 13-7. - Obstructing operation of fire engines or engine house. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct the working of the fire engines or trucks, or the front of any engine or truck house, whereby the free ingress and egress of the engine or truck may be prevented. 
(Code 1975, § 24-11)  
Sec. 13-8. - Fires on vessels. 
In the event of a vessel entering the port of Charleston on fire, or a vessel taking fire in the stream after having hauled out from the wharf, the chief of the fire department is empowered to negotiate for the service of the fire department in extinguishing such fires. 
(Code 1975, § 24-77; Ord. No. 2001-54, § 28, 5-29-01)  
Sec. 13-9. - Spark arresters on ships in port and steam apparatus near wharves. 
All ships and vessels now in the port of Charleston, or which may hereafter come to the port of Charleston, using a donkey or any other engine for the purpose of loading, and all steam apparatus of every kind including locomotives, steamboats or stationary engines, employed or used on or near any of the wharves of the city, shall provide and use, so long as such steam engines or apparatus may be employed on or near the wharves, proper and sufficient spark arresters. All ships and vessels shall use such spark arresters also on their galley stove pipes. Any captain or master of any ship, vessel or steamboat, or the owner or person in charge of any steam apparatus, locomotive or stationary engine, used or employed on or near any of the wharves of the city, who shall refuse or fail to provide and use such spark arresters shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1975, § 24-78; Ord. No. 2001-54, § 28, 5-29-01)  
Sec. 13-10. - Open burning prohibited. 
(a)  "Open burning" means the intentional burning of materials wherein products of combustion are emitted directly into the ambient air without passing through a stack or chimney from an enclosed chamber. For the purpose of this definition, a chamber shall be regarded as enclosed when, during the time combustion occurs, only apertures, ducts, stacks, flues or chimneys necessary to provide combustion air and permit the escape of exhaust gas are open. 
(b)  A person shall not kindle, maintain, or authorize to be kindled or maintained any open burning unless allowed below. 
(c)  Open burning is prohibited except as provided as follows: 
(1)  Fires set for the cooking of food for human consumption if: 
a.  Contained within a device designed for the purposes of cooking food over open flame; 
b.  Kept from beneath or under a residence (or eaves); 
c.  Kept three (3) feet from any combustible material; 
d.  If the cooking fire is constantly attended until extinguished; and 
e.  A minimum of one portable fire extinguisher with a minimum 4-A rating or other approved on-site fire-extinguishing equipment, such as dirt, sand, water barrel, garden hose, shall be available for immediate utilization. 
(2)  Fires set for recreational purposes if: 
a.  Contained within a device designed for the purpose of containing recreational fires to include: portable fire places, chimeras, grills, woodstoves, etc.; 
b.  Kept twenty-five (25) feet from any structure or combustible material; 
c.  If the recreational fire is constantly attended until extinguished; and 
d.  A minimum of one portable fire extinguisher with a minimum 4-A rating or other approved on-site fire-extinguishing equipment, such as dirt, sand, water barrel, garden hose, shall be available for immediate utilization. 
(3)  Fires set in a pit for the cooking of food for human consumption if: 
a.  The total fuel area is three (3) feet or less in diameter and two (2) feet or less in height; 
b.  Kept twenty-five (25) feet from any structure or combustible material; and 
c.  A minimum of one portable fire extinguisher with a minimum 4-A rating or other approved on-site fire-extinguishing equipment, such as dirt, sand, water barrel, garden hose, shall be available for immediate utilization. 
(4)  Fires set for the purpose of backfiring to contain previously ignited fires if performed by the organization responsible for fighting and containing the fire. 
(5)  Fires set for the purpose of heating, construction or maintenance activities that use propane, acetylene, natural gas, gasoline or kerosene in a device intended for such use. 
(6)  Fires set for the purpose of instruction and/or training of firefighters. 
(7)  Fires set for the removal of hurricane debris or other debris generated by a natural disaster if performed by or authorized by an organization responsible for fighting and containing the fire. 
(d)  The fire department, police department, and fire code officials are authorized to order the extinguishment of any fire that violates the provisions of this ordinance or creates a public nuisance as defined in Chapter 21. 
(e)  Violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine up to five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Code 1975, § 24-82; Ord. No. 2001-54, § 28, 5-29-01; Ord. No. 2010-113, § 1, 7-20-10)  
Secs. 13-11—13-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Administration generally, Ch. 2. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 13-26. - Established. 
There is hereby established a department to be known as the fire department. 
(Code 1975, § 24-4; Ord. No. 1978-11, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Sec. 13-27. - Duties and responsibilities of department. 
The fire department shall have the responsibility of enforcing the laws, ordinances and regulations of the state and the city relating to fire control. 
(Code 1975, § 24-4.1; Ord. No. 1978-11, § 1, 1-24-78; Ord. No. 1987-66, § 4, 5-26-87)  
Sec. 13-28. - Administration of department. 
The management, direction, and control of the department shall be under the supervision of the chief of the fire department who shall be appointed by the mayor, with the approval of city council. 
(Code 1975, § 24-4.2; Ord. No. 1978-11, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Sec. 13-29. - Appointment of personnel. 
The chief of the fire department shall have the power to hire, with the approval of the mayor, such personnel in such positions as are provided for in the budget of the department as approved by city council. 
(Code 1975, § 24-4.3; Ord. No. 1978-11, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Sec. 13-30. - Promulgation of special rules and regulations. 
The chief of the fire department or the fire official shall have authority to make, promulgate and enforce special rules and regulations for the purpose of preventing fire and safeguarding persons and property, including rules and regulations restricting storage, transfer or use of any inflammable material, or any gas, or the installation, operation or use of any type of machinery or equipment which may endanger life or property, or the congregation of persons under hazardous conditions; provided, that such special regulations shall not conflict with the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city. Such special regulations shall be entered in the official records of the board of firemasters and shall not become effective until the same shall have been advertised three (3) times in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(Code 1975, § 24-4.5; Ord. No. 1978-11, § 1, 1-24-78; Ord. No. 1987-66, § 5, 5-26-87)  
Sec. 13-31. - Special or auxiliary firemen. 
Special or auxiliary firemen may be appointed by the chief of the fire department, subject to the approval of the mayor. Such firemen shall be subject to the orders of the fire chief and the rules and regulations of the fire department, and shall possess all powers of a fireman. Persons so appointed may be suspended or dismissed by the fire chief, subject to the approval of the mayor. 
(Code 1975, § 24-89; Ord. No. 1977-32, § 1, 7-19-77)  
Secs. 13-32—13-40. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF FIREMASTERS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Boards and commissions generally, § 2-151 et seq. 
 
Sec. 13-41. - Established. 
There is hereby established a board of firemasters. 
(Code 1975, § 24-12; Ord. No. 1978-11, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Sec. 13-42. - Composition, membership of commission. 
The board of firemasters of the city shall be composed of the mayor and twelve (12) citizens appointed by him and confirmed by the city council. At least two (2) members of the board shall be members of the city council and, if possible, one member of the board shall be a retired fireman of the city fire department. 
(Code 1975, § 24-13; Ord. No. 1978-11, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Sec. 13-43. - Duties. 
The board of firemasters shall be charged with the responsibility of recommending policies and procedures for the operation of the department to the chief of the fire department and city council. 
(Code 1975, § 24-14; Ord. No. 1978-11, § 1, 1-24-78)  
Secs. 13-44—13-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - FIREMEN'S INSURANCE AND INSPECTION FUND[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Police relief and pension fund, § 25-36 et seq. 
State Law reference— Firemen's insurance and inspection fund, S.C. Code 1976, § 38-57-10 et seq. 
 
Sec. 13-51. - Board of trustees; creation; composition; appointment; terms; compensation; officers. 
The board of trustees of the firemen's insurance and inspection fund shall consist of the following members, who shall serve without pecuniary compensation: The chairman of the board of firemasters, the city treasurer, the chief of the fire department and two (2) citizens, one to be appointed by the chief of the fire department and one to be appointed by the mayor, the appointments to be confirmed by city council. The two (2) citizen members shall be appointed on the second Tuesday in January every four (4) years and serve until their successors are confirmed and qualified. The board shall select from their number a president and a secretary, who shall serve without compensation. The city treasurer shall be the treasurer of the board and of such fund. 
(Code 1975, § 24-18) 
Cross reference— City boards and commissions generally, § 2-151 et seq.  
Sec. 13-52. - Use of funds. 
No part of the firemen's insurance and inspection fund shall be used except for the benefit of the fire department of the city or the members thereof. 
(Code 1975, § 24-19)  
Sec. 13-53. - Acceptance by city of benefits of Act of March 7, 1910. 
The city council hereby accepts the benefits of an Act of the General Assembly of this state, entitled "An Act to declare and define the conditions upon which foreign fire insurance corporations may engage in and carry on business in this state, and to provide for the distribution of the fund arising from the compliance with such conditions," approved March 7, 1910, and amendments thereto. 
(Code 1975, § 24-20) 
State Law reference— License fee on fire insurance companies or agents, S.C. Code 1976, § 38-5-490.  
Sec. 13-54. - Clerk of the council; annual report to state fire marshal. 
The clerk of council shall on or before the thirty-first of October in each year make and file with the state fire marshal his certificate, stating the existence in the city of a regularly organized fire department under the control of the mayor and city council, the number of steam, hand or other engines, hook and ladder trucks and hose wagons in actual use, together with the value of the fire apparatus and necessary equipments belonging to the fire department in serviceable condition for fire duty, the number of organized companies and the system of water supply in use for such department, together with such other facts as the state fire marshal may require on a blank to be furnished by him. 
(Code 1975, § 24-21)  
Secs. 13-55—13-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - INSPECTIONS 
 
Sec. 13-61. - Duty of fire chief as to origin of fires; duty of hotel or rooming house owner to report fire. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to inquire into the origin of every fire that occurs in the city, and to keep a record of the same in proper books for that purpose. He is hereby authorized and empowered to summon, through the chief of police, and examine such persons as witnesses, as he may think proper. He shall report to the board of firemasters, when requested, the cause and locality of all fires, the amount and character of property destroyed, and the amount of insurance thereon. In all cases where the circumstances indicate that the fire is the act of an incendiary, he shall take the necessary steps to bring the offender to punishment. 
(Code 1975, § 24-22)  
Secs. 13-62—13-75. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CODES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2000-54, § 30, adopted May 29, 2001, renumbered former sections 13-79—13-82 as 13-77—13-80 in order to consolidate the provisions of this article. Sections 13-77 and 13-78 were formerly reserved. 
Cross reference— Building codes, § 7-26 et seq.; gas code, § 7-47 et seq.; housing code, § 7-71 et seq.; mechanical code, § 7-141; swimming pool code, § 7-156; electrical code, § 12-16 et seq.; plumbing code, § 24-16 et seq. 
 
Sec. 13-76. - Adopted. 
(a)  Except insofar as in conflict with the laws of the state and the ordinances of the city, the International Fire Code, 2000 Edition, published by the International Code Council, Inc., thereof including Appendices C, D, E, F, and G only, shall govern the conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion. 
(b)  The Code adopted by Section 13-76 of this article is hereby amended by the State of South Carolina as authorized by Section 9-60 (C) of the South Carolina Code of Laws, 1976 as amended, as set out in this section, which are incorporated by reference herein: 
SC Amendment Number: IFC 2000-01 
To replace section 508.5.1 of the International Fire Code with section 603.1.3.1 and 603.1.3.2 of the 1997 Standard Fire Prevention Code. 
(Code 1975, § 24-26; Ord. No. 1980-72, § 1, 6-24-80; Ord. No. 1982-62, § 1, 8-17-82; Ord. No. 1987-65, § 1, 5-26-87; Ord. No. 1989-61, § 9, 7-18-89; Ord. No. 1991-93, § 15, 9-10-91; Ord. No. 1994-420, § 6, 12-6-94; Ord. No. 1999-186, § 6, 12-21-99; Ord. No. 2001-54, § 29, 5-29-01; Ord. No. 2017-131, § 5, 10-10-17 )  
Sec. 13-77. - Modification. 
The fire official shall have power to modify any of the provisions of the fire prevention code, adopted by section 13-76, upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the fire prevention code; provided that, the spirit of the fire prevention code shall be observed, public safety secured and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modification when granted or allowed and the decision of the fire official thereon shall be entered upon the records of the fire official and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. 
(Code 1975, § 24-29; Ord. No. 1987-66, § 6, 5-26-87; Ord. No. 2001-54, § 30, 5-29-01)  
Sec. 13-78. - Appeals. 
Whenever the fire official shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a license or permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the fire prevention code, adopted by section 13-76, do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the fire prevention code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal to the board of adjustment and appeals as established by the building code within thirty (30) days from the date of the decision in question of the fire official. 
(Code 1975, § 24-30; Ord. No. 1987-66, § 7, 5-26-87; Ord. No. 2001-54, § 30, 5-29-01)  
Sec. 13-79. - Compliance with code required; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the fire prevention code, adopted by section 13-76 including amendments, or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certification or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by persons responsible for adoption or administration of the fire prevention code, or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance, respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 1-16 of this Code. 
(b)  The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time. When not otherwise specified, each ten (10) days that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  The application of any such penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Code 1975, § 24-31; Ord. No. 2001-54, § 30, 5-29-01)  
Sec. 13-80. - Licensing. 
No person shall engage in the business of installation, alteration or repair of fire protection systems in the city unless he shall have first secured an installation of fire protection systems license and shall have otherwise complied with the requirements for securing such license as the same may, from time to time, be promulgated by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1991-93, § 21, 9-10-91; Ord. No. 2001-54, § 30, 5-29-01)  
Sec. 13-81. - Permit and plan review fees. 
(a)  The code adopted by section 13-76 of this article identifies operational and construction permits required by the Fire Code, these permits may be instituted by the chief fire marshal as necessary to provide for fire prevention and safety. 
(b)  Additional permits or plan review requirements may be established by chief fire marshal as necessary to protect life and property. 
(c)  Fees shall be charged in accordance with the fee schedule established and reviewed from time to time by the council. A schedule of permit and plan review fees shall be made available to the public online at the city's website, at the clerk of council's office, or at the fire marshal's office of the fire department. 
(d)  Re-inspection fees shall be charged in accordance with the fee schedule established and reviewed from time to time by the council. The fee schedule shall be made available to the public online at the city's website, at the clerk of council's office, or at the fire marshal's office of the fire department. A re-inspection fee may be charged when re-inspection is required as a result of the permit holder having failed to meet the requirements of the applicable code during initial inspection, failing to properly prepare for the requested inspection, or failure to correct items cited during a previous inspection. 
( Ord. No. 2017-131, § 6, 10-10-17 )  
Secs. 13-82—13-95. - Reserved.
