Secs. 17-1—17-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS LICENSES 
 
Sec. 17-16. - Generally. 
Each year the city council shall adopt a business license ordinance for the purpose of providing such regulation as may be required by the businesses subject thereto and for the purpose of raising revenue for the general fund through a privilege tax. Copies of such ordinances, as adopted or thereafter amended, shall be made available to the public from the business license division of the department of budget, finance and revenue collections. 
(Ord. No. 1998-164, § 1, 9-8-98)  
Secs. 17-17—17-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - JUNK SHOPS AND PAWNBROKERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Junk dealers, S.C. Code 1976, § 40-27-10 et seq.; pawnbrokers generally, S.C. Code 1976, § 40-39-10 et seq.; pawnbroker's annual report to county auditor of average monthly value of property pledge during preceding year, S.C. Code 1976, § 12-37-1330. 
 
Sec. 17-51. - Bond required. 
The keeper of any junk shop or pawnbroker's establishment within the limits of the city shall file such bond as may be required under the state statutes. 
(Code 1975, § 45-1)  
Sec. 17-52. - Display of sign required. 
Every person receiving a license as a keeper of a junk shop or pawnbroker's establishment pursuant to the provisions of the annual license ordinance shall put up over the principal entrance to his shop a sign designating that he is licensed and containing his name. 
(Code 1975, § 45-2)  
Sec. 17-53. - Record of purchasers, etc., to be kept; inspection of such record. 
Every person receiving a license as a keeper of a junk shop or pawnbroker's establishment pursuant to the provisions of the annual license ordinance shall keep a book in which shall be written, at the time of every purchase or barter, a description of the article or articles purchased or bartered for, the name and residence of the person from whom received, and the day and hour when such purchase or exchange was made. Such book shall be at all times open to the inspection of the mayor of the city, the chief of police or any person duly authorized by them or either of them to inspect the same. 
(Code 1975, § 45-3)  
Sec. 17-54. - Inspection of shops or establishments. 
Junk shops and pawnbrokers' establishments shall be open at all times to the inspection of the mayor of the city, the chief of police or any person duly authorized by them or either of them. 
(Code 1975, § 45-6)  
Sec. 17-55. - Dealing with minors restricted. 
No keeper of any junk shop or pawnbroker's establishment shall himself, or through any other person, either directly or indirectly, purchase or receive, by way of pledge or barter or exchange, any kind of old articles, junk, old metals or other like commodities from any minor without the written permission of the parent or guardian of any such minor, which written permission shall be filed and produced whenever required by anyone authorized to inspect such shops or establishments. 
(Code 1975, § 45-7)  
Sec. 17-56. - Pawnbrokers' daily reports to police. 
All pawnbrokers doing business in the city shall make daily reports to the chief of police of the city, and within twenty-four (24) hours from the reception of any pawn or of all pawns deposited with them, giving the number of the ticket and such description of the personal property as will make its identification easy, and in case the pawn is of watches or other articles having a number, the description shall state among other things, such number. 
(Code 1975, § 45-8)  
Secs. 17-57—17-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - DEALERS IN SECONDHAND GOODS 
 
Sec. 17-71. - Daily report to police. 
Every person purchasing or dealing in any secondhand goods, including jewelry, except precious metals as defined in Title 40, chapter 54, South Carolina Code 1976, shall make daily report to the chief of police of the city, within twenty-four (24) hours from the time of the purchase, giving such description of the property purchased as will make its identification easy. 
(Code 1975, § 45-9)  
Sec. 17-72. - Dealing with minors restricted. 
No purchase of secondhand goods, including jewelry, except precious metals, as defined in Title 40, chapter 54, South Carolina Code 1976, shall be made from any minor without the written permission of the parent or guardian of any such minor, which written permission shall be held and produced whenever required by anyone authorized by the chief of police and the burden of proof shall be upon the purchaser of any such article to show that such written permission was the bona fide act of the parent or guardian. 
(Code 1975, § 45-10)  
Sec. 17-73. - Goods to be held thirty days before resale. 
Secondhand goods, including jewelry, except precious metals as defined in Title 40, chapter 54, South Carolina Code 1976, must be held in the possession of the purchaser, before being resold, for a period of thirty (30) days. 
(Code 1975, § 45-11)  
Secs. 17-74—17-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - GENERAL—PEDDLERS, CHARITABLE SOLICITORS, PALMETTO ARTISANS, BUSKERS, PANHANDLERS, AND VENDORS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, adopted March 25, 2014, repealed former Art. V, §§ 17-91—17-122, in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Art. V pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2007-43, § 2, 2-13-07; Ord. No. 2007-231, § 1, 12-6-07; 2008-118, § 1, 8-19-08; 2010-118, § 1, 7-20-10; Ord. No. 2011-52, §§ 1—4, 7-19-11. 
 
DIVISION 1. - FINDINGS 
 
Sec. 17-91. - Findings. 
The streets of the peninsula area of the city, south of Carolina Street, are the traditional city center where major institutional uses are located, where professional, retail and tourism commerce is conducted and where the city's oldest and most significant architecture is located. 
The revitalization of this area of the city has taken hold and continues, as evidenced, in recent years, by the addition of lodging, restaurant and related hospitality uses, new office and retail complexes and the expansion of the technology-based digital corridor. Successful revitalization has resulted in an infusion of people in this area of the city, both during and after normal business hours. 
Some four (4) million tourists now visit the city on an annual basis. The vast majority of these visitors frequent the peninsula area of the city, particularly the King and Market Street shopping districts and the peninsula neighborhoods graced with grand architecture. 
The built environment and development pattern of the peninsula area of the city is old, and established. The streets and sidewalks in this area of the city are narrow and are often crowded. The structures in this area of the city are typically sited at the front property line, leaving little, if any, space to accommodate outdoor vending or performing on private property, thus placing further demands on the sidewalks and other public spaces on the peninsula for these purposes. 
A diversity of uses in the peninsula area of the city is critical to maintaining its vibrancy and its desirability as a place to work, live and recreate. It is vital that the streets, sidewalks and other public places in the peninsula area of the city be able to accommodate varied uses by pedestrian and vehicular traffic. It is in the interests of the public health, safety and welfare that reasonable measures be enacted to maintain safety and accommodate a free flow and exchange of ideas and goods along and on the streets, sidewalks and other public places in the peninsula area of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
Sec. 17-92. - Definitions. 
The following words and terms when used in this article shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them in this section. 
Aggressive manner shall mean any of the following: 
(1)  Approaching or speaking to a person, or following a person before, during or after soliciting if that conduct is intended or is likely to cause a reasonable person to fear bodily harm to oneself or to another, damage to or loss of property, or to otherwise be intimidated into giving money or other thing of value; 
(2)  Intentionally touching or causing physical contact with another person or an occupied vehicle without that person's consent in the course of soliciting; 
(3)  Intentionally blocking or interfering with the safe or free passage of a pedestrian or vehicle by any means, including unreasonably causing a pedestrian or vehicle operator to take evasive action to avoid physical contact with the solicitor; 
(4)  Using violent or threatening gestures toward a person before, during, or after soliciting; 
(5)  Persisting in closely following or approaching a person, after the person has informed the solicitor by words or conduct that such person does not want to be solicited or does not want to give money or any other thing of value to the solicitor; or 
(6)  Using profane, offensive or abusive language which is likely to cause the person solicited to be intimidated by such language before, during, or after the solicitation. 
Aquarium District shall mean the area bounded on the north by Charlotte Street; on the east by the Cooper River; on the south by Laurens Street; and on the west by East Bay Street, said area to include all rights-of-way and sidewalks lying within and adjacent to said district and that portion of the city's riverwalk located within said district. 
Battery shall mean the elevated sidewalk adjacent to the Cooper River and Ashley River between the intersections of East Bay Street and Water Street and Murray Boulevard and King Street. 
Busker is a person who plays music or performs for entertainment on the public rights-of-way and other publically owned places. 
Charitable organization shall mean any person, organization, rescue squad, volunteer fire department or any other charitable or eleemosynary organization that holds itself out to be established for any benevolent, educational, philanthropic, humane, scientific, patriotic, social welfare or advocacy, public health, environmental conservation, civic or eleemosynary purpose, or for the benefit of law enforcement officers, firefighters or other persons who protect the public safety. 
Charitable soliciting shall mean any person on behalf of a charitable organization is traveling by foot or any type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, requesting, directly or indirectly, money, credit, property, financial assistance, remuneration, or other thing of value. 
City of Charleston's Youth Palmetto Art and Business Program shall mean the program^ administered by the City of Charleston's Recreation Department for youths between the ages of nine (9) and eighteen (18) or the completion of high school, whichever occurs first, for the purposes of teaching youth entrepreneurial skills using palmetto art products. 
Dangerous materials, objects or actions includes, but is not limited to, pyrotechnics, fireworks, knives, animals, fire, projectiles or any other prop, device, or material or action which could cause harm to or endanger the public, the busker, or property. 
King Street District shall mean that section of King Street between Carolina Street and Broad Street and all rights-of-way and sidewalks lying within and adjacent to said district. 
Market District shall mean the area bounded on the north by Hasell and Beaufain Streets; on the east by the Cooper River; on the south by Cumberland, Horlbeck Alley and Clifford Streets; and on the west by Archdale Street, excepting from said district the Market Head Hall, four (4) market sheds and the sidewalks abutting the sheds which are adjacent to the blocks of Church, Anson, and State Streets running between said sheds and that portion of Anson Street lying between south and north Market Streets in said district, said district to include all right-of ways and sidewalks lying within and adjacent to said district. 
Old and Historic District shall mean that portion of the city that is so designated from time to time on the official zoning map of the city. 
Palmetto artisan shall mean any person who is enrolled in the City of Charleston's Youth Palmetto Art and Business Program, who are traveling by foot or any type of conveyance, from place to place, house to house, or from street to street, attempting to sell palmetto bud fronds that have been physically altered from their natural state into a palmetto art product. Individuals, who are eighteen (18) or older and not in high school, that are selling palmetto art products shall be considered peddlers for the purpose of this chapter. 
Palmetto art products shall mean palmetto bud fronds that have been physically altered from their natural state into tangible items being offered for sale or donation. 
Panhandling shall mean the solicitation of alms whether by offering something of nominal value in exchange for a donation or not. 
Peddling shall mean any person traveling by foot or any type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, taking or attempting to take refundable security or seat deposits, or requesting a person's commitment of time, or orders for the sale of goods, wares, and merchandise, or other personal property of any nature whatsoever for immediate or future delivery provided no alcohol shall be contained therein, or for services to be furnished immediately or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or whether he is collecting advance payments on such sales or not. 
Peddler shall mean any individual, whether a resident of the city or not, who engages in the business of peddling as defined above. 
Perform includes, but is not limited to, the following activities: acting, singing, playing musical instruments, pantomiming, painting, juggling, magic, dancing, reading, puppetry, sidewalk art (working with non-permanent, water-soluble media, i.e., chalk, pastels, or watercolors directly on the pavement), and reciting. Perform shall not include the production of or the offer of items for sale at the location of the performance. 
Person shall mean an applicant, individual, corporation, limited liability company, association, partnership, trust, foundation or any other entity however styled. 
Right-of-way or Rights-of-way means a public road over which a person or entity has the legal right to access. 
Selling of palmetto art products shall mean the activities engaged in by palmetto artisans when they are attempting to sell or give for donation palmetto bud fronds that have been physically altered from their natural state into a palmetto art product. 
Soliciting shall mean peddling, charitable soliciting, selling of palmetto art products, busking, panhandling, and vending as herein defined. 
Solicitor means a person who solicits. 
South of Broad District shall mean the area bounded on the north by Broad Street; on the east by the Cooper River; on the south by the Ashley and Cooper Rivers; and on the west by the Ashley River, said district to include Broad Street and all rights-of-way and sidewalks lying within and adjacent to said district except the portion of Meeting Street lying between St. Michael's Alley and Broad Street and the portion of the sidewalk directly in front of 93 Broad Street. 
Special event shall mean a pre-planned activity sponsored by an individual, group, organization or entity proposed to be held on public property, including public streets, sidewalks, trails, facilities, parks, or other property owned or managed by the city which would significantly impact either public property and/or normal vehicular and pedestrian traffic requiring the use of city services, and which shall include but not be limited to a parade, foot race, bike or wheeled race, celebration, amusement event, cultural recognition, sporting event, demonstration, competition, commercial movie or television production, photography shoot, commercial for-profit event, charitable cause, or other similar activity. 
Vending shall mean any person engaged in the business of selling food or drink provided no alcohol shall be contained therein and/or reading material from a stationary cart or any other stationary vehicle or device that is placed, parked or stopped in or upon any city street or in any public parking space, public right-of-way, public sidewalk next to any city street or on any other public property in the Old and Historic District of the City of Charleston, except in such area as may be designated and marked by the department of traffic and transportation for such purpose and as is approved by city council. 
Vendor shall mean any individual, whether a resident of the city or not, who engages in the business of vending as defined above. 
Vendor space shall mean area as shall be designated and marked by the department of traffic and transportation for such purpose and as is approved by city council. 
Visitor reception and transportation district shall mean the area bounded on the north by Ann Street and the northern boundary of Wragg Square; on the east by Elizabeth Street; on the south by Hutson and Charlotte Streets; and on the west by King Street, said district to include all rights-of-way and sidewalks lying within and adjacent to said district. 
Waterfront Park District shall mean the area bounded in a northerly direction along Concord Street from the intersection of S. Adgers Wharf to the intersection of Concord Street and Mid-Atlantic Wharf; thence turning and running in a westerly direction on Mid-Atlantic Wharf to the intersection of Mid-Atlantic Wharf and Prioleau Street; thence turning and running in a northerly direction on Prioleau Street to the intersection of Prioleau Street and Vendue Range; thence turning and running in an easterly direction on Vendue Range to the intersection of Vendue Range and Concord Street to the intersection of Concord and Cumberland Streets, said area to include all rights-of-way and sidewalks lying within and adjacent to said district. 
White Point Garden shall mean the park area bounded on the west by King Street, on the north by South Battery Street, the east by East Battery Street, and the south by Murray Boulevard. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14; Ord. No. 2015-134, § 1, 9-22-15 ; Ord. No. 2016-076, § 1, 6-21-16 ; Ord. No. 2019-014, § 1, 2-26-19)  
DIVISION 2. - GENERAL RULES APPLICABLE TO PEDDLERS, CHARITABLE SOLICITORS, PALMETTO ARTISANS, BUSKERS, AND PANHANDLERS 
 
Sec. 17-93. - Obstructing public ways and means of ingress to and egress from private property. 
(1)  Solicitors shall not obstruct or otherwise inhibit the free, safe and efficient flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic on any public rights-of-way or public property even when transacting a sale. 
(2)  Solicitors shall not obstruct or otherwise inhibit the free, safe and efficient flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic into and out of private property adjacent to any public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
Sec. 17-94. - Conducting of business during certain hours prohibited. 
(1)  No person shall engage in peddling or charitable soliciting, as defined in section 17-92, between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(2)  No palmetto artisan shall engage in the selling of palmetto art products during school hours while school is in session, including summer school and mandatory after school programs, if applicable. While school is in session, Palmetto artisans are permitted to sell palmetto art products on Friday afternoons after school from 4:00 p.m. until 8:00 p.m., and on weekends and holidays from 8:00 a.m. until 8:00 p.m. When school is out of session, Palmetto Artisans are permitted to sell palmetto art products daily from 8:00 a.m. until 8:00 p.m. 
(3)  No person shall engage in busking between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
Sec. 17-94.5. - Sale of food or drink with any alcohol contained therein prohibited. 
No person shall engage in the sale or selling of food or drink with any alcohol contained therein. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the mayor may authorize the sale of food or drink containing alcohol during a city-sponsored event, including Piccolo Spoleto and MOJA Festivals, and a permitted special event as set forth in section 2-185, et. seq. of the Code of the City of Charleston. 
( Ord. No. 2015-134, § 2, 9-22-15 )  
Sec. 17-95. - Approaching vehicular traffic prohibited. 
Under no circumstances shall any moving vehicle be approached by a person soliciting. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
Sec. 17-96. - Use of traffic islands, medians or other traffic control devices for storage of sale of tangible property prohibited. 
Solicitors shall not store, keep or offer for sale any tangible property or service on any traffic island, median or other traffic control device located within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14  
Sec. 17-97. - Peddling, charitable soliciting, busking and the selling of palmetto art products unlawful on private property. 
It shall be unlawful to engage in soliciting on any property where a sign is posted that states "No Trespassing," "No Peddlers," "No Solicitors, "No Buskers" or words of similar import. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
Sec. 17-98. - Blocking rights-of-way. 
Solicitors shall not block roadways, fire apparatus access roads, sidewalks, crosswalks, driveways, doors, stairways, curb cuts, handicapped access ramps or block access to buildings, parks, conveyances, businesses, traffic control poles containing pedestrian crosswalk button(s), or be within twenty (20) feet of a fire hydrant, fire department connection (FDC), or within twenty (20) feet of any fire alarm or other emergency communication device, either by their location, or by the location of any crowd that they may draw. 
Solicitors shall not attract a crowd sufficient to obstruct the public right-of-way; a police officer may disperse the portion of the crowd that is creating the obstruction. At a minimum there shall be at least a five-foot passageway on the sidewalk as required by the Americans with Disabilities Act. 
Personal property used for soliciting shall not be left unattended on any public rights-of-way or other publically owned places. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
Sec. 17-99. - Noise. 
The conduct and behavior of all Solicitors shall otherwise comply in all respects with existing noise ordinances at all times. Solicitors or groups of these shall not interfere with a special event. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
Sec. 17-100. - Littering. 
Solicitors shall remove all trash and debris from the publicly owned rights-of-way and publically owned property in the vicinity of their activities immediately after their activities have ended. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
Sec. 17-101. - Aggressive solicitation prohibited. 
No person shall solicit in an aggressive manner on the public rights-of-way or other publically owned property. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
Sec. 17-102. - Prohibited areas for solicitors. 
(1)  Peddling, selling of palmetto art products, and charitable soliciting may take place on all sidewalks, streets or other publicly owned properties in the city except in the following districts: 
(a)  The Market District; 
(b)  South of Broad District; 
(c)  King Street District; 
(d)  Waterfront Park District; 
(e)  Aquarium District, and, 
(f)  Marion Square. 
(2)  The selling of palmetto art products by palmetto artisans shall be permitted in the above restricted areas when the selling of palmetto art products is carried out from city of Charleston designated palmetto artisan kiosks in accordance with the City of Charleston's Youth and Palmetto Art and Business Program. 
(3)  There shall be no soliciting in the Visitor Reception and Transportation Center District, or within fifty (50) feet of the perimeter of a(n): 
(a)  Automatic teller machine; 
(b)  Church grounds, while in session; 
(c)  School grounds, while in session; 
(d)  Library; 
(e)  Hospital; 
(f)  Funeral home; 
(g)  Bank; 
(h)  Hotel; 
(i)  Outdoor dining area; 
(j)  Entrance or exit of a performance venue; or 
(k)  A special event. 
(4)  During times of construction work on the streets, sidewalks and public infrastructure, the city may from time to time temporarily prohibit solicitors in the area near the construction work. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14; Ord. No. 2016-076, § 2, 6-21-16 )  
Sec. 17-103. - Fees. 
The fees, if any, for a peddler's permit, charitable solicitation permit, and Palmetto artisan permit shall be set by city council. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
Sec. 17-104. - Permit—Expiration. 
Permits issued under the provisions of this article shall expire on the thirty-first day of December in the year when issued or on the date specified on the permit, whichever date occurs first. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
Sec. 17-105. - Permit—Possession. 
Peddlers, charitable solicitors, and palmetto artisans are required, while engaged in peddling, charitable soliciting, or selling palmetto art products to have on their persons their permit. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
Sec. 17-106. - Transfer of permits prohibited. 
No permit issued under the provisions of this article is transferable. The authority granted in the permit shall be conferred only on the permittee named in said permit(s). 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
DIVISION 3. - PEDDLERS 
 
Sec. 17-107. - Peddling. 
(1)  No person shall engage in peddling within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a peddler's permit in compliance with the provisions of this article. Any peddler working for a corporation or other legally recognized organization shall individually obtain a peddler's permit. 
(2)  Application for a peddler's permit. Applicants for a peddler's permit under this article shall file with the chief of police an application in writing on a form to be furnished by the city's revenue collections department, which shall give the following information: 
(a)  Name and description of the applicant including the full name of the applicant as it appears on the applicant's birth certificate or court order if such court order was issued after the issuance of the applicant's birth certificate and the name of the applicant on the subsequently-issued court order is different from the name on the applicant's birth certificate; 
(b)  Permanent home and local address of the applicant; 
(c)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods and/or services to be sold; 
(d)  A description of any vehicle to be used and its license number; 
(e)  If the applicant is employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship between the applicant and his employer; 
(f)  Proposed area where the sales or providing of services will occur; 
(g)  The duration of the permit and the hours of operation for which applicant is seeking a permit; 
(h)  A statement indicating whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor. If so, the nature of the offense, the date and place of the offense, and the punishment imposed; 
(i)  A statement indicating whether or not a civil judgment has ever been entered against the applicant for fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation. If so, the nature of the action, the location of the court that heard the matter, the approximate date and amount of the judgment; 
(j)  A recent photograph of the applicant showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(k)  Applicants under the age of eighteen (18), who are not married or emancipated, may apply for a permit with the signed consent of their parent or legal guardian. 
(3)  Investigation of peddling applicant; issuance. The chief of police, in conjunction with the director of the department of revenue collections, shall issue a peddler's permit within seven (7) days as provided for hereunder when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, they find that: 
(a)  The applicant has not had a permit suspended or revoked within twelve (12) months immediately preceding the date of the application for a permit. 
(b)  There are no material omissions, untrue or misleading information contained in or omitted from the permit application; 
(c)  The applicant has not been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor involving a sex offense, controlled substances, or any violent acts against person or property; 
(d)  The applicant has not had a civil judgment or criminal conviction entered against him based upon fraud, deceit or misrepresentation; and 
(e)  There are no warrants outstanding against the applicant. 
If as a result of such investigation, the applicant's application for a permit is denied, the individual denying the permit shall endorse on such application his disapproval and notify the applicant of their reasons for denial. 
If as a result of such investigation, the application is granted, both the Charleston police department and the city revenue collections division shall endorse on the application their approval, and the city revenue collections division shall execute a permit addressed to the applicant. The director of revenue collections shall inquire into the nature of the business, the anticipated volume of sales and other details necessary to determine the amount of any business license fee required by the annual city business license ordinance. Upon payment of such prescribed business license fee and permit fee by the applicant, the director of revenue collections shall deliver to the applicant his permit and license. 
(4)  Revocation of peddler's permit. Peddler's permits issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked by the committee on business licenses after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(a)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for the permit; 
(b)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on the activity allowed under the permit; 
(c)  Any violation of this article; 
(d)  A conviction of a felony or misdemeanor involving a sex offense, a controlled substance, or any violent acts against person or property; 
(e)  A civil judgment or criminal conviction for fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation; 
(f)  Conducting the permitted activity in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public; or 
(g)  Failure to possess the identification required section 17-105. 
Notice of the hearing for a revocation of a peddler's permit shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds for the revocation, and the time and place of the revocation hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the permittee at the address listed on the permit application, at least ten (10) days prior to the date set for the revocation hearing. 
(5)  Appeals. Any person aggrieved by the action of the chief of police or the revenue collections director in the denial of a permit as provided in this section shall have the right to appeal to the City of Charleston's Committee on Business Licenses by filing with the city's clerk of council a statement in writing setting forth plainly and fully the grounds for the appeal. The appeal shall be filed within thirty (30) days after the aggrieved person receives actual notice of the decision of the chief of police or the revenue collections director. 
Any person aggrieved by the action of the committee on business licenses in the revocation of a permit as provided in this section shall have the right to appeal to the circuit court in and for the County of Charleston by filing with the clerk of court a petition in writing setting forth plainly and fully why the decision is contrary to law. The appeal must be filed within thirty (30) days after the aggrieved person receives actual notice of the decision of the committee on business licenses. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
DIVISION 5. - CHARITABLE SOLICITING 
 
Sec. 17-108. - Charitable soliciting permit. 
(1)  No person shall engage in charitable soliciting within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a charitable solicitor's permit in compliance with the provisions of this article. Any charitable solicitor working for a corporation or other legally recognized organization shall individually obtain a charitable solicitor's permit. 
(2)  Application for a charitable soliciting permit. Applicants for a charitable soliciting permit under this article shall file with the chief of police an application in writing on a form to be furnished by the revenue collections department, which shall give the following information: 
(a)  The purpose of the charitable soliciting; 
(b)  The name and description of the applicant including the full name of the applicant as it appears on the applicant's birth certificate or court order if such court order was issued after the issuance of the applicant's birth certificate and the name of the applicant on the subsequently-issued court order is different from the name on the applicant's birth certificate; 
(c)  Permanent home and local address of the applicant; 
(d)  The name of the charitable organization and its address along with the names, addresses, and telephone numbers of its principal officers; 
(e)  A description of any vehicle to be used and its license number; 
(f)  The location(s) where the charitable solicitation is to occur; 
(g)  The date(s) of the charitable solicitation; 
(h)  The approximate number of persons to be engaged in the charitable soliciting; and the times of day when the charitable soliciting is to occur; 
(i)  A statement indicating whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor. If so, the nature of the offense, the date and place of the offense, and the punishment imposed; 
(i)  A statement indicating whether or not a civil judgment has ever been entered against the applicant for fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation. If so, the nature of the action, the location of the court that heard the matter, the approximate date and amount of the judgment; 
(j)  A recent photograph of the applicant showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; and 
(k)  Applicants under the age of eighteen (18), who are not married or are not emancipated, may apply for a permit with the signed consent of their parent or legal guardian. 
(3)  Investigation of charitable soliciting applicant; issuance. The chief of police, in conjunction with the director of the department of revenue collections, shall issue a charitable solicitor's permit within seven (7) days as provided for hereunder when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, they find that: 
(a)  The applicant has not had a permit suspended or revoked within the twelve (12) months immediately preceding the date of the application for a permit. 
(b)  There are no material omissions, untrue or misleading information contained in or omitted from the permit application; 
(c)  There has not been another soliciting permit issued for the same location as the location being applied for; 
(d)  The applicant has not been convicted of a felony, or misdemeanor involving a sex offense, controlled substances, or any violent acts against person or property; 
(e)  The applicant has not had a civil judgment or criminal conviction entered against them based upon fraud, deceit or misrepresentation; 
(f)  There are no warrants outstanding against the applicant; and 
(g)  The conduct of the charitable soliciting will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of pedestrian and vehicular traffic, contiguous to the location requested on the permit application. 
If as a result of such investigation, the application for a permit is denied, the individual denying the permit shall endorse on such application his disapproval and notify the applicant of the reasons for denial. 
If as a result of such investigation, the application is granted, both the Charleston police department and the city revenue collections division shall endorse on the application their approval, and the city revenue collections division shall execute a permit addressed to the applicant. The director of revenue collections shall inquire into the nature of the business, the anticipated volume of sales and other details necessary to determine the amount of any business license fee required by the annual city business license ordinance. Upon payment of any such prescribed business license fee and permit fee by the applicant, the director of revenue collections shall deliver to the applicant his permit and license, if required. 
(4)  Revocation of charitable solicitor's permit. Charitable solicitor permits issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked by the committee on business licenses after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(a)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for the permit; 
(b)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying the activity allowed under the permit; 
(c)  Any violation of this article; 
(d)  Conviction of a felony or misdemeanor involving a sex offense, controlled substances, or any violent acts against person or property; 
(e)  A civil judgment or criminal conviction for fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation; 
(f)  Conducting the permitted activity in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public; or 
(g)  Failure to possess the identification required by the following Section 17-105. 
Notice of the hearing for a revocation of a charitable solicitation permit shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds for the revocation, and the time and place of the revocation hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the permittee at the address listed on their permit application at least ten (10) days prior to the date set for the revocation hearing. 
(5)  Appeals. Any person aggrieved by the action of the chief of police or the revenue collections director in the denial of a permit as provided in this section shall have the right to appeal to the City of Charleston's committee on business licenses by filing with the city's clerk of council a statement in writing setting forth plainly and fully the grounds for the appeal. The appeal shall be filed within thirty (30) days after the aggrieved person receives actual notice of the decision of the chief of police or the revenue collections director. 
Any person aggrieved by the action of the committee on business licenses in the revocation of a permit as provided in this section shall have the right to appeal to the circuit court in and for the County of Charleston by filing with the clerk of court a petition in writing setting forth plainly and fully why the decision is contrary to law. The appeal must be filed within thirty (30) days after the aggrieved person receives actual notice of the decision of the committee on business licenses. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
DIVISION 6. - PALMETTO ARTISANS 
 
Sec. 17-109. - Palmetto artisan permit—Required. 
(1)  No person between the ages of nine (9) and eighteen (18), unless still enrolled in high school, shall engage in the selling of palmetto art products within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a palmetto artisan permit in compliance with the provisions of this article and the rules and regulations of the City of Charleston's Youth Palmetto Art and Business Program. Copies of the program rules and regulations shall be made available to the public by the city's recreation department. Individuals over the age of eighteen (18) who are not still in high school who sell palmetto art products shall be considered peddlers for the purposes of this chapter. 
(2)  Application for a palmetto artisan permit. 
Applicants for a palmetto artisan's permit under this article shall complete an application for a Palmetto Artisan's permit and file it with the city's revenue collections department, which shall give the following information: 
(a)  Name and proof of age of the applicant; 
(b)  Permanent home and local address of the applicant; 
(c)  Name and contact information for parent or legal guardian; 
(d)  Name of School and location; 
(e)  Date of city of Charleston's Youth Palmetto Art and Business Program orientation attendance; 
(f)  A statement that the applicant will abide by all of the rules and regulations of the city of Charleston's Youth Palmetto Art and Business Program; 
(g)  A statement indicating whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor. If so, the nature of the offense, the date and place of the offense, and the punishment imposed; 
(h)  A recent photograph of the individual showing the head and the shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; and 
(i)  Applicants must apply for the permit with the signed consent of their parent or legal guardian. 
(3)  Investigation of palmetto artisan applicant; issuance. The Recreation Department in conjunction with the Charleston Police Department shall issue a palmetto artisan's permit within fourteen (14) days as provided for hereunder when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, they find that: 
(a)  The applicant has not had a permit suspended or revoked within the twelve (12) months immediately preceding the date of the application for a permit; 
(b)  There are no material omissions, untrue or misleading information contained in or omitted from the permit application; 
(c)  The applicant is between the ages of nine (9) and seventeen (17) or is eighteen (18) and still in high school; 
(d)  The applicant has successfully completed the City of Charleston's Youth Palmetto Art and Business Program orientation; 
(e)  The applicant has not received six (6) or more Palmetto Artisan Program violations in the past twelve (12) months. 
(f)  The applicant has not been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving a sex offense, controlled substances, or any violent acts against person or property; 
(g)  There are no warrants outstanding against the applicant; and 
(h)  The applicant's parent or guardian has signed the application. 
If as a result of such investigation, the application for a permit is denied, the individual denying the permit shall endorse on such application his disapproval and notify the applicant of the reasons for denial. 
If as a result of such investigation, the application is granted, both the Charleston police department and the city revenue collections division shall endorse on the application their approval, and the city revenue collections division shall execute a permit addressed to the applicant. The director of revenue collections shall inquire into the nature of the business, the anticipated volume of sales and other details necessary to determine the amount of any business license fee required by the annual city business license ordinance. Upon payment of such prescribed business license fee and permit fee by the applicant, the director of revenue collections shall deliver to the applicant his permit and license. 
(4)  Palmetto artisan's permit—Revocation. Palmetto artisan's permits issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked by the committee on business licenses after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(a)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for the permit; 
(b)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on the activity allowed under the permit; 
(c)  Any violation of this article; 
(d)  Conviction of a felony, misdemeanor or ordinance violation involving a sex offense, controlled substances, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation or any violent acts against person or property; 
(e)  Conducting the permitted activity in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the; or 
(f)  Failure to possess the identification required by section 17-105. 
Notice of the hearing for a revocation of a palmetto artisan's permit shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds for the revocation, and the time and place of the revocation hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the permittee at the address listed on their permit application at least ten (10) days prior to the date set for the revocation hearing. 
(5)  Appeals. Any person aggrieved by the action of the chief of police or the revenue collections director in the denial of a permit as provided in this Section shall have the right to appeal to the city of Charleston's Committee on Business Licenses by filing with the city's clerk of council a statement in writing setting forth plainly and fully the grounds for the appeal. The appeal shall be filed within thirty days after the aggrieved person receives actual notice of the decision of the chief of police or the revenue collections director. 
Any person aggrieved by the action of the committee on business licenses in the revocation of a permit as provided in this section shall have the right to appeal to the circuit court in and for the County of Charleston by filing with the clerk of court a petition in writing setting forth plainly and fully why the decision is contrary to law. The appeal must be filed within thirty (30) days after the aggrieved person receives actual notice of the decision of the committee on business licenses. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14; Ord. No. 2016-076, § 3, 6-21-16 ; Ord. No. 2019-014 , § 2, 2-16-19)  
Secs. 17-110—7-120. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 8. - VENDING 
 
Sec. 17-121. - Vending of food, drink or reading material. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of selling food or drink with any alcohol contained therein and reading material from a stationary cart or any other stationary vehicle or device that is placed, parked or stopped in or upon any city street or in any public parking space, public right-of-way or sidewalk next to any city street or on any other public property in the Old and Historic District of the City of Charleston except in such area as shall be designated and marked by the department of traffic and transportation for such purpose and as is approved by city council. 
(2)  The director of traffic and transportation shall survey the Old and Historic District and report to city Council, on at least an annual basis, those areas in the nonresidential portions of the Old and Historic District which are appropriate for accommodating the location of stationary vendors selling food or drink with any alcohol contained therein and reading material, taking into consideration factors such as vehicular and pedestrian circulation, access, availability of parking, street and/or sidewalk width and such other factors as he may deem necessary to protect the public health, welfare and safety; provided, however, that under no circumstances shall a vendor space designated for the sale of food or drink with any alcohol contained therein and reading material be located within one hundred (100) feet of the entrance to a church or within one hundred (100) feet of a residentially designated district; and provided further that when the director of traffic and transportation annually surveys the nonresidential portions of the Old and Historic District to determine the appropriate location of any vendor space, he shall seek to avoid locating stationary street vendors who sell food or drink with any alcohol contained therein and reading material unreasonably close to existing restaurants or to other designated vendor spaces. 
(3)  Vendor spaces designated for the sale of food or drink with any alcohol contained therein and reading material from stationary carts or other vehicles or devices shall be available to interested vendors on a daily basis, 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m., on a first come, first serve basis unless such spaces are franchised or unless designated by city council as not being available to interested vendors on a daily basis, 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. on a first come, first serve basis if not franchised in accordance with this section. 
(4)  No person shall engage in the sale of food or drink with any alcohol contained therein and reading material from a stationary cart or other vehicle or device from a vendor space unless: 
(a)  He has secured a business license, a peddler's permit for himself and any employee who shall operate his stationary cart or other vehicle or device approved by the police department and issued by the business license division, and a decal from the business license division displayed as follows: 
1.  The decal shall be prominently displayed on the stationary cart or other vehicle or device from which food or drink with any alcohol contained therein and reading material is dispensed; and 
2.  The peddler's permit issued to the vendor or his employee operating the stationary cart or other vehicle or device and the vendor's business license shall either be prominently displayed on the vendor's stationary cart or other vehicle or device or available from the vendor or his employee operating the stationary cart or other vehicle or device on demand; and 
(b)  He can and does confine all operations incident to the sale of food or drink with any alcohol contained therein and reading material within the perimeter of the vendor space; and 
(c)  He has paid such fees as may be set by city council for the privilege of utilizing such vendor space(s); and 
(d)  He has filed with the director of traffic and transportation a duly executed indemnification/hold harmless agreement with the city concerning the use of the designated vendor space. 
(5)  Nothing herein shall be construed to prevent the director of traffic and transportation, at the direction of city council, from designating vendor spaces on a temporary basis as and when city council may deem appropriate. 
(6)  Authority of the director of traffic and transportation regarding bidding and franchising procedures for all vendor spaces designated for the sale of food or drink with any alcohol contained therein and reading material is delineated as follows: 
(a)  The director of traffic and transportation shall have the authority to recommend to the committee on traffic and transportation that any or all vendor spaces designated for the sale of food or drink with any alcohol contained therein and reading material be made available only pursuant to a competitive bidding process and the execution of a franchise agreement with the successful bidder. The city may reject any or all bids. 
(b)  In determining whether such a recommendation is warranted, the director of traffic and transportation shall consider whether the demand for any vendor space from competing vendors is, or could be, disruptive to the public order or has resulted, or could result, in undue burden on enforcement officials. 
(c)  Upon the committee on traffic and transportation approving the franchising of certain vendor spaces, the director of traffic and transportation, with input from corporation counsel, shall draft bid specifications, which shall include, at a minimum: 
1.  The location of the vendor space proposed to be franchised; 
2.  A requirement of such minimum bid as shall be approved by the ways and means committee; 
3.  A provision to allow for the payment of the franchise fee on at least a semiannual basis; 
4.  A limitation on the term of the franchise agreement to no more than one year; 
5.  A requirement for the acquisition of public liability insurance in such amounts as shall be recommended by corporation counsel; 
6.  A prohibition against the assigning or subletting of any vendor space or franchise agreement; 
7.  A requirement that the successful bidder acquires and maintains a current City of Charleston business license; 
8.  A provision requiring the successful bidder to comply and maintain compliance with applicable rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the South Carolina Health Department; Except as prohibited by subsection 17-121(3) a limitation on the hours of operation from 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m., with a provision allowing for the franchised vendor space to be available to other licensed vendors for any day during the term of the franchise agreement that the successful bidder is not open for business in the franchised vendor space by 11:00 a.m., or if he thereafter vacates the franchised vendor space during the day; 
9.  A requirement that the successful bidder remove all vending apparatus from the vendor space at the end of each day and to otherwise maintain the area in and around the vendor space in a clean condition, free of trash and rubbish; 
10.  A requirement forbidding meter feeding or encroaching on any property outside the vendor space; 
11.  Provisions for the suspension or cancellation of the franchise agreement; 
12.  A provision requiring the use of recyclable or biodegradable containers; and 
13.  A provision allowing the city to reject any or all bids not deemed by it to be in the best interest of the city. 
(d)  No bid specifications shall be put out for bid until they have first been approved by the committee on ways and means. 
(7)  Authority of the department of traffic and transportation regarding the lawful and/or appropriate placement of stationary carts for the sale of food or drink with any alcohol contained therein and reading material in areas outside of the Old and Historic District is delineated as follows: 
(a)  In areas outside the Old and Historic District, the sale of food or drink with any alcohol contained therein and reading material from stationary carts or other stationary vehicles that are placed, parked or stopped in or upon any other public property shall be unlawful, except in such areas as may be designated and marked by the department of traffic and transportation for such purposes. 
(b)  In determining whether a location outside the Old and Historic District is appropriate to accommodate a stationary cart or stationary vehicle selling food or drink with any alcohol contained therein and reading material, the director of traffic and transportation shall consider the vehicular and pedestrian circulation around the proposed space, the availability of parking, street and/or sidewalk width, access and such other factors as he may deem necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare; provided however, that the director of traffic and transportation shall not designate a space for the sale of food or drink with any alcohol contained therein and reading material within one hundred (100) feet of the entrance to a church or within one hundred (100) feet of a residentially designated district; and provided further, the director of traffic and transportation shall seek to avoid having stationary street Vendors selling food or drink with any alcohol contained therein and reading material unreasonably close to existing restaurants or other designated street vending spaces. 
(c)  The director of traffic and transportation shall have the authority to recommend to the committee on traffic and transportation that any of the spaces designated for the sale of food or drink with any alcohol contained therein and reading material pursuant to the provisions of this section be made available only pursuant to a competitive bidding process and the execution of a franchise agreement with the successful bidder. The city may reject any or all bids. In determining whether such a recommendation is warranted, the director of traffic and transportation shall consider whether the demand for the space or spaces is, or could be, disruptive to the public order or has resulted, or could result, in undue burden on enforcement officials. If such a recommendation is made, and thereafter approved by the committee on traffic and transportation, the director of traffic and transportation, with input from corporation counsel, shall prepare bid specifications incorporating the provisions of this section. 
(d)  No bid specifications shall be put out for bid until they have first been approved by the committee on ways and means. 
(e)  Any spaces not franchised shall be available to licensed vendors pursuant to the criteria set forth in this section except as prohibited by subsection 17-121(3). 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14; Ord. No. 2015-134, § 3, 9-22-15 )  
DIVISION 9. - PENALTY 
 
Sec. 17-122. - Penalties. 
(1)  Penalty. Any person who is convicted of any violation of Chapter 17, Article V, may be sentenced to pay a fine not exceeding the maximum fine permitted by law or serve a term not exceeding thirty (30) days in jail, or both. Each day any violation of this article shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(2)  Court order on jurisdictional limits. In addition to the penalty that may be imposed pursuant to subsection (a) immediately above, any person who is arrested for and/or convicted of violating any provision of this article may be subject to an order of the court which shall impose a jurisdictional limit on said person prohibiting his presence in a specific geographic area of the City of Charleston. Failure to comply with the court order shall constitute a violation of the court order and shall result in the following: 
(a)  In the case of a bond where jurisdictional limits have been imposed, the bond may be revoked and the person shall be incarcerated until trial; and/or 
(b)  In the case of a sentence where jurisdictional limits have been imposed, the suspended sentence may be revoked and the person shall be incarcerated until he has served the original sentence imposed by the court without any portion thereof suspended. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
Sec. 17-122.5. - Severability. 
In the event any part of this article is found by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or otherwise unenforceable, such finding shall not affect the remaining provisions of this article, which shall remain in full force and effect to this end the provisions of this article are deemed severable. 
(Ord. No. 2014-40, § 1, 3-25-14)  
ARTICLE VI. - NEWSRACKS 
 
Sec. 17-123. - Newsracks. 
(a)  Definitions. 
Distributor means the person or entity that owns, is responsible for or directs the placing, installation, or maintenance of a newsrack in the public right-of-way. 
Intersection means that portion of the public right-of-way which surrounds the intersecting portion of two (2) or more roadways, extended along each roadway to the midpoint of each block. 
Multiple newsrack means a newsrack designed to dispense two (2) or more different publications. 
Newsrack means any freestanding self-service or coin-operated box, container, storage unit or other dispenser installed, used, or maintained in the public right-of-way, including a public sidewalk, for the display, sale or distribution of newspapers, periodicals or other publications. 
Public right-of-way means land, which by deed, conveyance, agreement dedication, usage or process of law is used or reserved for use as a public roadway, including the sidewalk as hereinafter defined, in the City of Charleston (the "right-of-way"). 
Sidewalk means the area of the public right-of-way which is designated or ordinarily used for pedestrian travel. 
(b)  Prohibition. 
(1)  No person or entity shall place, install, use or maintain any newsrack which rests in whole or in part upon, in, or on any portion of the right-of-way in the city, or that projects onto, into, or over any part of the right-of-way or which attempts to utilize or take advantage of the right-of-way in the city except in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(2)  All newsracks shall comply with federal, state and other local laws and regulations, as applicable, and shall be approved by the city prior to their installation as provided herein. 
(c)  Standards for newsracks placed in the right-of-way. 
(1)  No newsrack shall exceed fifty (50) inches in height, twenty-seven (27) inches in width, or twenty (20) inches in thickness. 
(2)  No newsrack shall be placed, installed or maintained within five (5) feet of any marked or unmarked crosswalk, fire hydrant, driveway, alley, loading zone, handicapped ramp or curb cut, on any grating or manhole cover, on any surface where the newsrack shall cause damage to or interfere with the use of any pipes, vault areas, telephone or electrical cables and wires, or within the initial twenty (20) feet of any area used by the Charleston Area Regional Transit Authority ("CARTA") for loading and unloading passengers at a bus stop, measured from the front position of the bus. 
(3)  No newsrack shall be placed, installed or maintained within two (2) feet of a curb face. 
(4)  A single or multiple newsrack shall be permitted in a right-of-way of the city on the Charleston peninsula generally from Spring Street to the north; from Concord Street to the east; from Broad Street to the south; and from Lockwood Boulevard to the west and specifically at the locations more fully described on Exhibit A, attached to Ordinance No. 2012-239 and incorporated by reference herein (the "permitted spaces"). In the event the distributor of a single or multiple newsrack desires its newsrack to be located in an area other than a permitted space as set forth on Exhibit A due to a compelling hardship, the distributor shall suffer as a result of its newsrack being located in a permitted space, the distributor may seek permission from the city to locate its newsrack on an alternative right-of-way and shall set forth the reasons why an alternative right-of-way for the placement of the distributor's newsrack is necessary. Any alternative right-of-way location request may only be approved by the city in its sole discretion based upon the following considerations: 
i.  The current number of newsracks that are located within or near the proposed area shall not create undue concentration of newsracks in such proposed area. 
ii.  The impact on pedestrian and vehicular traffic and accessibility to public transportation shall not be impacted by the addition of a newsrack in such proposed area. 
iii.  The impact on and proximity to buildings used for residential purposes shall not be impacted by the addition of a newsrack in such proposed area. 
iv.  No inconsistency of newsracks and the character of the surrounding streetscape shall occur by virtue of the presence of a newsrack in such proposed area. 
v.  In determining alternative location requirements, the city shall establish objective criteria relating to the surrounding uses likely to generate a demand for periodicals and other material customarily supplied through newsracks, distances between locations, and the visual compatibility of newsracks with surrounding facades and streetscape improvements. The criteria shall be nondiscriminatory among distributors, but may make reasonable limitations on the number of publications that any one distributor, publisher or its affiliates, may have at any one location when spaces at that location are limited in number. The city may also implement reasonable regulations to promote the full utilization of spaces and to require the forfeiture of spaces when they are not fully utilized. The city may make limitations on the lettering, logos, and graphics that appear on the newsracks, but shall allow a reasonable basis for publications contained within spaces to be readily identified. 
(5)  Newsracks, whether single or multiple, shall be painted in accordance with Sherwin Williams specifications Historic Charleston Green, PMS #DCR099, exterior Corothane I-Alphatic moisture cure urethane or its equivalent as approved by the City of Charleston. 
(6)  A newsrack shall exhibit only one graphic comprised of white lettering and/or numbering and covering a surface area no larger than the size of a rack card on the front of the newsrack only and in the same place on the front of the newsrack where a rack card would be inserted. A rack card may also be used in the same place. The one rack card may include a registered trademark and be of any design or color combination. 
(7)  Excepting the white lettering and/or rack card described in this section, no advertising signs or material shall be displayed on the outside of the newsrack other than signs or material dealing with the name, address and telephone number of the publication contained within the newsrack. 
(8)  Each newsrack shall be sufficiently weighted and bolted to the sidewalk to provide stability and safety in accordance with the newsrack manufacturer's recommended specifications which shall be submitted to the city with the newsrack encroachment permit application as set forth in subsection (e)(2) of this section. No newsrack shall be chained, tied or otherwise fastened to a tree, signpost, streetlight, telephone pole or other fixture on the right-of-way. 
(9)  Each newsrack shall be equipped with a coin-return mechanism to permit a person using the machine to secure an immediate refund in the event the person is unable to receive the purchased publication paid for. The coin-return mechanism shall be maintained in good working order. Newsracks dispensing free publications are exempt from this subsection. 
(10)  Each newsrack shall be made of a metallic or other material as approved by the city and the size, shape, color as set forth in subsections (1) and (5) of this subsection (c), and other design features, including orientation at the site, have been approved by the city. In determining design requirements, the city shall consider compatibility of design features with prevailing facade treatments and with streetscape improvements to the full extent newsracks having such features are reasonably available on the market. 
(11)  Each newsrack shall be maintained in a neat and clean condition and in good repair at all times. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, each newsrack shall be serviced and maintained so that: 
i.  It is reasonably free of dirt and grease; 
ii.  It is reasonably free of chipped, faded, peeling and cracked paint in the visible painted areas thereof; 
iii.  It is reasonably free of rust and corrosion in the visible unpainted metal areas thereof; 
iv.  The clear plastic or glass parts thereof, if any, through which the publications therein are viewed, are unbroken and reasonably free of cracks, dents, blemishes and discoloration; 
v.  The structural parts thereof are not broken or unduly misshapen; and 
vi.  It is free of graffiti. 
(12)  Provided the newsracks which are located in the city on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived are not determined to be a public nuisance or dangerous to the public safety, or its health or general welfare, such newsracks lawfully in existence as of the effective date of the ordinance shall be allowed to remain at the same location for a period not to exceed three (3) months from the effective date of the ordinance. 
(13)  During the three (3) months after the ratification of this article, nine (9) of the thirty-three (33) locations where newsracks currently exist shall be disassembled and permanently removed by the city or its designee. The nine (9) locations of the newsracks that shall be removed during this three-month period are more fully set forth in Exhibit B, attached to Ordinance No. 2012-239, and incorporated by reference herein. 
(d)  Removal. 
(1)  If the city determines that a newsrack has been placed, installed or maintained on a right-of-way in violation of this article, the director of livability, a division of the department of planning, preservation and sustainability (the "department") shall cause to be placed a notice of violation upon the newsrack. The notice of violation shall state that the newsrack shall be removed and destroyed unless the newsrack is brought into compliance with this article within ten (10) business days of the date of the notice. If the newsrack is not removed or brought into compliance within such ten-day period, and if no hearing has been requested under this section within such period, the department may remove and destroy the newsrack at the expense of the distributor. The notice given under this section shall also state that the distributor may, within ten (10) days of the date of the notice, request a hearing before the committee of traffic and transportation at which time the distributor shall be given an opportunity to contest the allegations of the complaint or to demonstrate that the conditions constituting a violation of this article have been remedied. If, after the hearing, the department determines that a violation of this article continues to occur, the department shall order the distributor to remove the newsrack from the right-of-way no later than five (5) days from the date of the written determination by the committee of traffic and transportation. 
(2)  Any newsrack that remains on the right-of-way for more than ten (10) days after it has been ordered removed pursuant to subsection (1) above shall be removed and destroyed by the city at the expense of the distributor. 
(3)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, the city may require a distributor to remove or relocate a newsrack when such removal or relocation is necessary to accommodate a public or private construction or repair project or similar activity. In cases where immediate removal of the newsrack is necessary to protect the health or safety of the public, the city may remove or relocate the newsrack at the distributor's expense and promptly give written notice to the distributor at the address identified on the newsrack of such removal or relocation thereafter. In all other cases, the city shall cause a notice to be placed upon the newsrack, or shall give written notice to the distributor at the address identified on the newsrack, stating that the newsrack must be removed or relocated within ten (10) days of the date of the notice and the reason for the removal or relocation. If the newsrack is not removed or relocated within the time specified by the city, the city shall remove and destroy or relocate the newsrack at the distributor's expense. The city may return a newsrack not previously destroyed if the distributor reimburses the city for its costs associated with its removal. 
(e)  Insurance required: encroachment permit required; encroachment permit not a property right. 
(1)  Any publisher or distributor wishing to place a newsrack on the public right-of-way shall provide a certificate of insurance to the city which shall evidence a minimum of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) per person and six hundred thousand dollars ($600,000.00) per occurrence in public liability coverage on the newsrack permitted by the city to be placed on the public right-of-way and which shall name the City of Charleston as an additional insured thereon. 
(2)  Prior to the placement of a newsrack on the public right-of-way, a publisher or distributor shall obtain an encroachment permit from the city by submitting a newsrack encroachment permit application and a nonrefundable twenty-five-dollar application fee to the city's department of engineering at 75 Calhoun Street, 3rd floor. 
All newsracks which are issued a newsrack encroachment permit as set forth in subsection (2) above shall display the name of the publisher or distributor and provide a telephone number to call with any complaints, including problems with maintenance, operation, or location on the outside of each newsrack on a label on the front of the newsrack not to exceed three (3) square inches. Any permit for the use of public space as provided for under this section are not property rights or entitlements of any newsrack owner, publisher or distributor of material found in them. 
(f)  Penalty for violation. Any person or entity that violates this article shall be subject to section 1-20, General penalty, of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2012-239, § 1, 5-8-12)  
ARTICLE VIII. - LATE NIGHT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENTS 
 
Sec. 17-124. - Findings. 
Successful communities are those that provide desirable atmospheres for living, working and recreating. To foster strong neighborhoods and a healthy economy, it is vital that a balance between these sometimes competing interests be achieved and maintained. Viable, well-managed nightlife activities are crucial elements to the success of the city, as they provide needed recreational opportunities to visitors and residents alike. The hospitality industry is of particular importance to the city's tourist economy, and it is imperative that this industry be conducted in a manner that fosters safe, inviting entertainment so that the city remains attractive to first-time, and returning, visitors. In recent years, the number of establishments that offer on-premises consumption of beer, wine and alcoholic beverages in the early morning hours has increased. These establishments, often in close proximity to one another, provide natural places for gathering and frivolity. Due to their hours of operation, the entertainment they provide and their numbers of patrons coming and going, these establishments often generate noise, litter, traffic and other deleterious effects which disturb the peace, quietude and good order of the community and impose unnecessary burdens on public safety officers. City council finds it in the interests of public safety and good order in the community that reasonable measures be enacted to require that establishments open after midnight and which allow for the on-premises consumption of beer, wine or alcohol, outside the confines of a structure that offers accommodations, demonstrate a willingness and ability to responsibly conduct their business and monitor the activities of their patrons. 
(Ord. No. 2013-55, § 1, 5-28-13)  
Sec. 17-125. - Definitions. 
Door person means a person who is present at all times at the entrance door of a late night entertainment establishment to monitor the number of persons entering the business for compliance with its maximum occupancy load and to check the identifications of persons, if authorized by the business. 
Late night entertainment establishment means a business in existence as of July 1, 2013 that: 
(a)  Is not located in a structure that provides accommodations as that term is used in section 54-120 of the Zoning Ordinance, as the same may from time to time be amended; 
(b)  Is open after midnight; 
(c)  Is licensed to allow on-premises consumption of beer, wine or alcohol; and 
(d)  Is required to have a Class 7(a) business license. 
A business that comes into existence on or after July 1, 2013 which meets the requirements of subsections (a), (b) and (c) shall not be subject to the provisions of subsection 17-126(b) during its first business license year; provided that every one hundred twenty (120) days, beginning on the date the establishment opens for business, the establishment shall submit a report to the city business license division that separately reports the percentage of gross revenues derived from the sale of food and other items from the percentage of gross revenues derived from the sale of beer, wine and/or alcoholic beverages. If for any reporting period, the percentage of gross sales from the sale of beer, wine and/or alcohol is thirty-five (35) percent or more of the gross sales of the establishment, the establishment shall be subject to subsection 17-126(b). This reporting requirement ends when the establishment renews it business license. 
Nothing in this definition shall be deemed to be inconsistent with the provisions of the city's business license ordinance, including but not limited to the schedule of license fees. 
Maximum occupant load means the maximum number of people allowed in a late night entertainment establishment pursuant to the International Fire Code or other fire code in effect in the city, all as the same may, from time to time, be amended. 
Off-site areas used for parking means: 
(1)  Parking spaces or areas not located on the lot of record of the late night entertainment establishment; and 
(2)  Shared parking areas on the lots of record of the late night entertainment establishment, either of which are made available by the late night entertainment establishment to its personnel and patrons for parking. 
Security person means a person who monitors the entrance and other areas of the late night entertainment establishment for purposes of, among others, monitoring compliance with the business's maximum occupancy load, identifying underage and intoxicated persons, enforcing the rules and regulations of the business, and otherwise providing security for the business and its patrons. 
Security supervisor means a security person who is responsible for supervising and overseeing security persons. 
Voluntary occupant load means the maximum number of people allowed in a late night entertainment establishment after midnight, if requested by the owner of the establishment and so designated on the application for a permit for a late night entertainment establishment. The voluntary occupant load must be less than the maximum occupant load and governs the amount of security required in the establishment after midnight. 
(Ord. No. 2013-55, § 1, 5-28-13; Ord. No. 2014-38, §§ 1, 2, 3-25-14)  
Sec. 17-126. - Late night entertainment establishment operational regulations. 
(a)  Noise. Late night entertainment establishments where music is played after 11:00 p.m. shall close all doors and windows of the establishment at 11:00 p.m. Notwithstanding the foregoing, noise generated from an establishment after 11:00 p.m. that is capable of being heard within fifty (50) feet of an entrance to the establishment is declared to be a nuisance. It shall be the responsibility of management of the establishment to take all measures as are required to manage noise from the establishment such that it does not constitute a nuisance as set forth herein. 
(b)  Security. 
(1)  Late night entertainment establishment personnel shall be responsible for operating the establishment in a safe and orderly manner. After midnight and until closing, the number and type of security personnel on duty at all times shall be determined by the business's maximum occupant load ("MOL") or voluntary occupant load ("VOL"), if requested and designated on the establishment's application regardless of whether the number of people constituting the maximum occupant load or voluntary occupant load, if applicable, is then present: 
a.  Forty-nine (49) MOL/VOL or less: one (1) door person and one (1) security person. The security person may also serve as the establishment's manager who may also have front-of-the-house duties.
