b.  One hundred (100) MOL/VOL or less: one (1) door person and one (1) security person, one (1) of which may be a manager, so long as said manager has no other duties. 
c.  One hundred one (101) MOL/VOL—Two hundred (200) MOL/VOL: one (1) door person and two (2) security persons, one (1) of which may be a manager, so long as said manager has no other duties. 
d.  Two hundred one (201) MOL/VOL—Three hundred (300) MOL/VOL: one (1) door person and three (3) security persons, one (1) of which may be a manager, so long as said manager has no other duties. 
e.  Three hundred one (301) MOL/VOL—Four hundred (400) MOL/VOL: one (1) door person and four (4) security persons, one (1) of which may be a manager, so long as said manager has no other duties. 
f.  Four hundred one (401) MOL/VOL—Five hundred (500) MOL/VOL: one (1) door person and five (5) security persons, including a security supervisor who may be one of the five (5) security persons. One (1) of the security persons which may be a manager, so long as said manager has no other duties. 
g.  Five hundred one (501) MOL/VOL—Six hundred (600) MOL/VOL: one (1) door person and six (6) security persons, including a security supervisor who may be one (1) of the six (6) security persons. One (1) of the security persons which may be a manager, so long as said manager has no other duties. 
h.  Six hundred one (601) MOL/VOL—Seven hundred (700) MOL/VOL: one (1) door person and seven (7) security persons, including a security supervisor who may be one of the seven (7) security persons. One (1) of the security persons which may be a manager, so long as said manager has no other duties. 
i.  Seven hundred one (701) MOL/VOL—eight hundred (800) MOL/VOL: one (1) door person and eight (8) security persons, including a security supervisor who may be one of the eight (8) security persons. One (1) of the security persons which may be a manager, so long as said manager has no other duties. 
j.  Eight hundred one (801) MOL/VOL and above: one (1) door person and one (1) security person for every one hundred (100) persons as allowed by the business's maximum occupant load or voluntary occupant load, if applicable, and one (1) security supervisor for every four (4) security persons. Security supervisors may also be security persons required under this subsection. One (1) of the security persons may be a manager, so long as said manager has no other duties. 
(2)  It shall be the responsibility of late night entertainment establishment personnel to employ crowd management techniques to assure that patrons are adequately disbursed throughout the establishment in compliance with the maximum occupant load of the specific area or areas of the establishment occupied after midnight. 
(3)  It shall be the responsibility of late night entertainment establishment personnel to see that the maximum occupant load is not exceeded. 
(4)  It shall be the responsibility of late night entertainment establishment personnel to maintain a line of persons adjacent to the outside of the late night entertainment establishment so they are not blocking the sidewalk, street or public ways or entrances to other establishments. 
(5)  It shall be the responsibility of late night entertainment establishment personnel to routinely monitor all on-site and off-site areas used for parking by the late night entertainment establishment or its patrons to prevent such areas from becoming outdoor gathering places. It shall be the responsibility of late night entertainment establishment personnel to clear all on and off-site areas used for parking of patrons within thirty (30) minutes of closing. 
(6)  All security personnel shall be readily identifiable by such means as a badge or other form of identification to assist patrons and public safety officers. 
(7)  It shall be the responsibility of late night entertainment personnel to assist persons in entering and leaving the late night entertainment establishment in an orderly manner. In the event any person is disorderly or otherwise is engaged in illegal conduct, the late night entertainment personnel shall contact law enforcement. 
(8)  The provisions of this subsection shall only be applicable between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m. on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, the holidays of Memorial Day and Labor Day, and between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m. on the day following New Year's Eve, Fourth of July, and Halloween, and when special concerts or promotions take place at the late night entertainment establishment. 
An establishment operating under a voluntary occupant load may allow occupancy after midnight up to the maximum occupant load of the establishment on the holidays of Memorial Day and Labor Day, and between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m. on the day following New Year's Eve, the Fourth of July and Halloween, and on the Friday, Saturday and Sunday of Southeast Wildlife Exposition and the Cooper River Bridge Run, provided the security personnel required by the establishment's maximum occupant load per subsection (b)(1) are maintained on the premises, regardless of whether the number of people allowed by the maximum occupant load is then present. 
(c)  Waste management. 
(1)  It shall be the responsibility of late night entertainment establishment personnel to maintain the exterior grounds of the establishment, the sidewalks abutting the establishment and all parking areas of the establishment, on and off site, in a clean condition, free of trash, rubbish or other debris. 
(2)  Late night entertainment establishments that utilize city sanitation services shall adhere to all ordinances, regulations and policies of the city pertaining to containing, collecting and disposing of sanitary waste. Sanitary waste containers shall be stored at such locations as may be approved by the late night entertainment establishment committee. 
(d)  It shall be the responsibility of late night entertainment establishment personnel to, at all times, operate and maintain the late night entertainment establishment premises in accordance with all requirements of this article and all other applicable city ordinances, including but not limited to zoning, building and fire codes. 
(e)  In addition to the general penalty provisions of this Code, the failure to abide by the provisions of this section 17-126 may result in the suspension or revocation of the establishment's business license or certificate of occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 2013-55, § 1, 5-28-13; Ord. No. 2014-38, §§ 3, 4, 3-25-14)  
Sec. 17-127. - Late night entertainment establishment review committee. 
There is hereby created a late night establishment review committee. The committee shall be appointed by the mayor and consist of seven (7) members, one (1) of whom shall be an employee of the police department, one (1) of whom shall be an employee of the department of planning, preservation and sustainability, one (1) of whom shall be an employee of the department of public services building inspections division, one of whom shall be an employee of the department of public services environmental services division, one (1) of whom shall be an employee of the department of traffic and transportation, one (1) of whom shall be an employee of the fire department fire marshal division, and one (1) of whom shall be an at-large employee, or any of their respective designees. The office of corporation counsel shall assist the committee, as necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2013-55, § 1, 5-28-13)  
Sec. 17-128. - Late night entertainment establishment committee duties and responsibilities. 
The late night establishment review committee shall act as an administrative board and shall review and approve or disapprove applications for late night entertainment establishments in the city. In its review and action on applications, the committee shall apply the criteria for the establishment of late night entertainment establishments as set out in section 17-130 hereof. The committee shall render its decision on an application within fourteen (14) days of its submission to the city. Failure to render a decision within this timeframe shall constitute approval of the application. In the event an application is disapproved, the committee shall set forth in writing its reasons for denial and include suggested means for the applicant to come into compliance with the provisions of section 17-130. This article establishes the minimum requirements to commence the application process for a late night entertainment establishment, and is supplemental to other city ordinances rules, regulations and applicable standard codes. Approval of a late night entertainment establishment application by the committee shall not be deemed to relieve the applicant from complying with any other applicable federal, state or local regulations applicable to its business, including building and fire codes. 
(Ord. No. 2013-55, § 1, 5-28-13)  
Sec. 17-129. - Late night entertainment establishment requirements. 
No city permit to operate a late night entertainment establishment shall be processed or issued until an application to operate the establishment has been approved by the late night entertainment establishment committee. 
(Ord. No. 2013-55, § 1, 5-28-13)  
Sec. 17-130. - Late night entertainment establishment application. 
(a)  The application to operate a late night entertainment establishment must include the following: 
(1)  Floor plans, drawn to scale, showing the interior of the structure to be occupied by the establishment, to include the designation and square footage of patron use areas (customer circulation, standing, dancing, seating and wait areas), stage areas for entertainment and non-patron use areas (restrooms, kitchen, office, storage etc.). All exits shall be noted, as well as areas to be sprinkled when required by Code. When an establishment will not occupy the entire structure, the plans must identify other uses in the structure at the time of application. 
(2)  A site plan, drawn to scale, showing the entire exterior of the premises to include the locations of all buildings on the premises, parking areas, refuse collection areas, the main entrance to the establishment, emergency exits from the establishment, all means of ingress and egress to the premises, lighting locations and the location and dimensions of existing and proposed trees, plantings and landscaping. 
(3)  If required parking is not to be provided on-site, a plan describing how parking will be addressed, to include the location of off-site areas used for parking and their distances from the premises where the establishment will be located. 
(4)  A security and management plan describing with particularity the days and hours of operation, crowd management measures to be taken, both in and outside the premises and any parking areas under the control of the establishment, and means of controlling access, and underage drinking and serving. 
(5)  A waste management plan describing with particularity how waste from the establishment will be collected, stored and discarded. 
(6)  An emergency action plan describing with particularity how and under what circumstances the establishment would curb fire hazards, manage an emergency, to include evacuation techniques and the respective responsibilities of on-duty personnel. 
(7)  Any fee that may, from time to time, be established by city council. 
(b)  The provisions set out in an approved late night entertainment establishment application shall constitute conditions of the establishment's certificate of occupancy and business license, in addition to those that may be imposed by applicable ordinances and standard codes in effect. In addition to the general penalty provisions of this Code, the failure of the establishment to adhere to representations in the approved application may result in the suspension or revocation of the establishment's certificate of occupancy or business license. 
(Ord. No. 2013-55, § 1, 5-28-13)  
Sec. 17-131. - Appeal—Application decisions. 
An applicant aggrieved by a decision of the late night entertainment establishment committee pertaining to its application for a late night entertainment establishment permit shall have the right of appeal to the business license committee. The appeal must be filed with the clerk of council within thirty (30) days of the mailing date of the decision of the committee. The appeal must be in writing and specifically delineate the grounds of appeal. 
(Ord. No. 2013-55, § 1, 5-28-13)  
Sec. 17-132. - Appeal—Operational regulation violations. 
(a)  Building official: A person aggrieved by a decision of the building official (or his designee) pertaining to the certificate of occupancy of a late night entertainment establishment shall have the right to appeal to the building code board of appeals. The appeal must be filed in the office of the building official within thirty (30) days of the mailing or hand-delivery date of the decision of the building official. The appeal must be in writing and specifically delineate the grounds of appeal. 
(b)  Business license official: A person aggrieved by a decision of the business license official (or his designee) pertaining to the business license of a late night entertainment establishment shall have the right to appeal to the business license committee, in accordance with the provisions of the business license ordinance. The appeal must be in writing and specifically delineate the grounds of appeal. 
(c)  Fire marshal: A person aggrieved by a decision of the fire marshal (or his designee) pertaining to the certificate of occupancy of its late night entertainment establishment shall have the right to appeal first to fire marshal in accordance with the terms of any order, and then to the building board of adjustment and appeals if the matter is not resolved in accordance with the provisions of the fire code. The appeal must be in writing and specifically delineate the grounds of appeal. 
(Ord. No. 2013-55, § 1, 5-28-13)  
Sec. 17-133. - Appeal—Circuit court. 
A late night entertainment establishment aggrieved by a decision of the building code of appeals or business license committee may appeal to the Circuit Court of Charleston or Berkeley County, as applicable. An appeal from the building code of appeals must be filed and served in accordance with the provisions of the building code. An appeal from the business license committee must be filed and served in accordance with the provisions of the business license ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2013-55, § 1, 5-28-13)  
Sec. 17-134. - Effective date. 
The provisions of this article shall become effective on July 1, 2013. Late night entertainment establishments in existence as of the effective date of this article shall come into compliance with the provisions of subsections 17-130 (c), (d), (e) and (f) prior to the renewal of its business license for the calendar year immediately following the date of ratification or upon any expansion of the floor area of the establishment, whichever shall first occur. 
(Ord. No. 2013-55, § 1, 5-28-13)  
Sec. 17-135. - Soft closing pilot program. 
(a)  Findings. 
Whereas, on October 14, 2014, city council enacted Ordinance No. 2014-36, imposing a moratorium on the opening of new establishments that sell alcohol, beer or wine for on-premises consumption after midnight in certain areas of the Peninsula. 
Whereas, one purpose of the moratorium was to allow the issue of an over concentration of such establishments to be studied. 
Whereas, city council appointed a committee of citizens to study the issue and provide a report to council as to its recommendations. 
Whereas, the committee consisted of representatives from the food and beverage industry, neighborhoods and the daytime business sector. 
Whereas, the committee met on a monthly basis, and at the city council meeting held on July 21, 2015, presented its report to city council. 
Whereas, one recommendation of the report was to test, for a period of ninety (90) days, the concept of a "soft closing", whereby establishments selling alcohol, beer or wine for on-premises consumption in the study area would be given the opportunity to remain open until 3:00 a.m., to measure if allowing patrons to remain on the premises of the affected establishment an extra hour would curb noise and traffic issues related to having patrons of all such establishments vacate the affected establishments by 2:00 a.m., and weigh the effects of a soft closing as it relates to noise and traffic and the effect on public safety operations. 
Whereas, the trial period ordinance was enacted on September 8, 2015 and the trial period ran from September 8, 2015 to December 7, 2015. 
Whereas, after studying the ninety-day trial period, it is now the committee's recommendation that a new six month trial period for the program be approved with the addition of certain rules and the revision of other rules related to the program. 
Whereas, it is the intent of the city that the soft closing program offer a fair and reasonable opportunity for all interested establishments citywide to prepare and participate in the trial program for the maximum benefit of all. 
(b)  Soft closing pilot program and rules. 
(1)  Notwithstanding the provisions of section 3-2 of the Code of the City of Charleston, for a period of six (6) months from the ratification of the ordinance from which this section derives, commercial establishments located within the City of Charleston which allow for on-premises consumption of alcohol, beer, ale, porter and/or wine may operate until 3:00 a.m., provided however, that at all times between 2:00 a.m. and 3:00 a.m. when the establishment is operating, the following requirements are met: 
i.  The house lights within the establishment shall be turned up to fifty (50) percent of their highest level or fifty (50) percent of the house lights within the establishment must be turned to their highest levels; 
ii.  The volume of any amplification devices, stereo systems, or like devices shall be turned down to a level that cannot be heard twenty-five (25) feet from the perimeter of the property at any time for any length of time; 
iii.  All alcohol, beer, ale, porter and/or wine shall be removed from all tables and patron bars within the establishment; 
iv.  There shall be no sale or gift of any alcohol, beer, ale, porter and/or wine to any patron of the establishment; 
v.  There shall be no consumption or possession of alcohol, beer, ale, porter and/or wine by any patron of the establishment; and 
vi.  Patrons shall be permitted to enter or re-enter the establishment, if the establishment has an operational kitchen with a nighttime menu that includes more than the sale of prepackaged foods, single snack packages, and individually wrapped food for consumption. The nighttime menu shall contain menu items that are prepared, cooked, and plated similarly to the establishment's normal daytime menu. 
(2)  Commercial establishments for which this section applies may, between 2:00 a.m. and 3:00 a.m., provide or sell food and non-alcoholic beverages to its patrons. 
(3)  Any commercial establishment desiring to participate in this trial program shall notify the soft closing program liaison of their desire to participate in the soft closing trial program at least seven (7) business days in advance of the day it intends to begin operating after 2:00 a.m. 
(4)  All commercial establishments to which this section applies are prohibited from operating between the hours of 3:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m., Mondays through Saturdays. 
(c)  This section shall begin on August 1, 2016 and end on January 31, 2017 unless extended by majority vote of the city council. 
( Ord. No. 2016-084, §§ 1, 2, 7-19-16 )  
Secs. 17-136—17-150. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - FRANCHISE AGREEMENT FOR INSTALLATION AND CONSTRUCTION OF FIBER OPTICS IN THE PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY 
 
Sec. 17-151. - Findings. 
(a)  Whereas, it is in the interests of the city to require a non-exclusive franchise agreement to regulate the incremental installation of fiber optic cable within property owned by the city or otherwise within public rights-of-way or easements to assist in expediting the implementation of a fiber optic network within the city, decrease the costs associated with the construction and creation of such a system, allow the city to control use of these public ways and to meet the needs of city departments, public safety organizations, and other publicly owned and operated facilities; 
(b)  Whereas, the regulation of the incremental installation of fiber optic cable by a nonexclusive franchise agreements will protect the public rights-of-ways or easements by improving both the management and regulation of competing demands through the elimination of duplicate fiber optic facilities within public property, easements, and rights-of-way; protect the economic vitality of the city by providing the broadband transport service and fiber facilities leasing required by broadband service providers; and manage traffic disruption that occurs whenever excavation occurs within or around these areas. 
( Ord. No. 2018-114 , § 1, 9-18-18)  
Sec. 17-152. - Non-exclusive franchise agreement required. 
No person or entity shall install and construct fiber optics cable within property owned by the city or otherwise within public rights-of-way or easements without first entering into a non-exclusive franchise agreement with the city. Such franchise agreement shall be granted for an initial period of five (5) years commencing on the date of the last signature placed on this agreement and shall be automatically renew for two (2) additional five-year periods provided upon compliance with the provisions of the franchise agreement. 
( Ord. No. 2018-114 , § 1, 9-18-18)  
Sec. 17-153. - Contents of franchise agreement. 
The franchise agreement shall contain the following provisions: 
NON-EXCLUSIVE FRANCHISE AGREEMENT 
This non-exclusive Franchise Agreement ("Agreement") is made as of the ________day of ________, 2018, by and between the City of Charleston, South Carolina, (the "City"), and ("___________"), a limited liability company authorized to do business within the State of South Carolina, and being incorporated in the State of _______. 
RECITALS 
WHEREAS, ___________ is a limited liability company duly organized and existing under the laws of the State of _______, which has been issued a Certificate of Convenience and Necessity from the Public Service Commission of South Carolina; and 
WHEREAS, ___________ desires to construct, install and maintain Facilities within certain portions of the Public Rights-of-Way in portions of the City of Charleston; and 
NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of the recitals and the mutual promises contained herein, the City and ___________ agree as follows: 
DEFINITIONS 
"Fiber Optic Facilities" means approved fiber optic cables, conduits, converters, splice boxes, cabinets, handholes, manholes, vaults, equipment, drains, surface location markers, appurtenances, and related facilities to be located by in the Public Rights-of-Way of the City as defined below. 
"Law" means any local, South Carolina or federal legislative, judicial or administrative order, certificate, decision, statute, constitution, ordinance, resolution, regulation, rule, tariff, guideline, standards or other requirement, as amended, now in effect or subsequently enacted or issued during the term of this Agreement, including, but not limited to, the Communications Act of 1934, as amended by the Telecommunications Act of 1996, Pub. L. No. 104-104 § 101(a), 110 Stat. 70 codified at 47 U.S.C. § 151, et seq., and all orders, rules, tariffs, guidelines and regulations issued by the Federal Communications Commission or the governing state authority pursuant thereto as applicable, all laws regulations and rules of the South Carolina Department of Transportation, and all rules, regulations and guidelines issued by the City. 
"Public Rights-of-Way" means the surface and the area across, in, over, along, upon and below the surface of the public streets, roads, sidewalks, lanes, courts, ways, alleys, and boulevards, but shall not include other public property used for parks, offices, libraries and other non-traffic, non-pedestrian purposes without the express written consent of the City. 
"Small Cell Facilities" or "DAS Facilities" means equipment installed in the public rights-of-way, other than Fiber Optic Facilities, including but not limited to electronic equipment, optical converters, power amplifiers, radios, multiplexers, microcells, remote radio units, antennas, related fiber optic and coaxial cables, wires, meters, pedestals, power switches, and related equipment. 
"Telecommunications Facilities" or "Facilities" means all facilities installed by to support the provision of Telecommunications Services, including Fiber Optic Facilities and Small Cell Facilities. 
"Telecommunications Services" means all telecommunications services that may provide under Law. 
CONSTRUCTION, MAINTENANCE AND OPERATION OF THE SYSTEM 
1.  Access. Subject to the provisions of this Agreement, and all applicable Law, the City hereby grants to the non-exclusive right to construct, install, maintain, locate, move, operate, place, protect, reconstruct, reinstall, relocate, remove and replace the Facilities in, under, and along all certain Public Rights-of-Way and only in the non-vehicular portions of the Rights-of-Way and as pursuant to permits issued pursuant to paragraphs 5 and 6 below. 
2.  Term. The term of this Agreement shall be for an initial period of five (5) years commencing on the date of the last signature placed on this Agreement. This Agreement shall automatically renew for two (2) additional five (5) year periods, unless gives ninety (90) days' notice of intent to terminate prior to the end of the applicable five (5) year period. 
3.  No Interference. Except as permitted by applicable Law or this Agreement, in the performance and exercise of its rights and obligations under this Agreement, shall not interfere in any manner with the existence and operation of any and all existing public and private Rights-of-Way, sanitary sewers, water mains, storm drains, gas mains, poles, overhead and underground electric and telephone wires, electronics, cable televisions, and other telecommunications, utility and municipal property without the approval of the owner(s) of the affected property or properties. 
4.  No Property Interest. This Agreement is not a grant by the City of any fee simple or other property interest of any kind and is made subject and subordinate to the prior and continuing right of the City to use the Public Rights-of-Way for any purposes allowed by law, including but not limited to streets and sidewalks and for the purpose of laying, installing, maintaining, repairing, protecting, replacing and removing sanitary sewers, water mains, storm drains, gas mains, poles and for other municipal uses and with right of ingress and egress, along, over, across and in said Public Rights-of-Way. 
5.  Application for Fiber Optic Permits. Prior to installing any Fiber Optic Facilities, shall file an engineering permit for approval of all work proposed (covering and showing all Fiber Optic Facilities) and engineering permits seeking approval of each job (covering all details of all sections or phases of the installation of the Fiber Optic Facilities, including the location of all borings, the size, type and location of equipment, and all lines and their encasement) within the Public Rights-of-Way. ___________ shall furnish detailed plans of the work and other such information as required by the City of Charleston's Department of Public Service and shall pay all required permit and inspection fees prior to issuance of general job permits and phase or section permits in accordance with the rates and standards in effect at the time of payment. Improvements shall be constructed and installed in accordance with applicable Law and plans approved by the City. 
___________ shall have obtained any other necessary permits from the South Carolina Department of Transportation, the County of Charleston, or any other governmental entity having jurisdiction over any applicable Rights-of-Way and provide copies of such permits to the City at the time of applying for the City general permit. Likewise, shall provide written certification that has permission from the owner of the pole in issue to attach to or otherwise modify it consistent with the plans and permit application(s) filed with the City. 
6.  Issuance of Permits. Upon execution of this Agreement, satisfaction of all applicable requirements and 's performance of the obligations in Section 5, the City will issue all permits necessary from the City to install 's Fiber Optic Facilities, in accordance with the City's standard permitting procedures. 
7.  DAS or Small Cell Permits. The parties agree that the installation of DAS or Small Cell Facilities shall be governed by a separate ordinance adopted by the City and generally applicable to all entities installing DAS or Small Cell Facilities in the public Rights-of-Way in the City. Prior to installing DAS or Small Cell Facilities, will first apply for and obtain all necessary permits or licensing agreements required by the City's Small Cell ordinances. 
8.  Manner of Construction. The construction, installation, operation, maintenance, and removal of its Facilities shall be accomplished without cost or expense to the City and in such a manner so as not to endanger persons or property, or unreasonably obstruct travel on the Public Rights-of-Way. In the event the use of any portion of the Facilities has been discontinued for a period of 180 consecutive days, such portion of the Facilities shall be deemed to have been abandoned and the City may execute against any required bonds to remove such Facilities and restore all locations as necessary. Any amount not covered by performance or other bonds shall be the sole responsibility of. 
9.  Condition of Facilities. ___________ agrees to keep its Facilities in compliance with the Law. ___________ shall inspect, on a periodic basis, their Facilities, and initiate repairs to any part of their Facilities not in compliance with the Law. If the City determines Facilities do not meet the requirements of this Ordinance, or any permits issued pursuant to this Ordinance, it shall provide thirty (30) days' notice before seeking the issuance of a summons. 
10.  Relocation for City Purposes. ___________ shall relocate, at ___________'s expense, unless otherwise provided for by Law, in cooperation with the City, any Facilities installed, used and maintained under this Agreement if and when made necessary by a City Public Works Project and/or the construction, maintenance or operation of any of the City's properties or facilities including without limitation, underground or above- ground facilities such as roads, sidewalks, water and sewer. The City will use its best efforts to identify any reasonable options for relocation, consistent with identification of the most cost- effective solution to the City for completion of a City Project. 
11.  Removal and Abandonment. 
(a)  Upon the expiration of this Agreement, ___________ agrees to promptly vacate and remove its Facilities at its own expense and restore all locations as required by the City, provided that the City's Director of the Department of Public Service may, at that time, agree in writing, upon the written request of ___________, to allow abandonment of some or all of its Facilities in place, if ___________ will transfer ownership of any abandoned Facilities to the City. 
12.  Undergrounding of Facilities Where Required. 
(a)  During any initial construction, ___________ shall place its Fiber Optic Facilities underground if required by the City pursuant to Law; provided, however , that if within the immediate area (determined on a block by block basis) other telecommunications and/or cable television companies have their facilities located above ground, shall have the option to place its Facilities above ground and later move the same underground when such other companies are required by the City to place their Facilities underground. After ___________ has installed any above ground Facilities, ___________ shall at ___________'s expense place its Facilities underground contemporaneously with any City required undergrounding of all telecommunications and cable television cables in the designated area. 
13.  Restoration of Public Rights-of-Way. After the construction, removal or relocation of any Facilities, ___________ shall, at its own cost, repair and return the Public Rights-of-Way to the same condition existing before such construction, removal, or relocation as determined by the City. shall be responsible for damage to street pavements, existing utilities, curbs, gutters, sidewalks and any other public or private property due to ___________'s installation, maintenance, repair or removal of its Fiber Optic Network Facilities in Public Rights-of-Way, and shall repair, replace, and restore in kind to the same or better condition, any damaged property at its sole expense. 
COMPENSATION 
14.  Franchise/Consent Fee. ___________ shall pay the City an annual franchise/consent fee at the maximum rate presently or hereafter specified in § 58-9-2230 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina, commencing on _______, and on _______ of each year thereafter. 
15.  Business License Fee. ___________ shall pay the City an annual business license fee at the maximum rate specified in the City's business license ordinance, the first payment being due on or before January 31, 20___. 
16.  Nondiscriminatory Fees. Notwithstanding anything included in this Agreement to the contrary, in no event shall be required to pay any fee, charge, cost, expense or compensation, or be subject to any obligations that would be a violation of Law. 
17.  Other Fees. shall pay all permit, inspection and user fees to the City in accordance with Law, as well as any other taxes or fees allowed to be imposed by § 58-9-2230(C) of the Code of Laws of South Carolina.

Chapter 18 - MARION SQUARE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Department of administrative services, § 2-176 et seq.; department of public service, § 2-231 et seq.; department of special facilities, § 2-246 et seq.; Colonial Common and Ashley River Embankment, Ch. 9; Cypress Gardens, Ch. 10; department of recreation and department of parks, Ch. 22; planning, Ch. 23; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 28; tourism, Ch. 29. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 18-1. - Boundaries and designation. 
The grounds bounded on the north by the building formerly known as and used by the South Carolina Military Academy, east on Meeting Street, south on Calhoun Street and west on King Street, held in trust, as of October 24, 1882, by the city council and a board of officers of the South Carolina National Guard, in the city, for the use of the National Guard as a parade ground, and for the citizens of the city as a public mall, shall be hereafter known as Marion Square. 
(Code 1975, § 32-1)  
Secs. 18-2—18-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— City boards and commissions generally, § 2-151 et seq.; board of commissioners of Colonial Common and Ashley River Embankment, § 9-16 et seq.; board of commissioners of Cypress Gardens, § 10-16. 
 
Sec. 18-16. - Management and control of Marion Square; composition; election and term of members. 
The management and control of Marion Square shall be, and is hereby, vested in a board of seven (7) commissioners. The commissioners shall hold office for one year from the date of their election and until their successors are elected and qualified. The superintendent of the South Carolina Military Academy, now known as The Citadel, the Military College of South Carolina, shall be ex officio a member and chairman of such board; of the other six (6) members of such board, three (3) shall be elected by the city council. The remaining three (3) members shall be elected by the board of officers of the South Carolina National Guard, in the city, at its first meeting in January. 
(Code 1975, § 32-2)  
Sec. 18-17. - Vacancies. 
If there should be a vacancy in the membership of the board of commissioners of Marion Square, such vacancy shall be filled by a new election of another person in the manner prescribed for the expired term. 
(Code 1975, § 32-3)  
Sec. 18-18. - Authority to adopt rules and regulations. 
The board of commissioners of Marion Square shall have power to make all such rules and regulations as may be necessary for their own government, and for the use, improvement and preservation of the square; provided, however, that such rules and regulations shall be approved by the city council and the board of officers of the South Carolina National Guard, in the city. 
(Code 1975, § 32-4)  
Sec. 18-19. - Management and expenditure of appropriations; reports. 
The board of commissioners of Marion Square shall have the management and expenditure of all moneys which may be appropriated for the improvement and preservation of the square, and shall annually, or oftener if required by the city council, report their actings and doings to the city council and the board of officers of the South Carolina National Guard, in the city, with a statement of all moneys received and expended by them. 
(Code 1975, § 32-5)  
Chapter 19 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— General penalty for Code violations, § 1-16; committee on traffic and transportation, § 2-58; municipal court, Ch. 20; offenses, Ch. 21; planning, Ch. 23; police, Ch. 25; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 28; tourism, § 29-1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 19-1. - Definitions. 
The following words and terms when used in this chapter shall for the purpose of this chapter have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section. Whenever any words or phrases used in this chapter are not herein defined but are defined in state statutes regulating operation of vehicles, any such statute definition shall apply: 
Bus stop. The term "bus stop" shall be taken to mean an area immediately adjacent to a curb designated by appropriate sign or marking for the loading or unloading of passengers by buses. 
Chauffeur. The word "chauffeur" shall be taken to mean any person, other than a person licensed as a taxicab operator under article IV of chapter 31 of this Code, who earns a substantial part of his livelihood by driving a motor vehicle for himself or another, or who at any time drives a motor vehicle used as a public or common carrier of persons or property. 
Curbing. The word "curbing" shall be taken to mean the lateral boundaries of that portion of the street designed for the use of vehicles, whether marked by curbstones or not so marked. 
Loading zone. The term "loading zone" shall be taken to mean an area immediately adjacent to a curb designated by appropriate sign or marking for the loading or unloading of materials or merchandise. 
Moped. The term "moped" shall be taken to mean any pedal bicycle which is equipped with a pedal-activated helper motor with a manufacturer's certified maximum rating of one (1.0) brake horsepower which produces only ordinary pedaling speeds up to a maximum of twenty (20) miles per hour. 
Parking meter zone. The term "parking meter zone" shall be taken to mean an area immediately adjacent to a curb, which the parking of vehicles is controlled, regulated and inspected with the aid of timing devices or meters, commonly known as parking meters. 
Passenger zone. The term "passenger zone" shall mean an area immediately adjacent to a curb designated by appropriate sign or marking for the loading or unloading of passengers by vehicles. 
Public car. The term "public car" shall mean any motor vehicle engaged in transporting passengers for hire that conforms to Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards for such vehicle and is equipped for operation on all public streets, roads, and interstate and other highways; however, such term shall not be construed to include buses, taxicabs or low speed vehicles. 
Taxistand. The word "taxistand" shall be taken to mean an area immediately adjacent to a curb designated by appropriate sign or marking for the parking of taxis and for the loading or unloading of passengers by taxis. 
(Code 1975, § 33-1; Ord. No. 1978-71, § 1, 11-21-78; Ord. No. 2004-135, § 1, 11-23-04) 
Cross reference— Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 19-2. - Drivers of governmental vehicles not excepted from chapter. 
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the driver of any vehicle owned by or used in the service of the United States government, this state, county or city, and it shall be unlawful for any such driver to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise permitted in this chapter or by state statute. 
(Code 1975, § 33-6) 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2.  
Sec. 19-3. - Authority of police chief to make special traffic regulations. 
The chief of police, with the approval of the mayor, shall have authority to make, promulgate and enforce special or emergency traffic regulations, including the designation of one-way streets, dangerous intersections where traffic shall be required to slow or stop, school zones, safety zones, parking meter zones and regulations as to parking, nonparking and time limits for parking and cause to be erected or placed signs, signals, and other traffic-control devices and restrict parking for the purpose of enforcing the same. Any person failing or refusing to obey any such regulation shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1975, § 33-9) 
Cross reference— Police department, § 25-16 et seq.  
Sec. 19-4. - Removal of vegetation obstructing view of traffic. 
Every bush, tree, plant or other article which obstructs clear view of traffic is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and the city engineer is hereby empowered and directed to remove or trim the same to alleviate the nuisance, without notice. 
(Code 1975, § 33-10)  
Sec. 19-5. - Unnecessary use of signaling devices. 
No signaling device shall be sounded except as a necessary warning of danger, and then only by giving a short blast and not more often than is necessary. 
(Code 1975, § 33-13)  
Sec. 19-6. - Riding on outside of vehicle. 
No person shall ride on the outside of any vehicle nor anywhere except within the body thereof. 
(Code 1975, § 33-14)  
Sec. 19-7. - Boarding or alighting from moving vehicles prohibited. 
No person shall board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is in motion and in accordance with section 19-243. 
(Code 1975, § 33-15)  
Sec. 19-8. - Opening doors of vehicles. 
No person shall open the door of a vehicle unless and until such movement can be made with reasonable safety. 
(Code 1975, § 33-16)  
Sec. 19-9. - Possession of vehicle without manufacturer's trade number prohibited. 
No person shall have in his possession any motor vehicle on which the manufacturer's trade or distinguishing number or identification mark has been removed, defaced, covered or destroyed. Any person having in his possession any motor vehicle so defaced shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor; provided, that anyone acquiring in good faith a vehicle with numbers so mutilated shall be relieved of liability under this provision by reporting the circumstances to the police department upon discovery and making satisfactory provision for some other permanent means of identifying such vehicle. 
(Code 1975, § 33-18)  
Sec. 19-10. - Inspection of vehicles; enforcement of chapter. 
All officers of the police department or other officials of the city may stop and examine and inspect any vehicles which they may have reasonable cause to believe to be violating any of the terms of this chapter, and to require the vehicles to be measured and weighed, or such other examination as may be proper or necessary to be made and to compel immediate compliance with all the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1975, § 33-19) 
State Law reference— Inspection of vehicles, S.C. Code 1976, §§ 56-5-5310—56-5-5440.  
Sec. 19-11. - Powers, duties and jurisdiction of municipal court. 
Nothing contained in this chapter shall serve to prevent the municipal court of the city from exercising the powers, duties and jurisdiction conferred by state statutes and the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 33-20) 
State Law reference— Trial jurisdiction of municipal court with reference to state traffic regulations, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-6150.  
Sec. 19-12. - The passing of items to or from the occupant of a motor vehicle on a roadway. 
(1)  Intent of section. This section is intended to provide for the free flow of motor vehicle traffic on roadways in the city. The city council finds that persons who distribute any item to, receive any item from or exchange any item with the occupant of a motor vehicle upon a roadway present a threat to the free and safe flow of motor vehicle traffic. By this section, the city council intends to promote the health, safety and welfare of the citizens traveling by vehicle or on foot in the city. 
(2)  Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following definitions apply: 
(a)  Pass/passing. Distributing any item to, receiving any item from, or exchanging any item with the occupant of a motor vehicle that is located in a lane of travel the roadway. 
(b)  Roadway. All public roads open to motorized vehicles within the city. This definition excludes private roads and private property. This definition also excludes areas in which parking is permitted in the city. 
(c)  Item. Any physical object. 
(3)  Prohibition on roadways. It shall be unlawful to violate any of the prohibitions set forth below in the city. 
(a)  No person shall knowingly distribute any item to, receive any item from, or exchange any item with the occupant of any motor vehicle when the vehicle is located in a lane of travel on the roadway. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to the distribution, receipt or exchange of any item with the occupant of a motor vehicle on private property or in a permitted parking area. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to any law enforcement officer acting in the scope of his/her official duty. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to the distribution, receipt or exchange of any item with the occupant of a motor vehicle located in the roadway in order to assist the occupant after a motor vehicle accident, with a disabled motor vehicle or where the occupant is experiencing a medical emergency. 
(4)  Severability. If any provision of this section is declared invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, the remaining provisions shall be severable and shall continue in full force and effect. 
( Ord. No. 2015-092, § 1, 8-18-15 )  
Secs. 19-13—19-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 19-26. - Applicability of federal regulations on federal property under city jurisdiction. 
Whoever within or upon any of the places now existing or acquired hereafter by the federal government within the corporate limits of this municipality over which concurrent or proprietary jurisdiction is obtained, is guilty of any motor vehicle violation which, although not made punishable by any enactment of city council, would be punishable by the laws and regulations of the federal government in force thereon at the time of such violation, shall be guilty of a like offense and subject to a like punishment, provided that police jurisdiction is properly acquired under section 23-1-15, South Carolina Code of Laws 1976, and is not in conflict with the general penalty provision provided in section 1-16 of this Code. 
(Code 1975, § 33-197; Ord. No. 1977-37, § 1, 8-16-77)  
Secs. 19-27—19-35. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DEPARTMENT OF TRAFFIC AND TRANSPORTATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Department of administrative services, § 2-176 et seq.; department of public service, § 2-231 et seq.; department of special facilities, § 2-246 et seq.; fire department, § 13-26 et seq.; department of recreation, § 22-16 et seq.; department of parks, § 22-46 et seq.; department of planning and urban development, § 23-16 et seq.; police department, § 25-16 et seq. 
 
Sec. 19-36. - Creation. 
There is hereby established a department of traffic and transportation. 
(Code 1975, § 23-1; Ord. No. 1986-113, § 1, 9-23-86)  
Sec. 19-37. - Supervision of department by director of traffic and transportation. 
The department of traffic and transportation shall be under the direction and supervision of the director of traffic and transportation. 
(Code 1975, § 23-2)  
Sec. 19-38. - Qualification of director; appointment by mayor. 
The director of traffic and transportation shall be an engineering graduate in the field of traffic and transportation or a person who has a minimum of five (5) years' full-time employment in traffic engineering and planning. He shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of city council. 
(Code 1975, § 23-3; Ord. No. 1986-113, § 2, 9-23-86)  
Sec. 19-39. - Duties of director generally. 
The director of traffic and transportation shall plan the operation of traffic on the streets and public property of the city, conduct engineering investigations of traffic conditions, analyze traffic accidents and devise remedial measures, cooperate with other officers and agencies in developing ways and means of improving traffic conditions, and exercise any additional duties imposed on him by ordinances or resolutions of the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 23-4)  
Sec. 19-40. - Specific duties of director; approval by committee on public safety and traffic. 
Without limiting the general duties described in section 19-39, the director of traffic and transportation specifically shall have the power and responsibility, on the basis of engineering and traffic investigations: 
(1)  To determine the installation, timing and location of traffic-control devices and to provide for their maintenance and testing under actual traffic conditions; 
(2)  To determine the location of traffic signs, signals, buttons, markers and devices and to arrange for their installation, maintenance and protection; 
(3)  To determine locations of crosswalks, safety zones, parking and no-parking zones, curb loading zones, bus stops, bus stands, stands for common carrier vehicles transporting passengers, stop or yield intersections, play streets, skating zones and bicycle routes, and to install appropriate signs or signals to designate the same; 
(4)  To restrict or prohibit the movement or the direction of movement of all vehicles or certain vehicles at all hours or certain hours in specific areas, and to erect and maintain signs, signals, markers or devices to instruct or warn traffic; 
(5)  To plan, design and manage a comprehensive parking system in the city for both on-street parking spaces and off-street parking facilities in a manner that will facilitate the flow of traffic in the streets, minimize the number of nonresidential vehicles parking in residential neighborhoods and maximize the use of on-street spaces and city-owned and operated off-street facilities so as best to serve the public; to plan, design and manage the location and timing of on-street parking, utilizing meters, where required; to plan, manage and operate city-owned or operated off-street parking facilities with the use of meters, attendants or other measures and to set the hours of operation, the number, term of occupancy, location and size of spaces and to develop circulation within such facilities so as to maximize their use, and to make such changes in the management of operation of such facilities from time to time as the public need may dictate or as city council may direct; 
(6)  To mark roadways, curbs and sidewalks and install and maintain signs designating traffic lanes, one-way streets, angle-parking zones and directions in which pedestrian or vehicular traffic shall be required or prohibited to move; 
(7)  To determine areas in which traffic shall be required to maintain minimum speeds and areas in which traffic shall be allowed to travel at greater speed, or required to travel at lower speed, than the standards set in section 19-206, and to install and maintain appropriate signs marking the same; and 
(8)  When required by state statutes, to consult with and obtain any necessary approvals from the state highway department. 
(9)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this Code, and regardless of the number of streets upon which a parcel of property may abut, to regulate, limit or condition the number or location of curb cuts or points of vehicular access to streets within the city, both existing and proposed, in order (1) to provide a free, safe and efficient flow of traffic, vehicular and/or pedestrian, or (2) to assure protection to neighboring developments or residents from safety, noise or traffic hazards that may be, or are, created by proposed or existing vehicular accesses. The authority granted by this subsection shall be exercised in consultation with the technical review committee, after the director has taken into consideration factors concerning the width of the street where the access is to be regulated, the existence of sidewalks thereon, the distance of such access from vehicles utilizing the access and such intersections, the character of the neighborhood(s) served by the street where the access is located and such other factors as are reasonable and pertinent in effecting the intent of this provision. 
(Code 1975, § 23-5; Ord. No. 1980-108, §§ 1, 2, 9-23-80; Ord. No. 1986-113, § 3, 9-23-86)  
Sec. 19-41. - Cooperation of department with other departments. 
The department of transportation, the department of public service, the police department and other city departments shall work cooperatively in studies of accidents, traffic and highway improvement, and municipal planning and the records of the respective departments shall be available to each other for these purposes. 
(Code 1975, § 23-6)  
Secs. 19-42—19-55. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - ABANDONED VEHICLES 
 
Sec. 19-56. - Definition. 
As used in this article, an "abandoned vehicle" means a motor vehicle that is inoperable or left unattended in a legal parking space on a street or road in the city for a period of more than seven (7) days. 
(Code 1975, § 33-69.1(a); Ord. No. 1981-64, § 1, 10-27-81; Ord. No. 1996-223, § 1, 10-29-96) 
Cross reference— Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 19-57. - Notice of determination of abandonment to be placed on vehicle; removal by city upon failure of vehicle to be moved. 
Whenever the city determines that a vehicle is an abandoned vehicle a notice so stating shall be attached to the car in a prominent place. If the vehicle is not moved within twenty-four (24) hours it will be removed by the city. 
(Code 1975, § 33-69.1(b); Ord. No. 1981-64, § 1, 10-27-81)  
Sec. 19-58. - Notice to owner after removal. 
After removing a car pursuant to section 19-57, the department shall notify the registered owner of the vehicle giving the grounds for removal and the name of the garage or place where the vehicle is stored. If the vehicle is not registered in this state, the vehicle is stored. If the vehicle is not registered in this state, the department shall make a reasonable effort to notify the registered owner or any lienholder of the removal and the location of the vehicle. The department shall forward a copy of the notice to the owner or person in charge of the garage or place where the vehicle is stored. 
(Code 1975, § 33-69.1(c); Ord. No. 1981-64, § 1, 10-27-81)  
Secs. 19-59—19-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - ACCIDENTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to require accident reports, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-1360; accident reports, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-1270. 
 
Sec. 19-71. - Report of accident or collision required. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle involved in an accident or collision resulting in injury to or death of any person or damage to any vehicle driven or attended by a person or other device driven or attended by a person in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices moved by human power, immediately shall stop the vehicle at the scene of the accident or collision or as close to it as possible, but shall return to and in every event shall remain at the scene of the accident or collision until law enforcement arrives and he or she has given information and rendered aid consistent with what is required by South Carolina Code § 56-5-1230. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not be applicable when the accident or collision has been investigated at the scene by a police officer while such driver was present there at. 
(Code 1975, § 33-91; Ord. No. 2019-111 , § 1, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 19-72. - Supplemental reports may be required. 
The police department may require any driver of a vehicle involved in an accident to file supplemental reports whenever the original report is insufficient in the opinion of the police department. 
(Code 1975, § 33-93)  
Sec. 19-73. - Reports from witnesses may be required. 
The police department may require witnesses of accidents to render reports to the police department. 
(Code 1975, § 33-94)  
Secs. 19-74—19-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - BICYCLES, MOTORCYCLES AND CERTAIN VEHICLES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2014-68, § 1, adopted May 13, 2014, retitled former Art. V from "Bicycles, Motorcycles and Toy Vehicles" to "Bicycles, Motorcycles and Certain Vehicles." 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2009-236, § 2, adopted Nov. 16, 2009, repealed the former div. 1, §§ 19-91, 19-92, and enacted a new div. 1 as set out herein. The former div. 1 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1975, §§ 22-169 and 22-170. 
 
Sec. 19-91. - Regulation of use of roller skates, in-line skates, toy scooters, coasters, motorized toy vehicles, and motorized scooters. 
(a)  Roller skates, in-line-skates, toy scooters, coasters, and motorized toy vehicles. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person upon roller skates, in-line skates, or any coaster, toy scooter, motorized toy vehicle or other similar device to: 
a.  Go upon any roadway designed for vehicular traffic posted more than twenty-five (25) miles per hour except while crossing a street at a crosswalk; 
b.  Use these devices in a city-owned or leased parking garage or surface lot; 
c.  Unless designated otherwise, use these devices upon a city-owned or leased athletic field or tennis court; 
d.  Unless designated otherwise, go upon any sidewalk or roadway in a school overlay zone or in a commercially zoned area on the peninsula as delineated on the zoning map of the city and as the zoning map may hereafter be amended by the ordinances of the city; 
e.  Use these devices in a reckless manner. Persons operating these devices on a sidewalk shall exercise due care for the safety of others using the sidewalk and yield the right-of-way to pedestrians; or 
f.  Operate these devices in a manner which causes damage to public or private property. 
(2)  For purposes of this section a motorized toy vehicle shall mean any toy vehicle which is powered by a twelve-volt battery and when operated at full throttle does not exceed fifteen (15) miles per hour. Any scooter, motorized toy vehicle, coaster, or other similar device which can be operated at a speed greater than fifteen (15) miles per hour shall not be operated on a public sidewalk. 
(b)  Motorized scooters. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motorized scooter, other than a motor scooter owned by that individual: 
a.  Upon any roadway designed for vehicular traffic; 
2.  Upon any public sidewalk; 
c.  In a city-owned or leased parking garage or surface lot; 
d.  Upon a city-owned or leased athletic field or tennis court; 
(2)  It shall be unlawful to use a motorized scooter on private property in a reckless manner. Persons operating these devices on private property shall exercise due care for the safety of others using the property and yield the right-of-way to pedestrians or other vehicular traffic. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful to rent, offer, or make available a motor scooter for the use on a public right-of-way. 
(4)  Any motor scooter left physically unattended on the public property may be removed and held by the city for twenty-four (24) hours. A confiscated motorized scooter shall be released upon proof of ownership and payment of a forty-five dollar ($45.00) fee for removal and storage. Motorizes scooters held for over twenty-four (24) hours may be disposed of by discarding, donation, auction, or any other manner deemed appropriate by the city. The city shall bear no responsibility to a motorized scooter owner or operator for loss of or damage to a confiscated motor scooter, including any chain or locking mechanism, in its enforcement of this section. 
(5)  For purposes of this section a motorized scooter shall mean a two-wheeled device that has handlebars, a floorboard that is designed to be stood upon when riding, and is powered by a motor. 
(c)  Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction, shall be subject to a maximum fine of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. No. 2009-236, § 1, 11-16-09; Ord. No. 2010-231, § 1, 8-17-10; Ord. No. 2010-271, § 1, 12-21-10; Ord. No. 2013-35, § 1, 3-12-13; Ord. No. 2014-43, § 1, 3-25-14; Ord. No. 2019-104 , § 1, 10-22-19)  
Sec. 19-92. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2019-104 , § 2, adopted Oct. 22, 2019, repealed former § 19-92 in its etirety which pertained to the operation of motorized scooters and derived from Ord. No. 2018-116 , § 2, adopted Sept. 18, 2018.  
Sec. 19-93. - Skateboard regulations on the peninsula. 
(a)  The city shall create a committee containing community and neighborhood representatives affected by this section to study, review, and comment on this and any future skateboard ordinance amendments. 
(b)  The provisions of this section are applicable to the use of skateboards within the municipal limits of the city. 
(c)  Every person riding a skateboard upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by the laws of this state declaring rules of the road applicable to vehicles or by the traffic regulations of this city applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except as to special regulations in this section and except as to those provisions of laws and regulations which by their nature can have no application. 
(d)  Every skateboarder operating a skateboard upon a roadway shall ride as near to the right side of the roadway as practicable. A skateboarder may, but is not required to, ride on the shoulder of the roadway in order to comply with the requirements of this subsection. A skateboarder may ride in a lane other than the right-hand lane if only one (1) lane is available that permits the skateboarder to continue on his intended route. 
(e)  A driver of a motor vehicle must at all times maintain a safe operating distance between the motor vehicle and a skateboard. 
(f)  A skateboard may not be used to carry more persons than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
(g)  Footwear shall be worn at all times while operating a skateboard. 
(h)  A person may not operate a skateboard while intoxicated or consuming alcohol. 
(i)  It is unlawful to harass, taunt, or maliciously throw an object at or in the direction of any person riding a skateboard. 
(j)  A person riding upon a skateboard may not attach it or himself to a vehicle, or any device which is used or may be used for propulsion. 
(k)  Skateboarders must be visible from both a minimum distance of five hundred (500) feet and a height of at least three (3) feet through the use of reflective clothing, lights, or other visible gear. 
(l)  Hand signals. A skateboarder shall indicate a right turn by extending the left arm upward, by raising the left arm to the square. A skateboarder shall indicate a left turn by extending the left arm horizontally. A skateboarder shall indicate stopping or decreasing speed by extending the left arm or the right arm downward. 
(m)  A skateboarder must be able to brake within a five-foot stopping distance. 
(n)  It shall be unlawful for any person upon a skateboard or other similar device to: 
(1)  Use these devices in a city-owned or leased parking garage or surface lot; 
(2)  Unless designated otherwise, use these devices upon a city-owned or leased athletic field or tennis court; or 
(3)  Operate these devices in a manner which causes damage to public or private property. 
(o)  The use of skateboards is prohibited on the streets and sidewalks identified on Exhibit A to Ordinance No. 2014-43 which is set out below. 
(Ord. No. 2013-35, § 2, 3-12-13; Ord. No. 2014-43, § 2, 3-25-14; Ord. No. 2018-116 , § 1, 9-18-18) 
Note— Formerly numbered as § 19-72. 
  
Secs. 19-94—19-100. - Reserved.

Sec. 19-101. - Registration. 
The owner or operator of every bicycle operated or furnished for operation or use, or which is used by either the owner or any other person on the streets or public places in the city may cause such bicycle to be registered at the police department, giving the make, model, number and such other description as may be feasible, on a form to be furnished by the police department. Bicycle registrations shall be valid for a period of three (3) years from the date of registration.

There shall be issued for each bicycle registered, as provided in this division, a decal license tag containing a number and other appropriate identification information. This decal license tag shall be attached to the bicycle for which it was issued. 
(Code 1975, § 33-158; Ord. No. 2010-231, § 2, 8-17-10)
