Sec. 19-278. - Parking limitations in districts. 
Upon designation by council of a permit parking district, the director of traffic and transportation shall designate within the district an adequate number of on-street parking spaces to reasonably ensure sufficient parking to residents of the district. In such district, appropriate signs giving notice of the designation of the district as a permit parking district will be posted restricting all parking beyond the time specified on such signs, except parking by the holders of permits for that district granted under this division. 
(Code 1975, § 33-201; Ord. No. 1979-49, § 1, 8-21-79)  
Sec. 19-279. - Obedience to parking regulations. 
No such permit shall entitle a vehicle to park on yellow lines, bus stops, loading zones, fire hydrants, or other prohibited zones, nor shall such vehicle be exempt from regulations governing the use of metered spaces. 
(Code 1975, § 33-204; Ord. No. 1979-49, § 1, 8-21-79)  
Sec. 19-280. - Parking permit violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Provide false information on an application for a permit; 
(2)  Reproduce a parking permit: 
(3)  Transfer a permit to any vehicle other than the one designated on the original application unless a new application has been submitted to the parking ticket revenue collections division containing the amended information; or 
(4)  Display an unauthorized decal. 
(b)  Any person who violates the provisions of this subsection shall be subject to a penalty of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
( Ord. No. 2017-134, § 7, 10-24-17 )  
Secs. 19-281—19-290. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - TRAFFIC CITATIONS 
 
Sec. 19-291. - Issuance of traffic citations. 
A police officer or parking enforcement officer finding any vehicle parked, standing or stopped in violation of any city ordinance or state law may, in lieu of immediately issuing a summons to its owner or driver, affix in a conspicuous place on said vehicle a traffic citation requiring the owner or driver to post a specified bond within forty-eight (48) hours at a specified location within the city. 
(Code 1975, § 33-83)  
Sec. 19-292. - Consequences of failure to comply with parking citation. 
(a)  The parking citation authorized by section 19-291 shall contain a warning that if the fine required by the citation is not posted within thirty (30) days, it shall be increased by an additional specified amount and that failure to comply with the requirements of the citation shall result in the issuance of a summons. 
(b)  Any vehicle parked on any street or other public property, whether in an authorized or unauthorized zone, which is found to be the subject of forty-five dollars ($45.00) or more past due on outstanding parking citations is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. The fee for immobilization and impoundment shall be that amount set forth by city council, as amended from time to time. 
(c)  Any vehicle identified as a public nuisance may be impounded and/or immobilized by the city. The city may also give authorization to a commercial towing or wrecker service to tow the vehicle away to store in a safe place until claimed by the owner. The fee for immobilization and impoundment shall be that amount set forth by city council, as amended from time to time. 
(d)  Unless an approved payment agreement has been signed by all parties, no vehicle shall be released to the owner until all outstanding parking citation charges, as well as towing and storage charges or booting charges and missing equipment costs, are paid and until satisfactory proof of ownership has been demonstrated. 
(Code 1975, § 33-84; Ord. No. 1977-9, § 1, 2-22-77; Ord. No. 2013-41, § 1, 4-23-13; Ord. No. 2016-027, § 3, 2-9-16 )  
Sec. 19-293. - Restrictions on cancellation or solicitation of cancellation of traffic citation or summons. 
No person shall cancel or solicit the cancellation of any traffic citation or summons. The judge or associate judge of the municipal court shall have sole authority to cancel, void or dismiss any traffic citation or traffic summons. 
(Code 1975, § 33-85)  
Secs. 19-294—19-305. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - PARADES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 19-306. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the following meanings: 
Parade is any parade, march, picket line, demonstration, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, including the sidewalk area thereof, park or other public place in the city. 
Parade permit is a permit as required by this section. 
(Code 1975, § 33-180) 
Cross reference— Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 19-307. - Driving through parades. 
No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade when such vehicles or persons are in motion or conspicuously designated as a parade, except that this portion shall not apply to single file parades on the sidewalk areas of the city, where vehicular traffic and those constituting the parade shall be required to obey all traffic-control signals unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(Code 1975, § 33-181)  
Sec. 19-308. - Parking on parade route. 
The chief of police shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict parking of vehicles along a street or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade. The chief of police shall post signs to such effect, and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. No person shall be liable for parking on a street unposted in violation of this section. 
(Code 1975, § 33-182)  
Sec. 19-309. - Obstructing or interfering with parades. 
No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct, impede or interfere with any parade or parade assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade. 
(Code 1975, § 33-183)  
Sec. 19-310. - Hours for conducting parade restricted. 
No permit shall be granted for a parade to convene before 8:00 a.m. or terminate after 8:00 p.m. 
(Code 1975, § 33-189)  
Sec. 19-311. - Threats to safety. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to brandish a firearm, knife, flag pole, metal or wood pole, bat, staff, golf club, sign post, or other similar solid wood or metal object while participating in or attending a parade as defined in this article. 
(b)  For purposes of this article, brandish shall mean to wave or flourish menacingly, to display ostentatiously, threateningly, angrily or aggressively. 
( Ord. No. 2018-089 , § 2, 7-17-18)  
Secs. 19-312—19-325. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17. 
 
Sec. 19-326. - Required; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade, consisting of fifty (50) or more persons, unless a parade permit shall have been obtained from the chief of police. Any person engaging in any parade for which a parade permit has been issued shall not violate any of the conditions or provisions of such permit. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions, 
(2)  Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities, providing such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities, and 
(3)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Code 1975, § 33-184; Ord. No. 2005-606, § 1, 10-18-05)  
Sec. 19-327. - Application; filing. 
(a)  A person seeking issuance of a parade permit shall file an application with the chief of police on forms provided by such officer. 
(b)  An application for a parade permit shall be filed with the chief of police not less than three (3) days nor more than thirty (30) days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. 
(Code 1975, § 33-185)  
Sec. 19-328. - Form and contents of application; late applications. 
(a)  The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade. 
(2)  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization and of the authorizing and responsible head of such organization. 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman and who will be responsible for its conduct. 
(4)  The date when the parade is to be conducted. 
(5)  The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point. 
(6)  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade; the type of animals and description of the vehicles. 
(7)  The hours when such parade will start and terminate. 
(8)  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed. 
(9)  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade. 
(10)  The time at which such units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such area or areas. 
(11)  The interval of space to be maintained between units of such parade. 
(12)  If the parade is designed to be held by and on behalf of, or for any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the chief of police a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf. 
(13)  Any additional information which the chief of police shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should issue. 
(b)  The chief of police, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider any application hereunder which is filed less than three (3) days before the date such parade is proposed to be conducted. 
(Code 1975, § 33-186)  
Sec. 19-329. - Notice of rejection. 
The chief of police shall act upon the application for a parade permit within two (2) days after the filing thereof. If the chief of police disapproves the application, he shall mail to the applicant within two (2) days after the date upon which the application was filed a notice of his action, stating the reasons for his denial of the permit. 
(Code 1975, § 33-187)  
Sec. 19-330. - Standards for issuance. 
The chief of police shall issue a permit as provided for hereunder when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic, pedestrian and vehicular, contiguous to its route. 
(2)  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city properly to police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city. 
(3)  The concentration of persons, animals, and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of areas contiguous to such assembly areas. 
(4)  The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment enroute to a fire. 
(5)  The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or to create a disturbance. 
(6)  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously, without unreasonable delays enroute and without passing by any location more than once. 
(7)  If the parade is to be solely on the sidewalk areas of the city, the parade shall be in single file only of persons participating, with no animals, vehicles or other nonhuman objects except reasonably sized signs individually carried in the line of procession. 
(Code 1975, § 33-188)  
Sec. 19-331. - Appeal to council upon denial. 
Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of a parade permit to city council. The appeal shall be taken within forty-eight (48) hours after notice. The city council shall act upon the appeal at its next regularly scheduled meeting, but not later than twenty (20) days from the time of receipt of the appeal. 
(Code 1975, § 33-190)  
Sec. 19-332. - Contents. 
Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  Starting time. 
(2)  Minimum speed. 
(3)  Maximum speed. 
(4)  Maximum interval of space to be maintained between units of the parade. 
(5)  The portion of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade. 
(6)  The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof. 
(7)  Such other information as the chief of police shall find necessary for the enforcement of this division. 
(Code 1975, § 33-191)  
Sec. 19-333. - Alternate. 
The chief of police, in denying an application for a parade permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a day, at a time, or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall within two (2) days after notice of the action of the chief of police file a written notice of acceptance with the chief of police. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have the effect of a parade permit under this article. 
(Code 1975, § 33-192)  
Sec. 19-334. - Notification of city officials upon issuance. 
Immediately upon the issuance of a parade permit the chief of police shall send a copy thereof to the following: 
(1)  The mayor. 
(2)  The fire chief. 
(3)  The general manager or responsible head of each public transportation utility, the regular routes of whose vehicles will be affected by the route of the proposed parade. 
(4)  The director of traffic and transportation. 
(Code 1975, § 33-193)  
Sec. 19-335. - Revocation. 
The chief of police shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued hereunder upon the violation of the standards for issuance as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1975, § 33-194)  
Sec. 19-336. - Possession by parade chairman. 
The parade chairman or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade. 
(Code 1975, § 33-195)  
Sec. 19-337. - Compliance with conditions. 
A permittee hereunder shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
(Code 1975, § 33-196)  
Secs. 19-338—19-350. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - PEDESTRIANS 
 
Sec. 19-351. - Obedience of pedestrians to bridge and railroad signals. 
(a)  No pedestrian shall enter or remain on any bridge or approach thereto beyond the bridge signal, gate or barrier after a bridge operation signal indication has been given. 
(b)  No pedestrian shall pass through, around, over or under any crossing gate or barrier at a railroad grade crossing or bridge while such gate or barrier is closed or is being opened or closed. 
(Code 1975, § 33-87)  
Secs. 19-352—19-365. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XI. - TRAFFIC-CONTROL SIGNS, SIGNALS AND MARKINGS[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
State Law reference— Local traffic-control devices generally, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-910. 
 
Sec. 19-366. - Traffic-control signal legend. 
Whenever traffic is controlled by traffic-control signals exhibiting different colored lights successively one at a time or with arrows, the following colors only shall be used, and such lights shall indicate and apply to drivers of vehicles and pedestrians as follows: 
(1)  Green alone means that: 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing the signal may proceed straight through or turn right or left unless a sign at such place prohibits either such turn, but vehicular traffic, including vehicles turning right or left, shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles and to pedestrians lawfully within the intersection or an adjacent crosswalk at the time such signal is exhibited, and 
b.  Vehicular traffic facing a green arrow signal shown alone or in combination with another indication may cautiously enter the intersection only to make the movement indicated by such arrow, or such other movement as is permitted by other indications shown at the same time. Such vehicular traffic shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians lawfully within an adjacent crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the intersection, and 
c.  Pedestrians facing the signal may proceed across the roadway within any marked or unmarked crosswalk. 
(2)  Yellow alone when shown following the green signal or in combination with the green signal means that: 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing the signal is thereby warned that the red or stop signal will be exhibited immediately thereafter and such vehicular traffic shall not enter or be crossing the intersection when the red or stop signal is exhibited, and 
b.  Pedestrians facing such signal are thereby advised that there is insufficient time to cross the roadway and any pedestrian then starting to cross shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles. 
(3)  Red alone means that: 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing the signal shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, if none, then before entering the intersection and shall remain stopped until an indication to proceed is shown, except that when a sign is in place at the intersection permitting a right turn, vehicular traffic facing a steady red signal may cautiously enter the intersection to make the turn indicated by such sign after stopping. Such vehicular traffic shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians lawfully within an adjacent crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the intersection, and 
b.  No pedestrian facing such signal shall enter the roadway unless he can do so safely and without interfering with any vehicular traffic. 
(4)  Red with green arrow means that: 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing such signal may cautiously enter the intersection only to make the movement indicated by such arrow but shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians lawfully within a crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the intersection, and 
b.  No pedestrian facing such signal shall enter the roadway unless he can do so safely and without interfering with any vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1975, § 33-22) 
State Law reference— Similar state law, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-970.  
Sec. 19-367. - Unauthorized painting or marking of street or sidewalk. 
No unauthorized person shall paint or mark any sidewalk, curb or roadway. 
(Code 1975, § 33-26)  
Sec. 19-368. - Offense of disregarding a traffic control sign on a restricted street. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a truck or other commercial vehicle having an overall length of more than twenty (20) feet that is engaged in making a commercial delivery or pick up of goods, products, equipment or personal property on any street marked with signage stating "No Trucks Except Local Delivery." 
This provision shall not apply to any such truck or commercial vehicle making a commercial delivery or pick up to a physical location on any such restricted street, provided that the operator of such commercial vehicle can show documents or other evidence of the need to make a delivery on a restricted street and there is no alternative route available for such delivery. 
(Ord. No. 2003-108, § 1, 11-12-03)  
Secs. 19-369—19-380. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XII. - VEHICLE EQUIPMENT AND CONDITION  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 19-381. - Safe loading and construction required. 
No one shall drive a vehicle which is so loaded or constructed as to cause delay, accident or injury to any other vehicle or users of the public streets. 
(Code 1975, § 33-113)  
Sec. 19-382. - Lighting equipment. 
Every vehicle shall be equipped with and display such lamps and reflectors as may be required by state law. 
(Code 1975, § 33-14) 
State Law reference— Lights on motor vehicles, S.C. Code 1976, §§ 56-5-4480—56-5-4690.  
Sec. 19-383. - Brakes. 
Every vehicle shall be equipped with such brakes as may be required by state law. 
(Code 1975, § 33-116) 
State Law reference— Brakes, S.C. Code 1976, §§ 56-5-4850—56-5-4900.  
Sec. 19-384. - Horns required. 
All motor vehicles shall be provided at all times with a suitable horn, the signal of which shall not conflict with the signal device used by the fire department, police department, and other emergency vehicles and ambulances, and shall comply with state law. 
(Code 1975, § 33-117) 
State Law reference— Horns, sirens, etc., S.C. Code 1976, §§ 56-5-4950—56-5-4980.  
Sec. 19-385. - Siren, exhaust and compression whistles prohibited. 
Sirens or exhaust and motor compression whistles or bells shall be unlawful on motor vehicles. 
(Code 1975, § 33-118)  
Secs. 19-386—19-390. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - SIZE, WEIGHT AND LOAD[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
State Law reference— Size, weight and load, S.C. Code 1976, §§ 56-5-4010—56-5-4230. 
 
Sec. 19-391. - Weight of vehicles. 
No vehicles operated on the streets of this city shall exceed in gross weight the maximum allowances applicable to such vehicle under Article 33, Chapter 5, Title 56 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina, as amended. 
(Code 1975, § 33-122)  
Sec. 19-392. - Permit for excess size or weight or other nonconforming acts. 
(a)  The city engineer may, in his discretion, upon application in writing and good cause being shown therefor to the effect that it is in the public interest, issue special written permits authorizing applicants to operate or move vehicles or combinations of vehicles of a size and weight exceeding the maximum specified in this article upon any city street. The application shall specifically describe the vehicle and load and the particular streets involved. For good cause, the city engineer may reject such application, or may limit or prescribe conditions of operation, and may require such undertaking, insurance or other security as he may deem necessary to compensate for injury to any street or road structure or for personal injury or property damages to persons and vehicles operating on such streets. 
(b)  Every such permit shall be carried in the vehicle or combination of vehicles to which it refers and shall be open to inspection by any police officer or other officer of the city. A person violating any terms or conditions of the permit shall be punished, upon conviction, as provided in section 1-16. 
(Code 1975, § 33-123) 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17.  
Sec. 19-393. - Vehicles in tow. 
All vehicles having another in tow must display a red flag in the day and a red light at night, both front and rear, and the tow line must not exceed fifteen (15) feet in length. 
(Code 1975, § 33-124)  
ARTICLE XIII. - NONCONSENSUAL TOWING OF VEHICLES 
 
Sec. 19-394. - Findings of council. 
City council finds in many instances when a vehicle is towed from private property without the owners knowledge or consent that vehicle owners are at the complete mercy of the tow truck operators and as such, are subjected to instances of price gouging and other overly stringent requirements for the return of their vehicles. 
City council finds that due to the unique parking arrangements in some downtown parking lots where city staff operates parking lots on leased private land many citizens and visitors alike are frequently confused over which lots are private or public; and 
City council finds that there is often inadequate signage, indicating the times when a car may be towed or of the price of a nonconsensual tow thereby inadequately apprising the public of the maximum risks of imprudent parking; and 
City council finds that owners or operators of towed vehicles believe their cars have been stolen and that the police department must respond, and to release their cars, usually late at night, owners must go to one location to pay for the cost of towing and another location to actually take possession of their cars. Car owners or operators can only retrieve their cars after paying cash. This scenario coupled with storage sites that are located on the outskirts of the city and in desolate locations tend to place the reluctant patrons in a dangerous situation; and 
Further, city council intends to exercise its police powers to ensure that the public security, general welfare, health and order of the city are adequately protected from price gouging and unscrupulous towing carriers. 
(Ord. No. 1997-116, § 1, 3-25-97)  
Sec. 19-395. - Definitions. 
Commercial property means any real property where the primary use is for office, retail, wholesale, restaurant, education, or service for hire uses and where parking is available for property owners, occupants, or their patrons, clients, or customers. The term also applies to parking lots for which hourly or other periodic charges are made for the right to park on the premises, regardless of whether there are structures on the property. The term does not include property having primarily a residential use, with the exception of multiple dwelling units. 
Deliver means placing a towed motor vehicle in the actual possession of the owner, authorized operator, or authorized agent of the owner. 
Motor vehicle means any motorized vehicle which is capable of moving on the public ways of the City of Charleston. 
Nonconsensual tow means a tow authorized or directed by a person other than the vehicle owner, authorized operator, or authorized agent of the owner. A nonconsensual tow includes, but is not limited to: (1) a private property tow; (2) any tow performed contrary to the specific direction of the vehicle owner, authorized operator, or authorized agent of the owner; or (3) any tow performed without disclosure of the rates and charges to be assessed. This definition shall not apply to nonconsensual tows that occur as a result of a vehicle repossession by a lien holder having title to the vehicle. 
Private property tow means the towing of a motor vehicle from private property at the request of the property owner. 
Towing carrier means any person, company, partnership, employees, engaged in the business of towing vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 1997-116, § 1, 3-25-97; Ord. No. 1997-161, § 1, 5-13-97; Ord. No. 2008-121, § 1, 9-9-08)  
Sec. 19-396. - Towing permit required. 
(a)  No towing carrier engaged in the business of performing nonconsensual tows shall operate within the corporate limits of the city without obtaining a towing permit from the department of traffic and transportation. The application for a permit shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and complete street address, city, state, zip code, and telephone number of the applicant, and the trade name under which the operation shall be conducted. A post office box is acceptable as an address so long as a physical address is also provided: 
a.  If the applicant is a corporation: 
1.  A statement of that fact and the name of the state in which it is incorporated; 
2.  The location of its principal office in the State of South Carolina and the names of its directors and officers; 
3.  A copy of its articles of incorporation or charter; and 
4.  A copy of its certificate of assumed trade name, if any. 
b.  If the applicant is a limited liability company, the name, title, and business address of each member. 
c.  If the applicant is a partnership, the name, title, and business address of each partner. 
(2)  A list with a complete description of the equipment to be operated. 
(3)  A statement that applicant is familiar with the rules contained in this article and will comply with them. 
(4)  A statement whether or not the towing carrier will provide storage for towed motor vehicles. If storage is provided, a complete address and phone number, if any, and description of the storage facilities shall be included. 
(5)  Every application must be signed by the applicant or its attorney or agent with the complete address and telephone number of the attorney or agent. 
(6)  A statement acknowledging the books and records concerning the towing and storage operations of any towing carrier shall be made available upon request during normal business hours to authorized personnel of the department of traffic and transportation. 
(7)  Certificates of insurance, from an insurer authorized to do business in the State of South Carolina, establishing proof of garage liability coverage of no less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). Further, towing carriers shall provide proof of garage keepers liability insurance covering customer's vehicles in an amount no less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) dollars per vehicle. 
(8)  All written authorization(s), if applicable, indicating the properties or lots from which the towing carrier is authorized to conduct nonconsensual tows. 
(b)  A towing carrier who operates in violation of this section shall be subject to a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or serve a term not exceeding thirty (30) days in jail, or both. 
(c)  The cost of the permit shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per tow truck or as otherwise set by city council from time to time. This license shall be renewable on February 1st of every year at the same rate of ten dollars ($10.00) per year. Any license under this article may be denied, suspended or revoked for violating any section of this chapter or Code. 
(Ord. No. 1997-116, § 1, 3-25-97; Ord. No. 1997-161, § 1, 5-13-97; Ord. No. 2004-05, § 3, 2-13-04)  
Sec. 19-397. - Tow record/invoice. 
Towing carriers shall use a tow record/invoice form for all non-consensual tows, which form shall contain the information shown in Appendix A to Ord. No. 1997-116. Towing carriers shall complete all applicable portions of the tow record/invoice form for each nonconsensual tow. The tow record/invoice shall be a multiple copy form, the copies of which shall be distributed as follows: The towing carrier shall retain the copy bearing all required original signatures for authorization and delivery. The towing carrier shall deliver a copy to the vehicle owner, authorized operator, or authorized agent of the owner at the time of delivery of the towed motor vehicle and payment of towing charges. 
(Ord. No. 1997-116, § 1, 3-25-97)

Sec. 19-398. - Marking of towing vehicles. 
No towing carrier shall operate any tow truck, owned or leased, upon the public ways of the City of Charleston without first marking or affixing, in a permanent manner, on each side of the tow truck, the towing carrier's name, address and telephone number, which markings shall also comply with applicable safety regulations. The use of magnetic signs are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 1997-116, § 1, 3-25-97)  
Sec. 19-399. - Towing from private property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to charge for the removal of any motor vehicle from commercial property without authorization from the owner of the motor vehicle or of the city, except under the following circumstances. 
(1)  The property owner has posted the property with signs. Each sign face shall be at least six (6) square feet. 
(2)  The posted signs were in place, clearly visible and legible to any driver approaching any point of ingress to the property where parking is prohibited or restricted at the time the vehicle was parked; and 
(3)  The posted signs contain a clear warning that violators' vehicles will be towed, at the vehicle owner's expense, the telephone number to call and the address where release of the towed vehicle may be obtained. 
(4)  All signage must be approved by the director of the department of traffic and transportation. 
(5)  The signage requirements in this article are exempt from the requirements for signage contained in the City of Charleston Zoning Ordinance; the requirements in this article shall prevail. 
(b)  The owner of the vehicle towed from commercially zoned private property shall be responsible for paying all applicable towing and storage charges provided that the private property owner has complied with all of the requirements contained in subsection (a) above. If a vehicle is towed as a result of a property owner's request and the property owner has not complied with the requirements of subsection (a) above, or if the vehicle is shown to have been legally parked, the property owner shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and may, in the discretion of the municipal judge as provided in S.C. Code 1976, § 14-25-75, be subject to reimburse the owner of the vehicle for all towing and storage charges which the owner of the vehicle paid. 
(c)  Before towing a vehicle from commercially zoned private property without authorization from the vehicle owner, the tow truck operator shall obtain from the property owner a written authorization which shall set forth the name and signature of the property owner, unless, such authorization has been previously filed pursuant to section 19-396(a)(8) above. 
(d)  Any towing carrier performing a nonconsensual tow, shall within thirty (30) minutes of the removal, telephone the police department to verbally report the tow by providing the applicable information on the tow record/invoice form described in section 19-397 above. Any towing operator which fails to give such notice within one hour of the time the vehicle was towed shall not be entitled to any compensation for the towing and storing operation and shall deliver it upon request. 
(e)  Any towing carrier performing nonconsensual tows pursuant to Article XIII, Nonconsensual Towing of Vehicles, shall remain staffed and ready to comply with a vehicle owner's request to release his/her vehicle twenty-four (24) hours per day, seven (7) days per week, three hundred sixty-five (365) days per year. 
(Ord. No. 1997-116, § 1, 3-25-97; Ord. No. 2008-121, § 2, 9-9-08; Ord. No. 2016-150, § 1, 11-22-16 )  
Sec. 19-400. - Maximum charge for nonconsensual tow. 
(a)  The maximum rate that may be charged for a nonconsensual tow of a vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating of less than ten thousand (10,000) pounds shall be no more than one hundred fifty (150) per cent of the city's most recent franchise towing fee for towing on city streets, which shall include charges for all services rendered including, but not limited to, hookup fees, gate fees, and all other services rendered in performing such private property tow, except as stated elsewhere in this section. 
(b)  If the owner, authorized operator, or authorized agent of the owner of a motor vehicle which is parked without authorization on private property attempts to retrieve said vehicle before removal of the motor vehicle from said private property, the maximum release fee (drop charge) shall not exceed fifty per cent (50) of the maximum fee allowed in subsection (a) above. In such circumstances, the owner, authorized operator, or authorized agent of the owner of a motor vehicle so parked may offer payment of the towing carrier's drop charge, and if so offered before removal of the motor vehicle to be towed, the towing carrier shall immediately accept such payment and immediately thereafter deliver the motor vehicle without further transportation or handling. 
(c)  If dollies are required and used to perform a nonconsensual tow, the maximum additional amount that may be charged shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(d)  The maximum storage amount that may be charged for a vehicle that has been towed as a result of a nonconsensual tow and that has remained on the tow lot for more than two (2) hours shall be no more than six dollars ($6.00) for the first twenty four hour period and fifteen dollars ($15.00) during any twenty-four (24) hour period of storage after the vehicle has been on the lot for the first twenty-four (24) hours. 
(e)  A fee in an amount not to exceed ten dollars ($10.00) may be charged to cover expenses incurred if the owner and lienholder of the towed vehicle are notified by certified, registered mail of the location of the towed article. 
(f)  All charges for a nonconsensual tow shall be for services rendered in the towing, storing, or notifying the owner of such vehicles. No towing carrier shall include in its charges any sum of money payable to a third person or entity for any purpose, including, but not limited to, payments to an owner or representative of property from which such vehicles are towed. The inclusion of such sums are declared to be an unfair trade practice. 
(g)  A towing carrier who violates the terms of this section shall be subject to a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or serve a term not exceeding thirty (30) days in jail, or both. 
(Ord. No. 1997-116, § 1, 3-25-97; Ord. No. 1997-161, § 1, 5-13-97; Ord. No. 2004-05, § 1, 2-13-04; Ord. No. 2007-157, § 1, 8-21-07)  
Sec. 19-401. - Methods of payment at vehicle storage facilities. 
Every vehicle storage facility doing business within the corporate limits of the city shall accept major credit cards in addition to cash. There shall be no additional fee charged for the use of credit cards. 
(Ord. No. 1997-116, § 1, 3-25-97)  
Sec. 19-402. - Signage required at place of payment. 
Every entity performing nonconsensual tows shall have affixed in a prominent place, clearly visible to patrons retrieving towed vehicles a sign provided by the City of Charleston outlining the maximum fees and required methods of payment. 
(Ord. No. 2007-157, § 3, 8-21-07)  
Sec. 19-403. - Severability. 
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, word or any other part of this article shall be declared unconstitutional or invalid by a court of competent authority, then the remainder of this ordinance shall not be affected and shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 1997-116, § 1, 3-25-97; Ord. No. 2007-157, § 2, 8-21-07) 
Note— Formerly numbered as § 19-402.  
Secs. 19-404—19-413. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIV. - VEHICLE IMMOBILIZATION SERVICE 
 
Sec. 19-414. - Findings of council. 
(a)  City council finds in many instances when a vehicle is booted on private property without the owner's knowledge or consent that vehicle owners are at the complete mercy of the booting operators and as such, are subjected to instances of price gouging and other overly stringent requirements for the return of their vehicles. 
(b)  City council finds that due to the unique parking arrangements in some downtown parking lots where city agents operate parking lots on leased private land many citizens and visitors alike are frequently confused over which lots are private or public; and 
(c)  City council finds that there is often inadequate signage, indicating the times when a car may be booted or of the price of a nonconsensual boot thereby inadequately apprising the public of the maximum risks of imprudent parking; and 
(d)  Further, city council intends to exercise its police powers to ensure that the public security, general welfare, health and order of the city are adequately protected from price gouging and unscrupulous booting operators. 
(Ord. No. 1999-142, § 1, 10-12-99)  
Sec. 19-415. - Definitions. 
Boot operator means any individual or company engaged in the practice of immobilizing vehicles through mechanical devices. 
Locking wheel boot or boot means a mechanical clamp or device that is professionally manufactured and designed to lock the wheel on a motor vehicle thus immobilizing the vehicle and preventing anyone but the keyholder from removing it. 
Motor vehicle means any motorized vehicle which is capable of moving on the public ways of the City of Charleston. 
Nonconsensual boot means the booting of a vehicle authorized or directed by a person other than the vehicle owner, authorized operator, or authorized agent of the owner. A nonconsensual boot includes, but is not limited to: 
(1)  A private property boot; 
(2)  Any booting performed contrary to the specific direction of the vehicle owner, authorized operator, or authorized agent of the owner; or 
(3)  Any boot performed without disclosure of the rates and charges to be assessed. 
This definition shall not apply to nonconsensual booting that occurs as a result of a vehicle repossession by a lien holder having title to the vehicle. 
Private property booting means the booting of a motor vehicle from private property at the request of the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 1999-142, § 1, 10-12-99)  
Sec. 19-416. - Booting license required. 
(a)  In addition to all other applicable licensing requirements, no person or entity engaged in the business of performing nonconsensual booting shall operate within the corporate limits of the city without first being licensed by the department of traffic and transportation. The application for a license shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and complete street address, city, state, zip code, and telephone number of the applicant, and the trade name under which the operation shall be conducted. A post office box is acceptable as an address so long as a physical address is also provided: 
a.  If the applicant is a corporation: 
1.  A statement of that fact and the name of the state in which it is incorporated; 
2.  The location of its principal office in the State of South Carolina and the names of its directors and officers; 
3.  A copy of its articles of incorporation or charter; and 
4.  A copy of its certificate of assumed trade name, if any. 
b.  If the applicant is a limited liability company, the name, title, and business address of each member. 
c.  If the applicant is a partnership, the name, title, and business address of each partner. 
(2)  A list with a complete description of the equipment to be operated. 
(3)  A statement that applicant is familiar with the rules contained in this article and will comply with them. 
(4)  Every application must be signed by the applicant or its attorney or agent with the complete address and telephone number of the attorney or agent. 
(5)  A statement acknowledging the books and records concerning the booting operations of any booting operator shall be made available upon request during normal business hours to authorized personnel of the city. 
(6)  Certificates of insurance, from an insurer authorized to do business in the State of South Carolina, establishing proof of liability coverage of no less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). 
(7)  All written authorization(s), if applicable, indicating the properties or lots from which the booting operator is authorized to conduct nonconsensual booting. 
(b)  A booting operator who operates in violation of this section shall be subject to a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or serve a term not exceeding thirty (30) days in jail, or both. 
(c)  The cost of the license shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per booting operator or as otherwise set by city council from time to time. This license shall be renewable on September 1 of every year at the same rate of ten dollars ($10.00) per year. 
(d)  Any license under this article may be denied, suspended or revoked for violating any section of this chapter or Code. 
(Ord. No. 1999-142, § 1, 10-12-99)  
Sec. 19-417. - Boot record/invoice. 
Booting operators shall use a booting record/invoice form for all non-consensual booting, which form shall contain the information shown in Appendix A to Ord. No. 1999-142. Booting operators shall complete all applicable portions of the boot record/invoice form for each nonconsensual boot. The boot record/invoice shall be a multiple copy form, the copies of which shall be distributed as follows: The booting operator shall retain the copy bearing all required original signatures for authorization and delivery. The booting operator shall deliver a copy to the vehicle owner, authorized operator, or authorized agent of the owner at the time of delivery of the booted motor vehicle and payment of booting charges. Further, booting operators shall maintain a time-stamp method of recording all calls pertaining to release of all vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 1999-142, § 1, 10-12-99) 
Editor's note— Appendix A to Ord. No. 1999-142 has not be set out herein but is available in the office of the clerk of council.  
Sec. 19-418. - Booting from private property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to boot a vehicle on commercially zoned private property without authorization from the owner of the motor vehicle or of the city, except under the following circumstances: 
(1)  The property owner has posted the property with signs. Each sign face shall be at least six (6) square feet. 
(2)  The posted signs were in place, clearly visible and legible to any driver approaching any point of ingress to the property where parking is prohibited or restricted at the time the vehicle was parked; and 
(3)  The posted signs contain a clear warning that: 1) violators' vehicles will be booted, at the vehicle owner's expense; 2) the telephone number to call for release of the vehicle; 3) that the maximum price for release of the vehicle is fifty dollars ($50.00); and 4) that the booting operator must arrive to release the vehicle within thirty (30) minutes of calling for release of the vehicle or there can be no charge for the release of the vehicle. 
(4)  All signage must be approved by the director of the department of traffic and transportation. 
(5)  The signage requirements in this article are exempt from the requirements for signage contained in the City of Charleston Zoning Ordinance; the requirements in this article shall prevail. 
(b)  The owner of the vehicle booted on commercially zoned private property shall be responsible for paying all applicable booting charges provided that the private property owner has complied with all of the requirements contained in subsection (a) above. If a vehicle is booted as a result of a property owner's request and the property owner has not complied with the requirements of subsection (a) above, or if the vehicle is shown to have been legally parked, the property owner shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and may, in the discretion of the municipal judge as provided in S.C. Code 1976, Section 14-25-75, be subject to reimburse the owner of the vehicle for all booting charges that the owner of the vehicle paid. 
(c)  Before booting a vehicle on commercially zoned private property without authorization from the vehicle owner, the boot operator shall obtain from the property owner a written authorization which shall set forth the name and signature of the property owner, unless, such authorization has been previously filed pursuant to section 19-416(a)(7) above. 
(Ord. No. 1999-142, § 1, 10-12-99; Ord. No. 2006-13, § 1, 1-24-06; Ord. No. 2016-027, § 1, 2-9-16 )  
Sec. 19-419. - Maximum charge for nonconsensual boot. 
(a)  The maximum rate that may be charged for a nonconsensual boot of a vehicle on commercially zoned private property shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) inclusive of any and all additional fees. Notwithstanding the provisions of any other law, when a vehicle has been booted on commercially zoned private property and subsequently towed from such property, no additional charge may be imposed for the towing of such vehicle. 
(b)  Immediately upon installing the locking wheel boot, a blaze orange warning decal at least forty-seven (47) square inches in size shall be prominently placed in the center of the drivers side window or on the front windshield directly in front of the vehicle steering wheel. The specific language on the warning sign shall be subject to approval by the director of traffic and transportation and shall clearly and legibly inform the operator of the vehicle that a locking device has been installed on the front wheel of the vehicle and that attempting to move the vehicle will cause serious damage to the vehicle. This decal shall display the telephone number and address of the licensee. Upon payment of the booting fee, the licensee shall remove the decal and shall have in possession the appropriate materials needed to remove all parts of the decal and residue. 
(c)  Vehicle immobilization service licensees shall maintain twenty-four (24) hour telephones and wheel locking device removal services, and shall respond to a request to remove a wheel locking device within thirty (30) minutes. If a licensee does not appear to remove the wheel locking device within thirty (30) minutes of a customer request, the locking device shall be removed at no charge. If a licensee fails to appear to remove the wheel locking device within one (1) hour of a customer request the licensee shall be subject to a fine as indicated in subsection (f). 
(d)  If the owner, authorized operator, or authorized agent of the owner of a motor vehicle that is parked without authorization on private property attempts to retrieve said vehicle before booting actually occurs there shall be no fee and the vehicle owner shall be allowed to remove the vehicle without further delay. 
(e)  Every boot operator doing business in the corporate limits of the city shall accept major credit cards in addition to cash. There shall be no additional fee charged for the use of credit cards. 
(f)  A booting operator who violates the terms of this section shall be subject to a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or serve a term not exceeding thirty (30) days in jail, or both. 
(Ord. No. 1999-142, § 1, 10-12-99; Ord. No. 2004-05, § 1, 2-13-04; Ord. No. 2016-027, § 2, 2-9-16 )  
Sec. 19-420. - Severability. 
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, word or any other part of this article shall be declared unconstitutional or invalid by a court of competent authority, then the remainder of this ordinance shall not be affected and shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 1999-142, § 1, 10-12-99)  
Secs. 19-421—19-440. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XV. - POLITICAL SIGNS IN PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY 
 
Sec. 19-441. - Political signs in public rights-of-way unlawful. 
From and after January 1, 1996, it shall be unlawful to place or allow to be placed, a sign promoting a political candidate or party within a state maintained street, highway or rights-of-way in the corporate limits of the City of Charleston, or within any right-of-way in the corporate limits of the city that is maintained by the City of Charleston. 
(Ord. No. 1995-489, § 1, 10-10-95; Ord. No. 1996-47, § 1, 2-27-96)  
Secs. 19-442—19-460. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVI. - RICKSHAWS[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2007-137, § 1, adopted July 17, 2007, amended former Art. XVI, §§ 19-461—19-475, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. XVI, §§ 19-461—19-475, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from 2000-245, § 1, 10-10-00; Ord. No. 2002-74, § 1, 5-28-02. 
 
Sec. 19-461. - The operation of rickshaws regulated. 
(a)  City council hereby makes the following findings of fact: 
(1)  The number of persons using the public streets in the Peninsula Area of the City of Charleston in the recent years has increased dramatically due to an expanded commercial use and the growing tourism industry. As a result, congestion on the streets in the Peninsula Area has increased because of a rise in the number of vehicles and pedestrians using the streets and sidewalks. 
(2)  Rickshaws pickup and discharge passengers at numerous locations in the Peninsula Area and tend to congregate at or near restaurants, places of assembly, and the market area. The continued proliferation of rickshaws in the Peninsula Area tends to create a carnival or theme-park atmosphere which is destructive of the historic and traditional ambiance of the Peninsula Area which is substantially made up of Eighteenth and Nineteenth Century structures. Therefore, in order to protect the historic and traditional ambiance of the Peninsula Area, city council finds it necessary to regulate rickshaws operating on the public right-of-ways in the Peninsula Area. 
(3)  Rickshaws, as hereinafter defined, are by their design and nature, slow moving, and pose a potential danger for those using the vehicles and the streets. The unregulated operations of rickshaws on the streets of the Peninsula Area would add to the congestion in the streets and would greatly inconvenience, if not endanger users of the streets in the area. As a result, it is in the public interest, and for the public's safety and welfare, that the users of the public right-of-ways be protected from unregulated vehicles which hinder travel or which pose dangers or distractions which give rise to accidents and inconvenience. 
(4)  The city approved a rickshaw pilot program July 20, 2010, authorizing additional rickshaw tokens to be distributed for night time use. As a result of the token pilot program, city council believes that there is an increasing demand for the use of rickshaws by residents and visitors in the district and that a limited increase in the number of rickshaws permitted in the district is in the public's best interest; 
(5)  City council further finds, for the same reasons, that electric, oil or gasoline powered rickshaws in operation in the Peninsula Area would not be in the public interest. 
(Ord. No. 2007-137, § 1, 7-17-07; Ord. No. 2011-29, § 1, 4-12-11)  
Sec. 19-462. - Definitions. 
The following words and terms are defined for the purpose of this article only: 
General operating decal shall be defined as a decal that is securely fastened to a rickshaw which allows an owner to operate that particular rickshaw at any time in the Peninsula Area. 
Night time operating decal shall be defined as a decal that is securely fastened to a rickshaw which allows an owner to operate that particular rickshaw during the hours of 6:30 p.m. to 3:00 a.m. Monday thru Friday and 5:00 p.m. to 3:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday in the Peninsula Area. 
Operating decal shall be defined as a general operating decal or a night time operating decal. 
Operator shall be defined as any person who operates, drives, or propels a rickshaw. 
Owner shall be defined as any person partnership, corporation, association, or other organization engaged in the business of transporting persons for hire or any other remuneration by a rickshaw. 
Peninsula Area shall be defined as the area bounded on the north by Mount Pleasant Street, on the east by the Cooper River, on the south by the Battery, and on the west by the Ashley River. 
Rickshaws, also known as "pedicabs", shall be defined as a bicycle or other opened or closed vehicle with three (3) or more wheels operated by one (1) individual for the purpose of, or capable of, transporting passengers in seats or a platform made a part of the rickshaw. This definition shall not include a bicycle built for two (2) where the operators are seated one behind the other, nor shall it include the operation of a bicycle with trainer or beginner wheels affixed thereto, nor shall it include a wheelchair or other vehicle with the purpose of operation by or for the transportation of a disabled person, nor shall it include a tricycle built for a child or an adult with a seat for only one (1) operator and no passenger. 
(Ord. No. 2007-137, § 1, 7-17-07; Ord. No. 2011-29, § 2, 4-12-11)  
Sec. 19-463. - Operating decal. 
No rickshaw shall operate in the Peninsula Area without a duly issued operating decal and without having paid such fee therefore. The operating decal must be securely affixed to the rickshaw in a location approved by the director of traffic and transportation. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 3, 4-12-11) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-29, § 3, adopted April 12, 2011, repealed § 19-463 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 19-463 pertained to certificate of appropriateness required and derived from Ord. No. 2007-137, § 1, adopted July 17, 2007.  
Sec. 19-464. - Operating decal application process. 
(a)  Any person or corporation desiring to bid on an operating decal shall have first provided to the director of traffic and transportation an operating decal application. The director of traffic and transportation will review the application to ensure that it meets the requirements of this article, and upon approval by the director of transportation, the director of traffic and transportation shall make recommendation to the procurement office to allow the applicant to participate in the bidding process for the operating decals. 
(1)  The operating decal application form shall require the following information: 
i.  The full name, address, and telephone number of the owner; 
ii.  Physical address of the rickshaw storage; 
iii.  The number of rickshaws to be inspected and a list identifying each rickshaw by its model number and unit number; 
iv.  Such other information as the director of traffic and transportation may require. 
(2)  The applicant shall provide the following materials to complete the application: 
i.  In the event that the owner is a corporation, a certified copy of the articles of incorporation; 
ii.  Factory authorized material setting forth the characteristics of the rickshaw(s) to be approved, including the dimensions, weight, and passenger capacity; 
iii.  True and accurate color photographs not less than eight (8) inches × ten (10) inches of all four (4) sides of the rickshaw(s) to be approved; 
iv.  Proof of the minimum insurance required which shall: 
a.  Be obtained from a carrier that is admitted and licensed to transact insurance in the State of South Carolina; 
b.  Be written on an occurrence basis; 
c.  Cover any and all rickshaws and employees of the business and all drivers of such vehicles whether such drivers are employees or otherwise have agreements to drive for that business; 
d.  Name the City of Charleston as an additional primary insured; 
e.  Provide minimum coverage in an amount no less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit liability (CSL) per occurrence; 
f.  Provide that all claims will be paid on a first dollar basis by the insurance provider; 
g.  Not contain policy exclusions that would change or limit coverage for passengers entering or exiting the vehicle; 
h.  Provide that all vehicles permitted to operate under the operating authority are listed as scheduled vehicles covered under the policy; and 
i.  All liability insurance coverage must include a rider that provides that at all levels of coverage, there must be notification to the city in writing not less than thirty (30) days before canceling or making a material change in the policy. 
v.  A statement that the rickshaw owner shall indemnify, defend, and hold harmless the City of Charleston, its officials, employees, agents, (collectively referred to as "indemnitees") and each of them from and against all losses, costs, claims, penalties, fines, expenses (including attorney's fees), liabilities (collectively referred to as "liabilities") by reason of any bodily injury to or death of any person or damage to or destruction or loss of any property arising out of, or resulting from, or in connection with an operating decal. The rickshaw owner shall further agree to indemnify, defend and hold harmless the indemnitees from and against liability which may be asserted by an employee or former employee of the rickshaw owner, or any of its subcontractors, for which liability to such employee or former employee would other wise be limited to payments under workers' compensation or similar laws. 
vi.  A current schedule of fees to be charged to the public for rickshaw services; 
vii.  A current city business license; and 
viii.  Such other material as the director of traffic and transportation shall require. 
(3)  Any operating decal application form that is incomplete or fails to contain the materials required by this section may be rejected as incomplete and returned to the applicant. 
(b)  Once a rickshaw has been found to be in compliance with this article, the director of traffic and transportation shall affix a rickshaw inspection sticker on the rickshaw indicating the same. 
(c)  Nothing herein shall be construed so as to prohibit the director of traffic or transportation or the traffic and transportation committee from requiring visual inspection of the rickshaw. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 4, 4-12-11) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-29, § 4, adopted April 12, 2011, repealed § 19-464 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 19-464 pertained to application and inspection and derived from Ord. No. 2007-137, § 1, adopted July 17, 2007.  
Sec. 19-465. - Design standards. 
(a)  The director of traffic and transportation shall not approve an operating decal application until he has first determined: 
(1)  that the general design and color of the rickshaw, specifically the character and appropriateness of the design and the color is appropriate for use in the Peninsula Area taking into consideration the age, condition, manner of propulsion, noise level and outward appearance of the rickshaw; 
(2)  that each rickshaw listed on the operating decal application is equipped with head lights, tail lights, a braking system, a slow moving sign, and seat belts; 
(3)  that all rickshaw equipment is neat, clean, operable and in safe condition; 
(4)  that at a minimum, on each side of the rickshaw there is displayed in three-inch letters the name of the rickshaw company, the telephone number for the rickshaw company, and the unit number for the rickshaw; 
(b)  Rickshaws approved under an entity's operating decal application shall be of the same color. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 5, 4-12-11) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-29, § 5, adopted April 12, 2011, repealed § 19-465 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 19-465 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2007-137, § 1, adopted July 17, 2007.  
Sec. 19-466. - Number of rickshaw operating decals permitted; restriction on monopolies. 
(a)  No more than fifteen (15) general operating decals and fifteen (15) night time operating decals shall be issued by the City of Charleston's procurement department. 
(b)  Operating decals shall be issued by the city's procurement department in accordance with the process as set forth in section 19-467 herein. 
(c)  No owner of a rickshaw company may be the recipient of more than forty-nine (49) per cent of the general operating decals and/or forty-nine (49) per cent of the night time operating decals. 
(d)  No subsidiary, parent, or affiliated company (for purposes of this article meaning any company that has interlocking directors or officers, or any of the same person or directors or officers, or any person who owns five (5) per cent or more of the stock of the company) of any person who has current decals may operate a rickshaw business in the city under the article. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 6, 4-12-11) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-29, § 6, adopted April 12, 2011, repealed § 19-466 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 19-466 pertained to expiration and derived from Ord. No. 2007-137, § 1, adopted July 17, 2007.  
Sec. 19-467. - Operating decal distribution. 
(a)  Operating decals shall be made available pursuant to a competitive bidding process and the execution of an agreement to operate with the city. The competitive bidding process and the execution of the agreement to operate shall be managed by the city's procurement division. 
(b)  There shall be two (2) separate competitive bidding processes for the operating decals. One (1) competitive bid process for the general operating decals and one (1) competitive bid process for the night time operating decals. 
(c)  Corporation counsel shall draft bid specifications, which shall include, at a minimum: 
(1)  That the distribution of the decals shall be made as follows: 
i.  The first decal to the highest bidder then the next decal to the second highest bidder and so forth until all available operating decals have been distributed; 
(2)  The minimum bid and the minimum amount that must be submitted with the bid; 
(3)  A provision that the payment of the successful bid shall be made within two (2) weeks after notification of the winning bid before the issuance of the operating decal; 
(4)  A provision which delineates the term for each operating decal which term shall not exceed five (5) years from date of distribution; 
(5)  A provision permitting the renewal of an operating decal upon the payment of a renewal fee based upon the original bid amount and an increase factor of fifteen (15) per cent per term and upon determination of the traffic and transportation director that: 
i.  the holder of the operating decal has performed satisfactorily under the terms of this and any other operating decal(s); 
ii.  the holder of the operating decal is in compliance with this article; and 
iii.  the holder has executed another agreement to operate with the city. 
(6)  A provision requiring that the operating decals distributed pursuant to this article to be issued to a specific rickshaw and to a specific owner; 
(7)  A provision requiring that the successful bidder resubmit an operating decal application to the director of traffic and transportation on at least an annual basis during the term of the operating decal; 
(8)  A prohibition against the successful bidder from transferring, assigning or subletting the operating decals. In the event of an absolute sale of a rickshaw company, the operating decal(s) shall be transferable to the new owner thereof; 
(9)  A provision requiring that the operating decal be securely attached to the rickshaw in a clearly visible place on the left rear portion of the rickshaw for which it was issued; 
(10)  A provision requiring that the operating decal may be temporarily transferred or to another rickshaw owned by the same owner so long as the transfer is temporary and for a period of time less than seventy-two (72) hours. Permanent transfers lasting longer than seventy-two (72) hours must be reported to the traffic and transportation department with seventy-two (72) hours of transferring the decal; 
(11)  A provision requiring that all operators of rickshaws shall have a valid South Carolina driver's license; 
(12)  A provision requiring that the successful bidder maintains a current City of Charleston business license; 
(13)  A provision requiring that the successful bidder within ten (10) days after a change in status of any information required by this article, the successful bidder shall notify in writing the traffic and transportation department of the change in status; 
(14)  A provision requiring that the Operating decal remains the property of the city and must be surrendered upon expiration, cancellation, or revocation; 
(15)  A provision which, subject to due process considerations authorizes the city, upon reasonable notice, to suspend or revoke the operating decal upon a finding that the owner has defaulted under, or otherwise violated, the agreement to operate or any city ordinance; 
(16)  A provision allowing the city to reject any or all bids not deemed by it to be in the best interest of the city. 
(d)  No bid specifications shall be put out for bid until they have first been approved by the committee on ways and means. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 7, 4-12-11) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-29, § 7, adopted April 12, 2011, repealed § 19-467 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 19-467 pertained to transferability and derived from Ord. No. 2007-137, § 1, adopted July 17, 2007.  
Sec. 19-468. - Renewals. 
Operating decals may be renewed at their expiration pursuant to section 19-467(c)(5). Non-renewed permits shall be distributed pursuant to 19-467. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 8, 4-12-11) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-29, § 8, adopted April 12, 2011, repealed § 19-468 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 19-468 pertained to suspension or revocation and derived from Ord. No. 2007-137, § 1, adopted July 17, 2007.  
Sec. 19-469. - Inspections. 
Any law enforcement officer of the City of Charleston and the director of traffic and transportation or his designee shall have the right to inspect or cause to be inspected any rickshaw operating on any street in the city as often as may be necessary for the purposes of ascertaining and causing to be corrected any unsafe or unsanitary considerations or any violations of this article. It shall be a violation of this section for any person to delay, interfere with or refuse to allow such inspection. Any rickshaw found not to conform to the standards and tolerances provided for in this article shall be ordered out of service. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 9, 4-12-11) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-29, § 9, adopted April 12, 2011, repealed § 19-469 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 19-469 pertained to route and number limitations and derived from Ord. No. 2007-137, § 1, adopted July 17, 2007.  
Sec. 19-470. - Route limitations. 
Rickshaws may operate on the streets or public ways in the Old and Historic District (the "district") provided that when operating in the district in residential areas zoned, SR, STR or DR, such operation shall be exclusively for the purpose of such entry into the district to pick up or discharge passengers in the residential portions of the district. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 10, 4-12-11) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-29, § 10, adopted April 12, 2011, repealed § 19-470 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 19-470 pertained to zones of operation and derived from Ord. No. 2007-137, § 1, adopted July 17, 2007.  
Sec. 19-471. - Traffic laws applicable to rickshaws. 
Every person operating a rickshaw upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by the laws of this state declaring rules of the road applicable to vehicles or by the traffic regulations of this city applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except as to special regulations in this article and except as to those provisions of laws and regulations which by their nature can have no application. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 11, 4-12-11) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-29, § 11, adopted April 12, 2011, repealed § 19-471 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 19-471 pertained to mechanized power, touring and sightseeing prohibited and derived from Ord. No. 2007-137, § 1, adopted July 17, 2007.  
Sec. 19-472. - Rickshaw parking. 
(a)  To provide drop off and pick up areas for rickshaws, the director of traffic and transportation may locate and designate rickshaw parking zones. 
(b)  It is unlawful for an operator to leave his rickshaw unattended. 
(c)  It is unlawful to park a rickshaw in a metered parking space. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 12, 4-12-11) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-29, § 12, adopted April 12, 2011, repealed § 19-472 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 19-472 pertained to lights required and derived from Ord. No. 2007-137, § 1, adopted July 17, 2007.  
Sec. 19-473. - Touring prohibited. 
(a)  The operation of rickshaws powered in any manner other than the strength of the operator is prohibited in the Old and Historic District. No person shall operate or cause to be operated for hire or otherwise a rickshaw for the purpose of conducting tours or sightseeing within the Old and Historic District. 
(b)  No person shall operate a rickshaw with sound produced by radio, tape, CD, DVD, record player, or any other mechanical sound device or instrument from the rickshaw. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 13, 4-12-11) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-29, § 13, adopted April 12, 2011, repealed § 19-473 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 19-473 pertained to passenger restraints required and derived from Ord. No. 2007-137, § 1, adopted July 17, 2007.  
Sec. 19-474. - Conduct prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to operate a rickshaw having more than three (3) passengers therein. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to refuse to provide the schedule of fares upon request to any passenger upon entry into or while seated in the rickshaw. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to operate a rickshaw in or upon any street in the city unless such person has a valid South Carolina driver's license. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful while the rickshaw is in motion, for the operator to collect fares, make change, or embark or debark passengers. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful to operate a rickshaw in any manner that violates any city ordinance or state law, or disrupts the flow of vehicular traffic on the public streets. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful to operate a rickshaw upon a sidewalk. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful to operate a rickshaw wearing headphones. 
(h)  It shall be unlawful to operate a rickshaw more than one (1) rickshaw abreast, except when overtaking and passing another rickshaw proceeding in the same direction. 
(i)  It shall be unlawful for an operator to allow a passenger in the rickshaw to drink or consume alcoholic beverages or to possess an open container of alcoholic beverage. 
(j)  It shall be unlawful for an operator to refuse to provide a receipt in legible writing containing the name of the operator, the decal number, the total amount paid, and the date of payment. 
(k)  It shall be unlawful for an operator to charge a passenger a fare greater than the fare contained on the approved fare schedule. 
(l)  Rickshaws shall be operated in a manner as to be a part of the normal traffic flow; provided, however, slower moving rickshaws shall safely pull temporarily to the side so as to prevent unnecessary delays to following traffic; and provided, further, animal-drawn vehicles are permitted to temporarily pull to the side of streets, out of the traffic flow, for description purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2011-29, § 14, 4-12-11) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-29, § 14, adopted April 12, 2011, repealed § 19-474 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 19-474 pertained to number of passengers restricted and derived from Ord. No. 2007-137, § 1, adopted July 17, 2007, and Ord. No. 2009-13, § 1, adopted Jan. 13, 2009.  
Sec. 19-475. - Operators. 
All operators of rickshaws within the Old and Historic District shall have a valid South Carolina driver's license. 
(Ord. No. 2007-137, § 1, 7-17-07)  
Secs. 19-476—19-490. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVII. - DUMPSTERS[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2001-36, § 1, adopted April 10, 2001, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as Art. XVII, §§ 19-457—19-462. In order to avoid conflicts in section numbering, the editor has redesignated the provisions of Ord. No. 2001-36 as §§ 19-491—19-496. 
Cross reference— Garbage, trash and refuse, Ch. 14. 
 
Sec. 19-491. - Findings of city council. 
City council finds it necessary to promulgate standards to govern dumpsters on public property, including rights-of-way. Such public property is an integral component of the public realm that should and must be available for public use, access and enjoyment without undue interference by private sector interests. The purpose of this article is to promote the public health, safety and welfare by establishing reasonable regulations to govern permits, placement, number and appearance of dumpsters on public rights-of-ways so as to: 
(1)  Provide for pedestrian and driving safety convenience; 
(2)  Restrict unreasonable interference with the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic including ingress and egress from any residence or place of business, or from the street to the sidewalk by persons exiting or entering parked or standing vehicles; 
(3)  Provide for safety during adverse weather conditions; 
(4)  Provide reasonable access and viewing for the use and maintenance of poles, posts, traffic signs, signals, hydrants, mailboxes, and access to locations used for public transportation and service purposes; 
(5)  Relocate and/or replace dumpsters which result in visual blight and/or excessive space allocation on the public rights-of-way, or which unreasonably detract from the aesthetics of store window displays, adjacent landscaping and other improvements, as well as to have abandoned or neglected dumpsters removed; 
(6)  Maintain and protect the values of surrounding properties; 
(7)  Reduce unnecessary exposure of the public to personal injury or property damage claims; and 
(8)  Treat all applicants for dumpster permits equally according to the standards set forth in this article and all applicable regulations promulgated in furtherance hereof. 
(Ord. No. 2001-36, § 1, 4-10-01)  
Sec. 19-492. - Definitions. 
[Unless the context clearly requires otherwise, the following terms, where used in this chapter, shall have the following meaning:] 
Applicant. The individual or entity who leases or otherwise obtains a dumpster for use and applies for a dumpster permit. 
Dumpster. An approved metal container as determined by the director of traffic and transportation, with a minimum capacity of four (4) cubic yards and a maximum capacity of thirty (30) cubic yards, used for the storage, collection, or removal of construction debris, demolition debris, or other discarded material. 
Graffiti. An inscription, drawing, mark or design that is painted, sprayed or otherwise placed on or in a dumpster with the consent of the owner. 
Owner. Individual or entity that is in the business of renting or otherwise providing dumpsters for temporary use, by an applicant, at an approved location. 
Right-of-way. Any public street, highway, sidewalk, parkway or alley. 
(Ord. No. 2001-36, § 1, 4-10-01)  
Sec. 19-493. - Dumpster permit required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to place or maintain a dumpster on a right of way unless such person or entity shall first obtain a dumpster permit. The department of traffic and transportation shall be the issuing authority for all dumpster permits. 
(b)  The applicant shall file with the department of traffic and transportation a written application for a dumpster permit each time which shall contain the following information. 
(1)  The name and address and telephone number of the applicant, owner and, if applicable, the principal in charge of the dumpster. 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of the responsible person whom the city may notify or contact at any time concerning the dumpster. 
(3)  A detailed statement explaining: (1) the reason for the necessity of a dumpster; (2) whether the dumpster will block a right-of-way; (3) which right-of-way will be obstructed; (4) the length of time the dumpster may be present in the right-of-way; (5) the number of dumpsters which will be present. 
(4)  A statement that applicant and the owner is familiar with the rules contained in this article and will comply with them. The statement shall be signed by both the applicant and the owner. 
(5)  Evidence of the applicant's City of Charleston business license, as applicable. 
(6)  Proof of insurance against any liability, loss or claim arising out of the issuance of dumpster permits, or out of the placement, presence, use, maintenance or removal of the dumpsters.
