ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 30-1. - Interfering with city property controlled by commissioners of public works. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere or tamper with the property of the city controlled by the commissioners of public works or with the property of the commissioners of public works. 
(Code 1975, § 46-1) 
State Law reference— Commissioners of public works, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-31-210 et seq.; interference with sewers, waterworks, etc., S.C. Code 1976, § 5-31-20.  
Sec. 30-2. - Enforcement by police. 
It shall be the duty of the police to report all persons found violating any of the provisions or prohibitions of any of the sections of this chapter and to arrest all persons who may violate the same or who may wantonly deface or injure any of the property of the city, controlled by the commissioners of public works. 
(Code 1975, § 46-2)  
Sec. 30-3. - Combined waterworks and sewer system. 
(a)  Feasibility of combination declared. The city council determines that the waterworks system of the city and the city system for collection and disposal of sewage are so related as to make it both proper and feasible to combine the same. 
(b)  Combination and designation of system. The waterworks system of the city and the system of the city for the collection and disposal of sewage in existence as of August 16, 1960 is hereby combined into a single system. Such system shall be known as "The Waterworks and Sewer System of the City of Charleston." 
(c)  Management of system; rates, tolls and charges. The combined system provided for in paragraph (b) of this section shall be under the full control and management of the commissioners of public works of the city, who shall be fully empowered to operate, maintain, enlarge and improve the same and to establish such rates, tolls and charges as it may deem proper for the services and facilities afforded by such waterworks and sewer system. 
(Code 1975, §§ 46-3—46-5) 
State Law reference— Authority for governing body of any city to constitute a municipally-owned and operated waterworks system and a municipally-owned sewer system as a single system, S.C. Code 1976, § 6-21-10 et seq.  
Secs. 30-4—30-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CITY ELECTRICIAN 
 
Sec. 30-16. - Appointment of employees. 
The director of the department of public service shall appoint, subject to the approval and consent of the mayor, such employees as are necessary to carry on the work formerly performed by the department of electricity. 
(Code 1975, § 18-7)  
Sec. 30-17. - Duty to supervise and inspect wiring and equipment. 
The department of public service shall supervise and inspect all electric wiring and apparatus and equipment for light, heat and power within the city. 
(Code 1975, § 18-8)  
Sec. 30-18. - Jurisdiction over telegraph, radio and alarm systems. 
The department of public service shall have charge of the police telephone and telegraph systems, the police and fire department radio system and the fire alarm system. 
(Code 1975, § 18-9) 
State Law reference— Interference with police and fire alarm boxes, see S.C. Code 1976, § 16-17-570.  
Sec. 30-19. - Inspection of wiring and apparatus. 
The department of public service may inspect or reinspect, at any time, any wiring or apparatus conducting or using electric current for light, heat or power, within the city. 
(Code 1975, § 18-10)  
Sec. 30-20. - Supervision over erection and maintenance of wires and poles in streets. 
Except as otherwise provided, the department of public service shall generally, so far as the interests of the city and the citizens are concerned, supervise and direct the erection, conduct and maintenance of all poles, wires and other electrical apparatus in, through, upon or over the streets of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 18-11)  
Sec. 30-21. - Supervision and regulation of placement of wires to prevent fires and accidents. 
The department of public service shall have general supervision over and shall regulate and determine the placing, stringing and attaching of all telegraph, telephone or electric light and power or other wires now in use or which shall hereafter be erected in the city so as to prevent fires or accident or injury to persons or property, and to cause all such wires and all electrical appliances to be so placed, constructed and guarded, as not to cause fires or accidents, or endanger life or property. 
(Code 1975, § 18-12)  
Sec. 30-22. - Enforcement of laws. 
The department of public service shall enforce all laws, ordinances, rules and regulations relating to the installation, alteration, repair and operation of electrical wiring, apparatus and equipment. 
(Code 1975, § 18-13)  
Sec. 30-23. - Right to enter buildings for inspections and testing. 
The employees of the department of public service shall have the right, in the discharge of their official duties, to enter any building, manhole or subway, or climb any pole for the purpose of examining or testing the electrical appliances therein or thereon contained. For such purposes, they shall be given prompt access during reasonable hours to all buildings, public or private, and to all manholes and subways, on application to the individual or company owning or in charge of the same. 
(Code 1975, § 18-14)  
Sec. 30-24. - Compliance with orders; interfering with department of public service. 
Any person failing to comply with the lawful orders of the department of public service, or hindering or interfering with the employees of the department in the discharge of their duty shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1975, § 18-15)  
Secs. 30-25—30-35. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - METERS AND METER INSPECTION 
 
Sec. 30-36. - Permit required to locate meter box in sidewalk or roadway. 
No meter boxes shall be placed in the sidewalks or roadways of the city except under special permit which will be issued by the department of public service only in case it is impracticable to locate such meter boxes inside the property which the meters are intended to serve. 
(Code 1975, § 18-110) 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17.  
Sec. 30-37. - Curb boxes in roadways prohibited; repair of curb and meter boxes. 
No curb boxes shall be placed or maintained in the roadways. All curb boxes in the sidewalks or to be placed there hereafter, and all meter boxes duly authorized shall be kept in proper repair by the public service corporation or by the commission controlling same; provided that should such public service corporation or commission fail to repair any such curb and meter boxes within ten (10) days after notice by the department of public service, the department shall repair the same at the expense of the corporation or commission controlling the same. 
(Code 1975, § 18-111)  
Secs. 30-38—30-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC LIGHTING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-111, § 2, adopted July 20, 2010, repealed the former §§ 30-53—30-56 and 30-58—30-60 of art. IV, and renumbered § 30-57 as § 30-53, and §§ 30-61 and 30-62 as §§ 30-54 and 30-55, as set out herein. The historical notation has been retained with the amended provisions for reference purposes. 
 
Sec. 30-51. - Public lighting. 
The director of parks or his designee shall have general supervision over the public lighting of the streets, whether such lighting be done by franchise agreement, contract or otherwise, as the city council may from time to time determine and shall issue the orders for the installation, acceptance, or discontinuance of street lights and develop, implement, enforce, and administer the city's street lighting standards. 
(Code 1975, § 18-80; Ord. No. 2010-111, § 2, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 30-52. - Enforcement of article. 
The department of parks shall see that all provisions of this article and other ordinances of the city and all orders and rules of the city council and of the public works and utilities committee of the city council relating to public lamps, or lighting of the streets and public grounds, are strictly enforced. 
(Code 1975, § 18-81; Ord. No. 2010-111, § 2, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 30-53. - Additional duties of department of parks. 
The department of parks shall perform such other duties pertaining to the public lighting as may from time to time be prescribed by the city council and the public works and utilities committee of the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 18-86; Ord. No. 2010-111, § 2, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 30-54. - Access to equipment for testing current and voltage; testing circuits. 
In order to properly inspect, maintain, and repair public lighting, the department of parks shall have access at all times to all electrical lamps, poles, posts, conduits, apparatus or machinery, on or in the streets, parks and squares. The department of parks or its duly authorized agent shall have the privilege at all times to test any of such circuits at such point or points as it may select, by the use of such standard measuring instrument as it may desire to use, and it shall maintain such instruments in circuits for so long a time as it may select. 
(Code 1975, § 18-90; Ord. No. 2010-111, § 2, 7-20-10)  
Sec. 30-55. - Deduction from bill when city uses less than prescribed amount of energy. 
Should the average amount of electrical energy actually supplied during any one month be determined by the department of parks and confirmed by the public works and utilities committee of the city council to be less than the amount prescribed, the department of parks shall make note of such deficiency on the bill of the person furnishing lights, and there shall be deducted from the amount of the bill an amount equal to that proportion that the actual amount of service rendered bears to the amount of service required." 
(Code 1975, § 18-91; Ord. No. 2010-111, § 2, 7-20-10)  
Secs. 30-56—30-75. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PUBLIC UTILITY POLES AND WIRES 
 
Sec. 30-76. - Marking of poles required; manner of working. 
All persons authorized to erect poles for the purpose of carrying electric, telephone or telegraph wires in the streets of the city shall, at the time of the placing of such poles, stencil in one-inch letters on such poles the initials of the name of the owner of such poles, which letters shall be placed at least five (5) feet above the sidewalk. The poles owned by the city shall be marked with the initials "F. and P." 
(Code 1975, § 18-54)  
Sec. 30-77. - Posting signs and bills on poles prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to place signs or post bills on any poles authorized by this article. 
(Code 1975, § 18-55)  
Sec. 30-78. - Permit to erect pole or run wires in street—Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect any pole or poles, or to stretch, extend or run any wires along and through any of the streets of the city unless he shall first have obtained a permit therefor from the department of public service. 
(Code 1975, § 18-56) 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17.  
Sec. 30-79. - Same—Application; filing of location. 
Any person desiring a permit, as required in section 30-78, shall file an application therefor in the office of the department of public service at least seventy-two (72) hours prior to the date when the work is proposed to begin; provided that in an emergency, the department of public service may waive prior notice. Such application shall be accompanied by a plan indicating the proposed character and location of such poles or wires. 
(Code 1975, § 18-57)  
Sec. 30-80. - Same—Issuance. 
A plan filed as provided in section 30-79 shall be approved by the department of public service and, when so approved, it shall issue a permit for the work covered by such plan, and shall immediately notify the necessary city departments if the contemplated work will require blocking or diversion of or otherwise interfere with normal pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1975, § 18-58)  
Sec. 30-81. - Poles in streets. 
For the purpose of reaching the premises of the users of the service furnished by any person operating under this article, the necessary poles for distributing wires from the subways may be erected under the direction and supervision of the public works and utilities committee of the city council where deemed necessary by the department of public service. 
(Code 1975, § 18-59)  
Sec. 30-82. - Classification of telegraph and power wires as electrical. 
All wires carrying currents for electric lights or electric power for any purpose whatsoever are hereby designated and classed as electric wires. All wires other than for such purpose are hereby designated and classed as telegraph wires. 
(Code 1975, § 18-60)  
Sec. 30-83. - When companies required to occupy same line of poles. 
All companies erecting wires shall occupy the same line of poles wherever such combined use is practicable, to be determined by the public works and utilities committee of the city council and shall pay therefor such rental or compensation as the parties interested may agree upon, or if they shall fail to agree, then such as may be fixed by such committee. 
(Code 1975, § 18-61)  
Sec. 30-84. - Use of buildings to support wires. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use roofs of buildings in the support of wires. No other part of buildings shall be so used without the consent of the owners thereof properly authenticated to the department of public service and its approval of the same. 
(Code 1975, § 18-62)  
Sec. 30-85. - Compliance with National Electrical Code required; approval of samples prerequisite to stringing wires. 
All electric light or power wires erected or strung after October 13, 1936, shall be erected or strung to conform to the requirements of the National Electrical Code as adopted by section 12-16 of this Code. Permits to string wires will be granted only after approval of samples submitted to the department of public service, and no wires, other than those thus approved by sample, may be strung. 
(Code 1975, § 18-63)  
Sec. 30-86. - Size of poles. 
All poles shall be of ample size to support with safety the wires to be placed thereon. 
(Code 1975, § 18-69)  
Sec. 30-87. - Poles and wires obstructing travel; removal of superfluous poles and wires. 
It shall be the duty of the department of public service to direct the placing of poles and wires in the streets, alleys and public places of the city so that the same shall cause as little obstruction as possible either to public travel on such thoroughfares or to the private use and enjoyment of adjacent property. The department of public service shall compel the removal of superfluous poles, loops, wires and supports at once. 
(Code 1975, § 18-68)  
Sec. 30-88. - Height of wires above street. 
All wires shall be erected at a distance not less than eighteen (18) feet above the level of the street for telephone cables, twenty (20) feet for police and fire alarm and twenty-four (24) feet for electric wiring. 
(Code 1975, § 18-70)  
Sec. 30-89. - Fastening wires to trees; powers of inspections division and director of parks; cutting tree limbs for poles and wires. 
No electric wires, cables, guys, poles, cross-arms, brackets, insulators, or other wires or fixtures shall be attached to or come in contact with any tree standing for use or ornament in any public street, lane, court, park or other public place in the city, without the consent of, or written permit from, the inspections division. The inspections division may order the removal of any wires, cables, guys, poles, cross-arms, brackets, insulators or other wires or fixtures, attached to or in contact with such trees, which it deems injurious to such trees, or when such removal is advisable for the protection of the trees. It shall be the duty of the inspections division, where necessary to remove or cause to be removed any such wires or wire fixtures. The cost of such removal shall be charged to and paid for by the company or person owning such wires or wire fixtures. Application shall be made to the director of the department of parks whenever it shall be deemed necessary to trim any tree or trees to clear wires or any other such like purpose, and if the same be granted, such necessary trimming shall be done, in each instance, under his supervision and attention, and all expense of such trimming of the trees shall be borne and paid for, in advance, by the person or corporation making such application. Every person having any wire charged with electricity, running through a public highway, shall securely fasten such wire so that it shall not come in contact with any tree. It shall be unlawful for any person to cut away the limbs or branches of any tree for the purpose of erecting posts or suspending wires for electric light, telegraph or telephone or fire alarm service without the express permission, in writing, of the director of the department of parks. 
(Code 1975, § 18-71; Ord. No. 1976-16, §§ 7, 8, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 1979-16, § 4, 2-22-79; Ord. No. 1982-48, §§ 2, 3, 5-25-82)  
Sec. 30-90. - Location of poles; relocation. 
All poles, unless otherwise ordered by the department of public service, shall be set within the curb and five (5) feet from any fire hydrant, the right being hereby reserved to the public works and utilities committee of the city council to change, at the expense of the respective company, the location of any pole or poles when such change is deemed necessary for the public convenience or safety. 
(Code 1975, § 18-72)  
Sec. 30-91. - Right of city to install alarm wires on poles. 
The right is reserved to the city council to place without cost any police or fire alarm wires that are or may be in the future erected for the city's use, on any pole or poles erected in the streets, alleyways or other highways of the city, and all permits granted for the erection of poles shall be subject to this condition. 
(Code 1975, § 18-73)  
Sec. 30-92. - Suspension of permits; discontinuance of service upon repeated violations. 
Any violation or refusal on the part of any person or company to make such alterations or repairs in present or future construction as may be demanded by the public works and utilities committee of the city council in conformity with this article shall work immediate suspension of all permits held by the person or company guilty of such violation or refusal. In case of persistent violation of the requirements of this article, and in case of dangerous necessity, the public works and utilities committee of the city council may instruct the chief of police and the department of public service, either or both, to cut out light or to cut out the current in any locality concerned and to enforce the discontinuance of all rights until violations have been remedied. 
(Code 1975, § 18-75)  
Sec. 30-93. - Emergency crew for removal of wires upon occurrence of fire. 
When requested by the fire department upon occurrence of a fire, the electric utility, telephone or telegraph companies shall immediately send to the scene an emergency crew, with the necessary apparatus and tools to remove such wire or wires as shall be ordered removed by the chief of the fire department or his assistant or other officer in charge of such fire. Such emergency crew shall report immediately to the chief, assistant or other person in charge of the fire, and be and remain under his orders, which shall be promptly executed, until dismissed. 
(Code 1975, § 18-78)  
Sec. 30-94. - Authority of fire chief to order current turned off in emergency. 
The electric utility company shall immediately turn off electric current in any district when notified by the chief of the fire department, his assistant or other officer in charge, that great emergency exists. 
(Code 1975, § 18-79)  
Secs. 30-95—30-105. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - SANITARY SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 30-106. - Injuring or obstructing sewers or drains. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to do or cause to be done any injury or to cause an obstruction of any kind in any manner to any of the appliances or parts of the public sanitary sewers or drains. 
(Code 1975, § 42-6)  
Sec. 30-107. - Consent required to uncover public sanitary sewer or drain. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to uncover a public sanitary sewer or drain, or connection branches thereof, for any purpose or to make connection therewith, or to open any manhole or flush tank, unless and except with the approval of the manager of the commissioners of public works. 
(Code 1975, § 42-35)  
Secs. 30-108—30-115. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTIONS 
 
Sec. 30-116. - Removal of sewage by connection with storm drain prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to make, or cause to be made, any connection for the removal of sewage from any premises, with any storm or subwater drain, or with any stream or watercourse within the limits of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 42-38)  
Sec. 30-117. - Permit for connection with sanitary sewer—Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to make or cause to be made any connection for the removal of sewage with any sanitary sewer of the city without first obtaining a written permit from the inspections division. 
(Code 1975, § 42-36) 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17.  
Sec. 30-118. - Same—Application; filing; issuance. 
Application for a sanitary sewer connection permit pursuant to this division shall be filed at the office of the inspections division. If the application is approved a permit shall be issued to the master plumber or plumbing contractor who is the agent of the owner. The applicant also shall notify the department of traffic and transportation and the police department if the proposed work will require blocking or diversion of or interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1975, § 42-39)  
Sec. 30-119. - Same—Form of application. 
Application for a permit to make a sanitary sewer connection shall be made on suitable forms provided by the inspections division. 
(Code 1975, § 42-40)  
Sec. 30-120. - Same—Approval of plumbing work and material in building required for issuance. 
Permits to make connections with the public sanitary sewers shall be issued only when the plumbing work and material in the house or building to be connected is in accordance with the rules and regulations for plumbing prescribed in this Code. 
(Code 1975, § 42-51)  
Sec. 30-121. - Licensed plumber required to make connection. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a plumber duly licensed to do such work by the city, or the authorized agent of such plumber so licensed, to make any connection with the public sanitary sewers. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause any such connection to be made by any person other than as provided in this section. 
(Code 1975, § 42-41)  
Sec. 30-122. - Compliance with division required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to make connections with the public sanitary sewer in any other manner and with any other material than as provided in this division. 
(Code 1975, § 42-42)  
Sec. 30-123. - Pipe connections of buildings with public sanitary sewers; backfilling; repaving. 
Every pipe connected with the public sanitary sewers, from a point four (4) feet outside of the foundation walls or piers of the building, shall be strong, sound and impervious in all of its parts, shall be solidly laid on a true grade, and as nearly as possible in a straight line; all shall be jointed in the best manner, and covered at least to a depth of one foot with well-rammed earth, entirely free from stones and rubbish. Within twenty-four (24) hours (Sunday excepted), after the backfilling of the trench is completed, all paving and ballast shall be replaced and the street left in the best condition, to the satisfaction of the department of public service. 
(Code 1975, § 42-43) 
Cross reference— Permit required for disturbing surface of or opening street or taking up sidewalk, § 28-21.  
Sec. 30-124. - Gasket required at joints. 
Gaskets shall be used to prevent cement, lead or other compound from entering the pipes at the joints. 
(Code 1975, § 42-44)  
Sec. 30-125. - Separate connection of buildings with sanitary sewers; six-inch lines to private property; permit for more than one drain. 
(a)  Every building, except under conditions determined by the manager of the commissioners of public works and not conflicting with other provisions of this article, shall be separately and independently connected with the public sanitary sewers; each tenement to be regarded as a separate building; provided, however, that in all private courts, lanes and alleys fronting on streets in which there is a public sanitary sewer, on which private courts, lanes and alleys there are located two (2) or more separate lots and houses, such lots and houses may be connected by the use of one sewer laid in such private court, lane or alley connecting with the public sanitary sewer in such street, such sewer to be constructed by the owners of property fronting on such private court, lane or alley at their joint expense, and under the supervision of the manager of the commissioners of public works or upon the written request of the owner of any property fronting on such private court, lane or alley, the city may construct such sewer and the owners of adjoining property may connect with the same, provided they pay their proportionate cost of the same. For such purpose, the manager of commissioners of public works shall keep in his office a record of the cost of such sewer and shall establish the proportion which each owner shall pay. In the event of any disagreement as to such cost, the person affected shall have the right of appeal to the city council. Six (6) inch lines may be laid in private property after approval by the inspections division, but only when there is not less than ten (10) feet of four (4) inch pipe to the closet or slop sink and where there are a number of small houses on one lot. 
(b)  No more than one drain shall be used to connect a building with the public sanitary sewers without special permit of the manager of the commissioners of public works and the inspections division. 
(Code 1975, § 42-45) 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17.  
Sec. 30-126. - Drains—General construction requirements. 
No drain connected with the public sanitary sewer shall be laid at a less grade than one in one hundred (100) without the written permission of the inspections division. In all ditches where the bottom is unsafe from any cause, the grade shall be made secure by concrete, planking or other means, to the satisfaction of the inspections division, or by the use of cast iron or fibre pipe of satisfactory quality. If water pipe is laid in the sewer connection trench, it shall be laid well to one side and above the sewer. Iron water pipes shall be laid in a separate trench. 
(Code 1975, § 42-46)  
Sec. 30-127. - Same—Size; depth for laying pipes and drains. 
All drains connected with the public sanitary sewers or branches shall be four (4) inches in diameter, except as provided in section 30-125. No earthenware pipe shall be laid less than one foot under cover of earth. All drains of less depth shall be of cast-iron pipe, with well-calked lead joints. 
(Code 1975, § 42-47)  
Sec. 30-128. - Laying pipe in street within five feet of street sanitary sewer prohibited. 
No person shall lay any pipe or conduit for any purpose whatsoever in any street within five (5) feet on either side of the public sanitary sewer in such street. 
(Code 1975, § 42-48)  
Sec. 30-129. - Opening trenches in street or public way. 
In opening trenches in any street or public way, the paving or ballast shall be removed with care, the sides of the trench shall be sheeted or braced when directed and in the manner directed by the department of public service. The earth thrown from the trench shall be placed so as not to obstruct the gutters and so as to cause the least obstruction to public travel. Gas and water pipes shall be protected from injury, the trench enclosed and lighted at night and every precaution taken to prevent injury to person or property during the progress of the work. 
(Code 1975, § 42-49)  
Secs. 30-130—30-145. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - UNDERGROUND CONDUITS, CABLES AND WIRES IN PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY 
 
Sec. 30-146. - Compliance with article required. 
All persons to whom a permit may be granted for running or laying underground conduits, ducts or pipes for electrical conductors or cables or wires, or who shall be required by law or ordinance to do so, shall comply with the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 18-92)  
Sec. 30-147. - Permit to lay conduits—Required. 
No street, lane, alley, road or public place in the city shall be broken or occupied by any person for the purpose of laying down conduits, ducts or pipes except under a permit from the department of public service, as provided in this article. 
(Code 1975, § 18-93) 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17.  
Sec. 30-148. - Same—Application; filing of plans and specifications. 
Any person duly authorized by the city council to run or lay underground conduits, ducts or pipes for electrical conductors, cables or wires, and desiring a permit as required in section 30-147 shall file with the department of public service an application therefor, with plans and specifications showing the location, routes and length of the proposed underground conduits, ducts or pipes. Such application shall be filed at least seventy-two (72) hours before the date scheduled for beginning the work, but in an emergency, the department of public service shall waive prior notice. 
(Code 1975, § 18-94)  
Sec. 30-149. - Same—Issuance; penalty for opening street without permit. 
The department of public service is hereby authorized, upon the filing of the application and plans and specifications required by section 30-148, to grant a permit for the breaking and occupancy of the streets, lanes, alleys, roads and public places as shall be set forth in such application, plans and specifications, subject to the regulations and qualifications of this article. The department of public service shall immediately notify the department of traffic and transportation if the permit will require blocking or diversion of, or interfere with normal pedestrian or vehicular traffic. The opening of any street or public place for such purposes without a permit having been first obtained shall subject such person to punishment as provided in section 1-16 of this Code and the stoppage of the work until such permission is obtained. 
(Code 1975, § 18-95)  
Sec. 30-150. - Excavations; length and width; time restrictions; restoration of street surface. 
During the construction or laying down of underground conduits, ducts or pipes, conductors, cables or wires under this article, no street, alley, lane or road or public place shall be opened or roadway broken into for a greater distance than one thousand (1,000) feet at any one time, or opening, and no section of one thousand (1,000) feet shall be kept open for a longer period than ten (10) days. Such opening or trench shall not be of greater width than five (5) feet, except the manholes, and as the work progresses the paving shall be promptly and properly relaid and the street, alley, lane or road put in good condition at the expense of the person constructing the same. For good cause shown the department of public service may extend the time during which such trench may be kept open. 
(Code 1975, § 18-96)  
Sec. 30-151. - Inspection of work by city; access of officials. 
The work of constructing any underground conduits, or laying any ducts, pipes, electrical conductors, cables or wires under this article shall be subject to inspection by the department of public service, who shall have at all times free and unobstructed access to the conduits, ducts or pipes, electrical conductors, or cables for the purpose of making such inspection. 
(Code 1975, § 18-97)  
Sec. 30-152. - Liability for damage to gas or water mains or sewer connections; bond required. 
All persons occupying any streets, lanes, alleys or roads with poles or with underground conduits, ducts, pipes, cables, electrical conductors or wires under this article shall be liable for all damages to gas and water mains, sewers and sewer connections and drains and drain connections, for all damages which may come to the city directly and proximately, or for which it may be in any manner whatsoever responsible, caused by the opening of trenches or the condition of streets, alleys, lanes or roads resulting from the erection of poles or the construction of conduits or the laying of ducts, pipes, electrical conductors, cables or wires or making connection, and good and sufficient bond shall be given, subject to the approval of the mayor, in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) as the security for the same. 
(Code 1975, § 18-98)  
Sec. 30-153. - Authority of city to require duct for fire and police purposes. 
Any person constructing conduits or laying ducts or pipes under this article shall furnish to the city, on demand, one duct for municipal fire and police purposes; provided, however, that no electric light or power wire shall be placed or used by the city or by any other person in any duct or conduit constructed or used by any telephone or telegraph company. 
(Code 1975, § 18-99)  
Sec. 30-154. - Report of underground conduits and wires by owners. 
All persons having telegraph, telephone or electric light wires, electrical conductors or cables placed underground shall, whenever thereto required by the mayor of the city, file their report within thirty (30) days thereafter, under oath, with the mayor, showing the actual number of wires and their location, and the miles of wire and electrical conductors underground, owned or leased or controlled by them in the city. 
(Code 1975, § 18-100)  
Sec. 30-155. - Bond for restoration of street surface required. 
Upon the passage of any ordinance granting any individual privileges under this article or under any ordinance in force relating to or regulating or requiring underground wires, electrical conductors, conduits, pipes or tubes, the individual shall, before exercising any privileges or requirements thereunder, give a bond to be prepared and approved by the corporation counsel and the mayor, and to be entered of record, in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) conditioned that they will properly relay and pave all openings made by them. Such bond shall be cancelled when such openings shall have been properly relaid and paved and accepted as such by the city engineer. No permit shall be issued, as provided in section 30-149, until this condition is complied with. 
(Code 1975, § 18-101)  
Sec. 30-156. - Telegraph, telephone and burglar alarm business; construction and maintenance of conduits. 
All persons conducting a telegraph, telephone or burglar alarm business, shall, when so required by the public works and utilities committee of the city council, construct and maintain, each for himself, or conjointly, should they so determine and agree, such conduits or subways including necessary manholes and house connections in the streets, as may be necessary to contain the wires used and to be used by them, or any or either of them, or their lessees, along and through the streets. 
(Code 1975, § 18-102)  
Secs. 30-157—30-170. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - UNDERGROUND UTILITY DISTRICTS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 30-171. - Designation of underground utility districts. 
The city council shall from time to time by ordinance designate and extend underground utility districts within the city. 
(Code 1975, § 18-103)  
Sec. 30-172. - Relocation of overhead wires in district. 
(a)  City council shall from time by ordinance designate underground utility districts for non-standard service within the City of Charleston. 
(b)  Prior to an area of the city being designated as an underground utility district for non-standard service (hereinafter referred to as "district"), a written petition, signed by sixty-six and two-thirds (66 2/3 ) percent or more in number of the owners, as hereinafter defined, owning at least sixty-six and two-thirds (66 2/3 ) percent of the assessed value of the real property in the area requesting the non-standard service, including those property owners that are exempt from ad valorem taxation as provided by law, shall be submitted to city council to request non-standard service within said area. The petition shall describe the area in which the non-standard service is being requested (hereinafter referred to as the "proposed district"), and shall include a list of all property owners therein, identified as either exempt or non-exempt from ad valorem taxation as provided by law, the property addresses, mailing addresses of the property owners within the proposed district if they receive mail at a different address and the tax map numbers assigned to each parcel of property in the proposed district. The petition shall further provide that the responsibility of securing the necessary easements within the proposed district that shall be necessary to support the aboveground and underground facilities and equipment for the non-standard service shall be borne by the property owners within the proposed district at no cost to the city or the company. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, an owner shall be defined as any person eighteen (18) years of age, or older, or the proper legal representative for any person younger than eighteen (18) years of age, and any firm or corporation, who or which owns legal title to a present possessory interest in real estate equal to a life estate or greater (expressly excluding leaseholds, easements, equitable interests, inchoate rights, dower rights and future interests) and who or which owns, at the date of the petition, at least an undivided one-tenth ( 1/10 ) interest in a single parcel of real estate and whose name appears on the county tax records as an owner of real estate. 
(d)  Upon receipt and approval of the petition as provided in paragraph (b) above, the city shall submit the petition to the company for the purpose of undertaking the planning, designing, engineering and cost estimating for the non-standard service project. Upon the completion of the planning, designing, engineering and cost estimating for the non-standard service project in the proposed district, the company shall submit to the city its plans and cost estimate for the project, the easement locations for the aboveground and underground facilities and equipment for non-standard service and the cost associated with each parcel within the proposed district connecting to the non-standard service facilities and equipment (hereinafter referred to as the "plans"). The city, upon completion of its review, shall submit the plans and the estimated amount of the annual underground utility fee to the property owners within the proposed district. 
(e)  Prior to the city designating a proposed district as a district, the city shall receive a second petition signed by sixty-six and two-thirds (66 2/3 ) percent or more of the owners owning at least sixty-six and two-thirds (66 2/3 ) percent of the assessed value of the real property within the proposed district. The petition shall provide that the property owners agree to the plans, agree to pay the cost to connect to the underground facilities and equipment upon completion of construction of the project and agree to be responsible for fifteen (15) percent of the total cost of the non-standard service project by the payment of the underground utility fee. The petition shall include all necessary easements from the property owners on whose land the aboveground and underground non-standard service facilities and equipment shall be placed. 
(f)  Upon receipt of the second petition as provided in paragraph (e) above, the city shall, by ordinance, designate the area described in the petition as a district. 
(g)  The city shall establish a priority list for districts (hereinafter referred to as the "priority list"). A district shall be added to the priority list once the requirements contained in paragraphs (a) through (f) above have been met. The company shall be required to commence construction of non-standard service projects within a district within twelve (12) months of it being placed on the priority list, subject to the company's ability to construct more than one (1) district at a time and subject to the amounts present or anticipated in the fund that are reasonably projected to be adequate to cover the costs of the non-standard service projects as they are incurred. Such projects shall be undertaken in advance of amounts being designated to the fund, however, so long as future revenues to the fund over the next successive ten-year period are reasonably projected by the company to be adequate to cover any negative balances and associated finance and federal and state income tax charges, and to provide for a contingency balance of twenty-five (25) percent in the fund. Once commenced, the company shall carry underground utility district non-standard service projects to completion. 
(h)  After a district has been designated and prior to commencement of construction, the city shall authorize the collection of an underground utility fee from the property owners of each parcel within the district by ordinance pursuant to Section 6-1-330, South Carolina Code of Laws, as amended. The underground utility fee shall be based on a combination of fifty (50) percent of the assessed value and fifty (50) percent of the front footage of all real property located within the district with the exception of marshes, wetlands, or retention or detention ponds that cannot be developed under applicable federal, state or local law. The aforesaid fee shall be collected by the city or its agent on an annual basis and deposited into the fund until fifteen (15) percent of the total cost of the nonstandard service within the district is collected. 
(i)  When any street or portion thereof within the City of Charleston is designated as a district, any person, firm, company or corporation owning or maintaining overhead wires or equipment, associated overhead structures or poles serving the same in such street or portion thereof shall remove such wires and equipment, associated structures and poles prior to or concurrently with the underground placement of non-standard service utilities in the district and shall install same underground concurrently with the underground placement of non-Standard service utilities in the district, with the exception of such poles as are necessary to support street lighting, traffic signals and transmission lines above forty-three thousand (43,000) volts. 
(Code 1975, § 18-104; Ord. No. 1999-162, § 2, 11-16-99; Ord. No. 2001-109, § 1, 10-9-01)  
Sec. 30-173. - Limitations on new above-surface installations. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct, maintain or use any pole, overhead wires or associated structure within an underground utility district, excepting such poles as are necessary to support street lighting, traffic signals, and transmission lines above forty-three thousand (43,000) volts, after the date when such utilities are required to have been removed, or after a reasonable period of time after the designation by city council of an underground utility district or the extension of an existing district. 
(Code 1975, § 18-105)  
Sec. 30-174. - Notice of district establishment to utility companies and property owners. 
Within sixty (60) days after the passage of an Ordinance which provides for the assessment and collection of an underground utility fee and connection costs within a utility district, the clerk of council shall mail a notice of such action to all affected utilities and all persons owning real estate in the affected area. Such notice shall be directed to the last known address of such utility or property owner, as shown on the records of the city treasurer. Such notice shall advise property owners that overhead wires, poles and associated structures are to be removed, and if such property owners or their tenants desire to continue to receive utility service or services, such property owners shall at their expense make the necessary modifications to facilities on their property in order to receive such underground service from the utilities' specified terminal point. If no other changes are made in owner's facilities, then only that portion being modified to receive underground service shall be upgraded to conform to the city electrical code. 
(Code 1975, § 18-106; Ord. No. 2005-18, § VI, 1-25-05)  
Sec. 30-175. - Adaptation of service facilities of structure by property owner. 
All conduits, conductors and associated equipment necessary to receive utility service between service conductors or underground pipe or conduit of the supplying utility and the service facilities to the structure being served shall be provided by the person owning such property. Such required construction shall be accomplished within one hundred eighty (180) days after the installation of the utility's facilities. 
(Code 1975, § 18-107)  
Sec. 30-176. - Discontinuance of service to premises for noncompliance. 
If the property owner does not comply with section 30-175, within the time specified therein, the department of public service shall have authority to order disconnection and removal of any and all poles, overhead wires or associated overhead structures supplying utility service to such property and the utility shall not be required thereafter to provide service to such premises, until the owner makes the necessary changes. 
(Code 1975, § 18-108)  
Sec. 30-177. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any provision of this article or failing to comply with any order issued pursuant hereto shall be punished as provided in section 1-16 of this Code. 
(Code 1975, § 18-109)  
Secs. 30-178—30-180. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - SPECIFIC UNDERGROUND UTILITY DISTRICTS

(b)  City council authorizes the expenditure from the fund for the purpose of providing SCE&G and the city's portion of the funding for The Crescent Neighborhood underground utility district for non-standard service as more fully set forth in Exhibit A.

(e)  All property owners within the Crescent Neighborhood Underground Utility District are required to connect to the underground service to be installed in accordance with this section and shall pay the cost for connection. 
(Ord. No. 2005-18, §§ I—VI, 1-25-05)
